description: Our Service Design show takes the ideas for new services born in Service Strategy and turns these into a defined blueprint for the development of the services. We look at the operational aspects to designing an IT service, such as Service Level Management, managing suppliers, and planning for service availability and resilience. All of our planning cumulates into a Design Package which we then handover to the Service Transition lifecycle phase. Like all ITIL shows we also look at critical success factors and key performance indicators and we do some exam prep too!

episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:03.839
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:03.839 --> 00:00:06.040
Hi, and welcome to ITPro.TV.

3
00:00:06.040 --> 00:00:08.210
My name is Jo Peacock and

4
00:00:08.210 --> 00:00:13.190
I'm going to be taking you through
an introduction to your ITIL intermediate.

5
00:00:14.320 --> 00:00:18.710
So, let's take a look then,
at our first slide here, coming up and

6
00:00:18.710 --> 00:00:23.840
we have our introduction to
our intermediate class and

7
00:00:23.840 --> 00:00:27.730
exactly what content is going to be found
in this upcoming intermediate class.

8
00:00:27.730 --> 00:00:32.340
You will see what we will cover
is an introduction to the class,

9
00:00:32.340 --> 00:00:37.100
followed by the principles and
the processes of the Life Cycle phase.

10
00:00:37.100 --> 00:00:39.240
Then we'll take a look at organizing for

11
00:00:39.240 --> 00:00:43.500
that Life Cycle phase and
also the technology considerations,

12
00:00:43.500 --> 00:00:48.270
especially those that we need when
we're implementing the phase itself.

13
00:00:48.270 --> 00:00:51.880
Then we'll take a look at the challenges
and the critical success factors, and

14
00:00:51.880 --> 00:00:57.110
all of the risks that are associated
with that particular lifecycle phase.

15
00:00:57.110 --> 00:01:00.850
And most importantly, of course,
for you is that preparation for

16
00:01:00.850 --> 00:01:04.980
the exam that's going to be coming up
when you have completed your class.

17
00:01:05.980 --> 00:01:10.670
So let me take a look now then at how
we're going to approach this particular

18
00:01:10.670 --> 00:01:11.790
intermediate class.

19
00:01:14.250 --> 00:01:17.230
We're going to be doing
some presentation work.

20
00:01:17.230 --> 00:01:22.550
Obviously, you're going to be watching us
on screen, both myself and my colleagues,

21
00:01:22.550 --> 00:01:27.110
and we're going to be taking you through
the course materials for the class.

22
00:01:27.110 --> 00:01:29.910
And then there are going
to be some discussions and

23
00:01:29.910 --> 00:01:35.530
some exercises that are going to be
based primarily in our chat rooms,

24
00:01:35.530 --> 00:01:38.140
and also in our forums as well.

25
00:01:38.140 --> 00:01:42.530
And we're also available if you want
to undertake any of the assessments,

26
00:01:42.530 --> 00:01:45.840
then please feel free to come
back to us via the forums.

27
00:01:45.840 --> 00:01:49.270
And we will be able to help
you out in anyway we can.

28
00:01:49.270 --> 00:01:53.130
Also provided in the course material,
which is available for you to download,

29
00:01:53.130 --> 00:01:57.540
are mock tests or
exams if you prefer to use that word and

30
00:01:57.540 --> 00:02:02.720
we will be conducting a run
through of that mock exam for you.

31
00:02:04.530 --> 00:02:08.770
So where are we then at
ITIL intermediate level?

32
00:02:08.770 --> 00:02:13.590
Well, you'll see in using
Bloom's Taxonomy that we are actually at

33
00:02:13.590 --> 00:02:15.090
level 4, analyzing.

34
00:02:15.090 --> 00:02:19.806
In other words, at the foundation level,
we've done the remembering and

35
00:02:19.806 --> 00:02:24.660
the understanding of those concepts
within ITIL, and we are actually moving

36
00:02:24.660 --> 00:02:29.160
through applying those concepts
to analyzing those concepts and

37
00:02:29.160 --> 00:02:33.240
being able to apply the ITIL processes and

38
00:02:33.240 --> 00:02:39.130
also the concepts at a real world level,
in a real world situation, okay.

39
00:02:39.130 --> 00:02:42.590
So where does ITIL come from then?

40
00:02:42.590 --> 00:02:45.080
Well let me give you a little
bit of a background.

41
00:02:45.080 --> 00:02:48.430
It's actually owned by
a company called Axelos and

42
00:02:48.430 --> 00:02:54.110
it was first published in the mid
1980s by the UK government.

43
00:02:54.110 --> 00:02:59.430
And the office of government
commerce owned ITIL for a very,

44
00:02:59.430 --> 00:03:04.509
very long time and we developed ITIL
right the way back to the 1980s.

45
00:03:05.630 --> 00:03:09.300
Through it's version two in the 1990s,

46
00:03:09.300 --> 00:03:12.820
mid 1990s, to version three
which was released in 2007 and

47
00:03:13.840 --> 00:03:18.920
there was an update to
version three in 2011.

48
00:03:18.920 --> 00:03:23.460
Which is exactly where we are right now,
it is copyrighted,

49
00:03:23.460 --> 00:03:28.750
is trade-mark protected, it's
a framework for managing services, and

50
00:03:28.750 --> 00:03:33.830
this, should you say flexible framework,
a framework that we would expect

51
00:03:33.830 --> 00:03:39.940
any organization to adopt as a framework,
but then to adapt it to suit your needs.

52
00:03:41.500 --> 00:03:47.960
itSMF was born right the way in the 1980s
out of a desire to be able to demonstrate

53
00:03:47.960 --> 00:03:54.340
value for money and efficiency for
the use of tax payers Money within the UK.

54
00:03:54.340 --> 00:03:58.650
Way back in the 1980s,
these things started appearing on desks.

55
00:03:58.650 --> 00:04:03.880
And quite frankly, we didn't know
how to manage these in an unbiased,

56
00:04:03.880 --> 00:04:08.360
in an impartial, and
in efficient and effective way.

57
00:04:08.360 --> 00:04:10.420
And thus ITIL was born.

58
00:04:10.420 --> 00:04:15.110
And ITIL was born from
a group of industry experts

59
00:04:15.110 --> 00:04:19.960
that went out into the big wide world and
analyzed various organizations.

60
00:04:19.960 --> 00:04:23.270
From various different industry sectors,
not just government but

61
00:04:23.270 --> 00:04:26.690
we're talking finance,
we're talking retail, etc.

62
00:04:26.690 --> 00:04:31.230
And they came back with
a set of best practices.

63
00:04:31.230 --> 00:04:37.380
Best practices that they observed in the
real world for managing our IT services.

64
00:04:38.380 --> 00:04:40.220
And thus we have ITIL.

65
00:04:40.220 --> 00:04:43.520
And as I've already said,
we've had subsequent revisions.

66
00:04:43.520 --> 00:04:47.800
And now we're up to versions 3 2011.

67
00:04:47.800 --> 00:04:56.240
So we work on the understanding that
we have a life to every single service.

68
00:04:57.500 --> 00:05:01.780
And we start off with the concept and
service strategy, and then,

69
00:05:01.780 --> 00:05:07.600
we take that concept and
we design it, and then we develop it,

70
00:05:07.600 --> 00:05:11.360
and we deploy it as a service
into a live environment,

71
00:05:11.360 --> 00:05:14.520
which is where we operate and
where we maintain it.

72
00:05:14.520 --> 00:05:18.345
And we continually seek to ensure that we

73
00:05:18.345 --> 00:05:22.230
are aligned with the needs
of the organization in CSI.

74
00:05:24.960 --> 00:05:29.040
So, you're attending this class
because you probably want

75
00:05:29.040 --> 00:05:33.040
to achieve an ITIL
intermediate qualification.

76
00:05:34.180 --> 00:05:37.920
So you can see that if we were
to start off right at the very,

77
00:05:37.920 --> 00:05:40.280
very top, you'll see where I am.

78
00:05:40.280 --> 00:05:46.560
I am an accredited ITIL trainer working
with an accredited training organization.

79
00:05:46.560 --> 00:05:51.610
I'm also a credited examiner and
proctor or invigilator for

80
00:05:51.610 --> 00:05:57.020
these exams and work very, very closely
with the official ITIL accreditor and

81
00:05:57.020 --> 00:06:00.560
also Axelos who owns the ITIL copyright.

82
00:06:02.100 --> 00:06:07.080
Now in terms of ITIL, where can you
go with your qualification level?

83
00:06:07.080 --> 00:06:13.130
Well, we start off with ITIL Foundation
and ITIL Foundation would traditionally be

84
00:06:13.130 --> 00:06:20.020
a three-day classroom experience where
we learn the foundations of ITIL.

85
00:06:20.020 --> 00:06:23.640
And we learned all the terminology and all
of the definitions to that terminology.

86
00:06:23.640 --> 00:06:28.900
There's roughly around about 75 that we
learned within the ITIL Foundation class.

87
00:06:28.900 --> 00:06:34.530
And then as we move through, we can either
take a ITIL partition class, which can be

88
00:06:34.530 --> 00:06:40.820
taken at any point in time throughout the
progression of your career within ITIL.

89
00:06:40.820 --> 00:06:46.220
Because ITIL practitioner focuses on
the implementation of ITIL, okay?

90
00:06:46.220 --> 00:06:50.960
Whereas if we take a look at the more
advanced intermediate classes you are at

91
00:06:50.960 --> 00:06:55.040
this moment in a Lifecycle Module.

92
00:06:55.040 --> 00:06:59.720
And those Lifecycles consist of
service strategy, service design,

93
00:06:59.720 --> 00:07:04.470
service transition, service operation,
and continual service improvement.

94
00:07:04.470 --> 00:07:07.680
And that's where we focus on those
Lifecycles that we've just looked at

95
00:07:07.680 --> 00:07:09.330
previously.

96
00:07:09.330 --> 00:07:11.630
Okay.
And on the right-hand side then,

97
00:07:11.630 --> 00:07:16.630
we have our Capability Modules, and
these Capability Modules really

98
00:07:16.630 --> 00:07:22.020
focus on specific areas
within ITIL such as

99
00:07:22.020 --> 00:07:27.560
RCV focuses on release control and
validation.

100
00:07:27.560 --> 00:07:30.240
And these classes,
you will notice that every single

101
00:07:30.240 --> 00:07:34.430
one of these classes has got
a skull right beside each one.

102
00:07:34.430 --> 00:07:39.229
So we go to number two for
ITIL Foundation and we've got a three for

103
00:07:39.229 --> 00:07:44.660
Life Cycle modules, and we've got
a four for our capabilities modules.

104
00:07:44.660 --> 00:07:49.710
Now, what we need to do is
ensure that we have achieved

105
00:07:49.710 --> 00:07:55.425
a minimum of fifteen credits
at both either Lifecycle or

106
00:07:55.425 --> 00:08:00.555
Capability module level in order
to be able to qualify to sit

107
00:08:00.555 --> 00:08:04.165
the Managing Across
the Life Cycle class and

108
00:08:04.165 --> 00:08:08.665
therefore subsequently the test
that goes along with that class.

109
00:08:08.665 --> 00:08:11.995
So we need to take two
from the ITIL foundation.

110
00:08:11.995 --> 00:08:13.065
That's a prerequisite.

111
00:08:13.065 --> 00:08:14.905
We have to do the foundation.

112
00:08:14.905 --> 00:08:19.500
And then we need to add in
another 15 scores from either,

113
00:08:19.500 --> 00:08:22.890
as I've said, the Life Cycle or
the Capability Stream.

114
00:08:22.890 --> 00:08:24.090
You can interchange.

115
00:08:24.090 --> 00:08:25.560
You can mix and match.

116
00:08:25.560 --> 00:08:29.100
You do not have to stick to one stream or
the other.

117
00:08:29.100 --> 00:08:32.055
Once you've got that 17 in total,

118
00:08:32.055 --> 00:08:37.165
both scores that are needed to be able
to sit managing across the Lifecycle.

119
00:08:37.165 --> 00:08:41.345
You're perfectly able to sit
that Lifecycle class, and

120
00:08:41.345 --> 00:08:43.845
to be able to take that test afterwards.

121
00:08:43.845 --> 00:08:48.145
And as soon as you've taken that test,
you will be awarded those five credits.

122
00:08:48.145 --> 00:08:52.535
Which will mean that you
have achieved ITL Expert.

123
00:08:52.535 --> 00:08:57.250
Now ITL Expert is allocated
as soon as you have Pass

124
00:08:57.250 --> 00:09:02.510
the management across the Lifecycle
test and have achieved 22 credits.

125
00:09:02.510 --> 00:09:05.770
Both of those must happen in order for
you to achieve ITIL expert.

126
00:09:07.380 --> 00:09:10.620
Now we have the ITIL Master
qualification and

127
00:09:10.620 --> 00:09:14.630
the ITIL Master is
a completely different beast.

128
00:09:14.630 --> 00:09:19.220
The ITIL Master is a two
year qualification.

129
00:09:19.220 --> 00:09:25.750
And during that two years, you will be
expected to submit various white papers

130
00:09:25.750 --> 00:09:31.500
on specific topics within
the ideal qualifications scheme.

131
00:09:31.500 --> 00:09:35.870
So these could be topics
on activities within ITIL.

132
00:09:35.870 --> 00:09:38.830
These could be topics on
processes within ITIL.

133
00:09:38.830 --> 00:09:43.870
These could be topics on implementation
of various aspects of ITIL.

134
00:09:43.870 --> 00:09:51.410
You will be required to submit a number of
white papers over the period of two years.

135
00:09:51.410 --> 00:09:56.520
At the end of those two years,
once you have submitted the prerequisite

136
00:09:56.520 --> 00:10:01.260
white papers, then you will be
asked to attend a panel interview.

137
00:10:01.260 --> 00:10:04.630
And during that panel interview,
you will be assessed.

138
00:10:04.630 --> 00:10:06.930
Not only on your white papers but

139
00:10:06.930 --> 00:10:11.631
also on your experience within
the IT service management arena.

140
00:10:11.631 --> 00:10:14.540
And at the end of that
panel interview then if

141
00:10:14.540 --> 00:10:18.020
successful you will be awarded
to state of this ITIL master.

142
00:10:20.060 --> 00:10:24.810
So the qualification scheme, I'm going to
take this back now to Bloom's Taxonomy

143
00:10:24.810 --> 00:10:29.360
then and just very, very quickly look at
the fact that in ITIL Foundation, and

144
00:10:29.360 --> 00:10:31.992
I know that I've already covered
this in a previous slide.

145
00:10:31.992 --> 00:10:36.700
But we've just looked at understanding,
understanding the terminology and

146
00:10:36.700 --> 00:10:39.345
the concepts of ITIL foundation.

147
00:10:39.345 --> 00:10:41.340
And then in the Lifecycle modules,

148
00:10:41.340 --> 00:10:45.700
we're looking at implementing
those processes contained within.

149
00:10:45.700 --> 00:10:50.990
And then capability, we're looking at
actually undertaking those processes and

150
00:10:50.990 --> 00:10:53.070
managing those processes.

151
00:10:53.070 --> 00:10:57.890
With managing across the Lifecycle,
this is so senior management.

152
00:10:57.890 --> 00:11:02.090
This is that CIO level and
it's senior management level.

153
00:11:02.090 --> 00:11:05.905
And in MALC as we like
to abbreviate it to,

154
00:11:05.905 --> 00:11:10.475
your concern with leading
IT Service Management.

155
00:11:10.475 --> 00:11:15.385
So I mentioned right to the very beginning
of all of this that we had a test

156
00:11:15.385 --> 00:11:20.735
to go along with every single
Lifecycle phase and varies.

157
00:11:20.735 --> 00:11:25.865
And we will be conducting a session to
go all over this particular test or

158
00:11:25.865 --> 00:11:30.530
at least a sample of this test just
to give you some preparation for

159
00:11:30.530 --> 00:11:32.960
the actual test itself.

160
00:11:32.960 --> 00:11:37.600
So, your test is conducted online,
it's conducted virtually.

161
00:11:39.160 --> 00:11:42.699
It is an eight multiple
choice question test.

162
00:11:44.120 --> 00:11:46.390
It's complex multiple choice.

163
00:11:46.390 --> 00:11:49.440
You get an hour and a half for
this particular test and

164
00:11:49.440 --> 00:11:53.640
with every single question,
you will be given a scenario.

165
00:11:53.640 --> 00:11:58.270
And then you will be given
four possible options,

166
00:11:58.270 --> 00:12:04.730
four possible answers, for the question
that is posed along with that scenario.

167
00:12:04.730 --> 00:12:07.830
You get 5 points for the best fit answer.

168
00:12:07.830 --> 00:12:10.410
Now it mentions up there,
the most correct.

169
00:12:10.410 --> 00:12:13.910
I always call it the best fit
because every single question asks

170
00:12:13.910 --> 00:12:19.300
what is the best answer given
the scenario and given the question.

171
00:12:19.300 --> 00:12:23.350
Don't be alarmed if you don't see
an answer that you think is 100% correct

172
00:12:24.870 --> 00:12:27.540
because the question is asking you for

173
00:12:27.540 --> 00:12:32.990
the best and for that best fit
you're going to get five points.

174
00:12:32.990 --> 00:12:36.130
For the next best fit you're
going to get three, for

175
00:12:36.130 --> 00:12:41.410
the next one which we've considered to be
the least correct your going to get one.

176
00:12:41.410 --> 00:12:46.240
And for the next one you're going
to get zero now it mentions

177
00:12:46.240 --> 00:12:51.020
up on that slide there that the next
one is zero marks for incorrect.

178
00:12:51.020 --> 00:12:53.310
We like to call that in the industry.

179
00:12:53.310 --> 00:13:00.600
We call that the distracter and we call it
distracter for a reason cuz it distracts.

180
00:13:00.600 --> 00:13:04.990
And quite often is what you will find is
with your distracter a lot of the words

181
00:13:04.990 --> 00:13:08.599
and the terminology that are taken
straight out of the ITIL book,

182
00:13:08.599 --> 00:13:13.580
straight out of the publication and
are put into that 0 appointed.

183
00:13:13.580 --> 00:13:15.490
Because it's there to distract.

184
00:13:15.490 --> 00:13:21.250
And it sounds great but more often than
not that distracter has absolutely

185
00:13:21.250 --> 00:13:26.600
no relevance to the scenario or
to the question.

186
00:13:26.600 --> 00:13:29.390
So you have to be incredibly
careful with that.

187
00:13:29.390 --> 00:13:31.480
It's so easy to be distracted.

188
00:13:32.800 --> 00:13:38.370
You have to get 28 out of a possible
40 in order to be able to pass and

189
00:13:38.370 --> 00:13:44.540
achieve accreditation at
any Lifecycle test okay?

190
00:13:44.540 --> 00:13:48.610
If English is not your first language
you are allowed a paper dictionary.

191
00:13:48.610 --> 00:13:53.140
But you will be asked to
show that to the proctor at

192
00:13:53.140 --> 00:13:55.650
the time that you take your test.

193
00:13:55.650 --> 00:14:00.610
And as I've already said,
you have to have an ITIL foundation

194
00:14:00.610 --> 00:14:03.780
in version three or version three, 2011.

195
00:14:03.780 --> 00:14:09.310
Or an ITIL version two foundation bridge,
to version three.

196
00:14:10.650 --> 00:14:15.450
I will be very very honest with you,
there are not that many people that have

197
00:14:15.450 --> 00:14:18.580
attained the version two
to version three bridge.

198
00:14:18.580 --> 00:14:21.890
And most people will have
the version three, or

199
00:14:21.890 --> 00:14:25.800
2011, sorry, ideal foundation certificate.

200
00:14:27.540 --> 00:14:31.730
You will be required to
upload that certificate to

201
00:14:31.730 --> 00:14:36.510
the examining board prior to
sitting your Lifecycle test.

202
00:14:36.510 --> 00:14:38.430
So be prepared with that.

203
00:14:38.430 --> 00:14:42.590
You will need to have it to hand and
saved as a pdf as well.

204
00:14:44.250 --> 00:14:50.160
So when we come to the end of
every single lifecycle class,

205
00:14:50.160 --> 00:14:55.030
we will be going over and this one is no
exception, we will be going over a sample

206
00:14:55.030 --> 00:14:59.670
test for you and during that sample test
I will be giving you lots of hints and

207
00:14:59.670 --> 00:15:04.150
tips on how to select that
best fit possible answer.

208
00:15:04.150 --> 00:15:08.300
And also how to ensure that you read
the full question how to relax and

209
00:15:08.300 --> 00:15:12.740
to make sure that you approach
it with an open mind.

210
00:15:12.740 --> 00:15:16.100
But you consider relevance
in every single answer.

211
00:15:17.590 --> 00:15:21.610
Ultimately we wanna get you
pass the test just as much as

212
00:15:21.610 --> 00:15:23.760
you want to achieve that accreditation.

213
00:15:24.970 --> 00:15:31.550
So, just to sum up, what we will
be doing over the next few shows

214
00:15:31.550 --> 00:15:37.460
is encouraging you to take your
ITIL Lifecycle Intermediate classes.

215
00:15:37.460 --> 00:15:41.685
And feel free to join us in the forums for
any questions that you may have.

216
00:15:41.685 --> 00:15:45.954
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo begin the foundation refresher. Jo reviews the key aspects of ITIL foundation by describing the 5 core volume service lifecycles: service strategy, service design, service transition, service operation, and continual service improvement. She also defines what ITIL means by a Service and Service Management. Also the key terms that define value: Utility and Warranty by Jo.
episodes.title: ITIL Foundation Refresher
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.240 --> 00:00:03.671

2
00:00:03.671 --> 00:00:08.253
I'm your host Don [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:08.253 --> 00:00:12.288

4
00:00:12.288 --> 00:00:15.230
>> Welcome to another great
episode right here on IT Pro TV.

5
00:00:15.230 --> 00:00:20.760
You're watching an ITIL Foundation
Refresher for your intermediate class.

6
00:00:20.760 --> 00:00:22.900
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong, and

we're about to get started here with

8
00:00:28.390 --> 00:00:29.820
Jo, welcome back to the show.

9
00:00:29.820 --> 00:00:30.640
>> Thank you, Ronnie.

10
00:00:30.640 --> 00:00:31.520

00:00:31.520 --> 00:00:32.260

12

>> We are doing great today, Jo.

13

As we begin, we understand that
foundations pretty much set the tone for

everything that we'll be

15

So having this refresher at this

00:00:49.790 --> 00:00:51.790

18
00:00:51.790 --> 00:00:56.140
>> Yeah so what we're doing today in this

going over what everyone learned

20
00:01:01.530 --> 00:01:06.120
You see, we cover lots and lots of topics

21
00:01:06.120 --> 00:01:10.990
Whether it be the lifecycle classes,
which the service operation is wide or

whether it be the capability classes,
such as release control validation etc.

23
00:01:16.690 --> 00:01:21.130
Or even through to the A class for
managing across the life cycle or

24
00:01:21.130 --> 00:01:23.430
the ITIL Practitioner Class.

25
00:01:23.430 --> 00:01:27.905
We need to understand that foundation
material because it's foundation and

26
00:01:27.905 --> 00:01:30.050
[LAUGH] it is the foundation for
all of our other material.

27
00:01:30.050 --> 00:01:32.890
Now in our foundation quest in ITIL,

28
00:01:32.890 --> 00:01:37.510
we learn all of the terminologies
that is associated with ITIL, and

29
00:01:37.510 --> 00:01:41.610
all of the 75 terms and
definitions in the ITIL Foundation Class.

30
00:01:42.630 --> 00:01:44.010
And I'll be honest with you,

31
00:01:44.010 --> 00:01:48.620
sometimes the ITIL Foundation class
can be a little bit daunting.

32

Certainly the feedback that you get from a

33
00:01:54.390 --> 00:01:58.770
is that they feel like their brains
are full after the end of the first day.

34
00:01:58.770 --> 00:02:03.090
So what we're going to do really, and
we do this at the start of every single

35
00:02:03.090 --> 00:02:07.620
intermediate class is we will just
go over the foundation principles

36
00:02:07.620 --> 00:02:11.850
just to refresh them in everybody's mind,
and then to act as a basis for

37
00:02:11.850 --> 00:02:15.520
what we're going to cover
over the following sessions.

38
00:02:15.520 --> 00:02:18.300
And so here what we're going to
do over the next few sessions,

39
00:02:18.300 --> 00:02:23.350
is we are going to go over
the ITIL foundation itself.

40
00:02:23.350 --> 00:02:27.660
and we're going to go over the concept
of the Life Cycle, etc and

41
00:02:27.660 --> 00:02:32.120
we're going to be going over,
as I said, the foundation material.

42
00:02:32.120 --> 00:02:34.830
>> Alright, Jo.
This is the best time to get started.

43
00:02:34.830 --> 00:02:36.440
So let's go ahead and do that.

44
00:02:36.440 --> 00:02:38.000
Where are we beginning?

45
00:02:38.000 --> 00:02:39.770
>> Okay, so
the first thing that we're going to do,

46
00:02:39.770 --> 00:02:45.130
and you saw this slide flash up very
very quickly on the screen there and

47
00:02:45.130 --> 00:02:48.930
Let's take a look at that
first particular slide there.

48
00:02:48.930 --> 00:02:51.830
It says here that ITIL is
presented in 5 CORE volumes

49
00:02:51.830 --> 00:02:53.740
that are referred to as
a SERVICE LIFECYCLE.

50
00:02:55.600 --> 00:02:56.910
Let's take a step back.

51
00:02:56.910 --> 00:02:58.460
>> All right.
>> And that's what I want to do.

52
00:03:00.330 --> 00:03:03.990
Let's just think about the fact
that a service, an IT service,

53
00:03:03.990 --> 00:03:07.450
and we're gonna come in to
the definition of service very shortly.

54
00:03:07.450 --> 00:03:12.210
But a service, well it has a beginning and
it has an end.

55
00:03:12.210 --> 00:03:13.410
It starts off as an idea.

56
00:03:15.240 --> 00:03:16.410
These things don't just happen.

57
00:03:16.410 --> 00:03:20.352
You don't just walk in and all of a sudden
everything's there on your laptop okay.

58
00:03:20.352 --> 00:03:26.570
Any new service well it has an idea and
that idea has to be developed.

59
00:03:26.570 --> 00:03:30.510
is gotta be designed first of all, then it
gets developed, and then it gets tested,

60
00:03:30.510 --> 00:03:34.010
and then it gets deployed and
then it's put into the live environment.

61
00:03:34.010 --> 00:03:38.540
And then we're continually checking
that service to make sure it's

62
00:03:38.540 --> 00:03:40.540
doing what it's supposed to do.

63
00:03:40.540 --> 00:03:43.510
And eventually that
service will be retired.

64
00:03:44.730 --> 00:03:47.530
So we refer to that as
the life of a service.

65
00:03:48.980 --> 00:03:51.200
And thatâ€™s the concept of the life cycle.

66
00:03:51.200 --> 00:03:56.280
Is the fact that we understand the concept
that not just all about services but

67
00:03:56.280 --> 00:03:58.520
also IT as a whole.

68
00:03:58.520 --> 00:04:02.360
Well, any process starts off as an idea,
and

69
00:04:02.360 --> 00:04:07.160
then it's designed and then developed and
then built and then transitioned, and

70
00:04:07.160 --> 00:04:12.100
put into the live environment, and
then we wanna continually improve it.

71
00:04:12.100 --> 00:04:12.660
Okay?

72
00:04:12.660 --> 00:04:14.730
And it's the same with any organization,
and

73
00:04:14.730 --> 00:04:18.610
with any IT service provider,
it starts off as an idea.

74
00:04:18.610 --> 00:04:22.210
Things have to start off with a concept.

75
00:04:22.210 --> 00:04:27.700
So what we have is the concept
of a service lifecycle and

76
00:04:27.700 --> 00:04:29.660
we've split it into five.

77
00:04:29.660 --> 00:04:33.560
And in the first book, and
we call them core publications or books,

78
00:04:33.560 --> 00:04:36.640
because there's a book for
each life cycle phase.

79
00:04:36.640 --> 00:04:38.870
And we start off with Service Strategy.

80
00:04:38.870 --> 00:04:42.570
And then that's where our ideas
come from in service strategy.

81
00:04:42.570 --> 00:04:48.210
This is where we go back to the business
and we understand what our business needs.

82
00:04:48.210 --> 00:04:52.880
How our business works and
how we can add value to our business.

83
00:04:52.880 --> 00:04:57.900
And then in service design we then take
that idea that we've came out with

84
00:04:57.900 --> 00:05:02.770
in service strategy and
we design that idea.

85
00:05:02.770 --> 00:05:04.440
This is not where we develop.

86
00:05:04.440 --> 00:05:07.750
This is where we design the idea.

87
00:05:07.750 --> 00:05:11.230
And then in service transition this
is where we do the development and

88
00:05:11.230 --> 00:05:15.850
we do the build and the test and
the deployment of our new services.

89
00:05:15.850 --> 00:05:19.660
And then we deploy them into
the live service operation.

90
00:05:19.660 --> 00:05:23.520
And then on a regular basis,
we want to continually improve.

91
00:05:23.520 --> 00:05:28.010
So while I'm looking at this
next slide and it'll show you

92
00:05:28.010 --> 00:05:31.940
the processes within the next slide, I
want to bring in another concept for you.

93
00:05:31.940 --> 00:05:34.200
I want to take you just out of IT for
a moment.

94
00:05:35.240 --> 00:05:38.040
Because our service strategy I
said we come up with the idea and

95
00:05:38.040 --> 00:05:40.280
we have processes and service strategy.

96
00:05:40.280 --> 00:05:44.390
Such as financial management and business
relationship management and strategy

97
00:05:44.390 --> 00:05:48.255
management where you know we come up with
those ideas to make sure we've got enough

98
00:05:48.255 --> 00:05:53.795
money, and then this service design, we
have things like service level management

99
00:05:53.795 --> 00:05:57.635
that worked hard our targets for
how we're going to deliver that service.

100
00:05:57.635 --> 00:06:01.965
So this is still in design, and
then design, and availability, and

101
00:06:01.965 --> 00:06:05.235
capacity, and continuity, et cetera.

102
00:06:05.235 --> 00:06:07.995
And we've got supply
management in there too.

103
00:06:07.995 --> 00:06:11.120
Now, Let's take this out of IT as I said.

104
00:06:11.120 --> 00:06:13.320
Let's say we were building a house.

105
00:06:14.610 --> 00:06:17.760
Now I know, I've got grand ideas,
I can tell you now.

106
00:06:17.760 --> 00:06:23.675
I know that what I want is I want Say,
five bedroom?

107
00:06:23.675 --> 00:06:25.720
Yeah, I'll reckon that will be enough.

108
00:06:25.720 --> 00:06:26.735
>> [LAUGH]
>> But I want six bathrooms,

109
00:06:26.735 --> 00:06:29.775
cuz I need one bathroom just for
guests that are visiting for the day.

110
00:06:29.775 --> 00:06:34.205
Not that anybody ever visits me, but
nevertheless, I want six bathrooms, okay,

111
00:06:35.365 --> 00:06:40.760
and I don't think I need a swimming pool,
but I wouldn't mind having a dedicated

112
00:06:40.760 --> 00:06:45.640
office just for me, that was sound proof,
that I could work in, that would be great.

113
00:06:45.640 --> 00:06:46.800
That's what I want.

114
00:06:46.800 --> 00:06:49.630
So, what I do with service strategy,
is I go to the bank and I say,

115
00:06:49.630 --> 00:06:50.560
can I have some money?

116
00:06:51.560 --> 00:06:53.580
Okay?
I've got this idea,

117
00:06:53.580 --> 00:06:55.480
can I have some money please?

118
00:06:55.480 --> 00:06:56.490
And here's my idea.

119
00:06:56.490 --> 00:07:00.820
And this is what happens in service
strategy and the end of service strategy

120
00:07:00.820 --> 00:07:05.000
the bank says, yeah, here you go, have
four or five hundred thousand dollars.

121
00:07:06.580 --> 00:07:07.220
There we go.

122
00:07:07.220 --> 00:07:08.150
So now what I do?

123
00:07:08.150 --> 00:07:09.770
What do i do with that
$500,000 do you reckon?

124
00:07:11.530 --> 00:07:14.200
>> You thus take that money,

125
00:07:14.200 --> 00:07:18.970
and you would either have it
designed to be ready to build it.

126
00:07:18.970 --> 00:07:20.590
>> Right, so now I go to an architect.

127
00:07:20.590 --> 00:07:24.780
And so this is what's happening here in
service design is I go to an architect.

128
00:07:24.780 --> 00:07:28.940
And I say,
okay please can you design me a house?

129
00:07:28.940 --> 00:07:30.720
These are my prerequisites.

130
00:07:30.720 --> 00:07:32.440
And generally, you know what?

131
00:07:32.440 --> 00:07:34.180
I'm a customer.

132
00:07:35.330 --> 00:07:38.800
I'm not a builder so
I don't know anything about materials.

133
00:07:38.800 --> 00:07:42.470
But what I do know is that I've got
some very specific requirements.

134
00:07:42.470 --> 00:07:44.460
And probably because
I'm little bit strange.

135
00:07:44.460 --> 00:07:45.980
Very incredibly specific.

136
00:07:45.980 --> 00:07:50.206
So i'm gonna go to him and I'm gonna
say to him I want five bedrooms, and

137
00:07:50.206 --> 00:07:54.572
I want six bathrooms, and I want my
own sorta sound proofed office where,

138
00:07:54.572 --> 00:07:57.460
I still want a window in it,
I like daylight, but

139
00:07:57.460 --> 00:08:01.020
then at the same time I don't
want any noise coming in.

140
00:08:01.020 --> 00:08:05.234
And I want bathrooms and
I wanna have marble in the bathrooms,

141
00:08:05.234 --> 00:08:09.077
and This is everything that I want,
and my kitchen.

142
00:08:09.077 --> 00:08:12.190
I've gotta have one of those
refrigerators with the TV screen in it.

143
00:08:12.190 --> 00:08:15.360
I'm telling you now it's
got to have one of those.

144
00:08:15.360 --> 00:08:17.454
And I want a camera in every room.

145
00:08:17.454 --> 00:08:21.820
And I want at least two
maybe three routers in them.

146
00:08:21.820 --> 00:08:25.870
I want everything to be wireless and
I want everything hidden in the walls.

147
00:08:25.870 --> 00:08:28.500
I don't wanna see any of this technology.

148
00:08:28.500 --> 00:08:29.620
I told you I was picky.

149
00:08:30.685 --> 00:08:34.120
So what I'm going to do is I'm
gonna go to the architect and

150
00:08:34.120 --> 00:08:35.780
I'm gonna tell him all of this.

151
00:08:35.780 --> 00:08:38.952
And he is going to produce a blueprint.

152
00:08:38.952 --> 00:08:42.170
But here's something special
about that blueprint.

153
00:08:42.170 --> 00:08:46.500
That blueprint is not just
going to be the plans,

154
00:08:46.500 --> 00:08:50.400
the two dimensional plans for that house.

155
00:08:51.530 --> 00:08:54.470
What that architect is going to deliver me

156
00:08:54.470 --> 00:08:58.780
is a three dimensional mock-up of what
that house is going to look like.

157
00:08:58.780 --> 00:09:02.180
He's going to include all of the plans for
all of the plumbing, for

158
00:09:02.180 --> 00:09:07.430
all of the electrics, for
all of the IT wiring that I want.

159
00:09:07.430 --> 00:09:12.600
He's going to include all of the list
of contractors that he's going to use,

160
00:09:12.600 --> 00:09:13.860
those suppliers.

161
00:09:13.860 --> 00:09:17.830
He's going to tell me exactly what tiles
are going to be used in the bathroom.

162
00:09:17.830 --> 00:09:20.379
He's going to tell me
exactly where he's going to

163
00:09:21.630 --> 00:09:24.720
purchase all of the furniture from.

164
00:09:24.720 --> 00:09:26.670
Yeah, I didn't mention furniture, did I?

165
00:09:26.670 --> 00:09:30.170
He's gonna tell me where he's
gonna purchase everything,

166
00:09:30.170 --> 00:09:32.830
even the bed sheets and everything from.

167
00:09:32.830 --> 00:09:35.780
He's going to even tell me what color
the bed sheets are going to be.

168
00:09:37.370 --> 00:09:39.240
This is not just any blueprint.

169
00:09:39.240 --> 00:09:44.100
This is what I call, and what we call
in ITIL, a service design package.

170
00:09:45.330 --> 00:09:50.070
And that service design package
contains absolutely everything

171
00:09:50.070 --> 00:09:53.503
that's needed to build, and to test, and

172
00:09:53.503 --> 00:09:59.030
to deploy, and then to run that house.

173
00:09:59.030 --> 00:10:02.680
That service design package even includes
all of the instruction manuals for

174
00:10:02.680 --> 00:10:05.870
all of the appliances and everything
else that I've got in that house.

175
00:10:07.130 --> 00:10:09.460
That's what's in that
service design package.

176
00:10:09.460 --> 00:10:11.710
So we think of it as
an architect's blueprint, but

177
00:10:11.710 --> 00:10:14.790
here in ITIL we think of it
as a service design package.

178
00:10:14.790 --> 00:10:19.030
And this is why we've got all of
those processes in Service Design.

179
00:10:19.030 --> 00:10:23.840
And then what happens is we hand
that over to Service Transition.

180
00:10:23.840 --> 00:10:27.350
We hand it over to the builder,
to the contractors.

181
00:10:27.350 --> 00:10:28.890
And we let them come and do their work.

182
00:10:28.890 --> 00:10:30.980
And they do the build and the tests and

183
00:10:30.980 --> 00:10:33.116
take a look at all of
those processes in there.

184
00:10:33.116 --> 00:10:36.260
They understand with Asset and
Configuration Management

185
00:10:36.260 --> 00:10:39.895
exactly what the wiring's going to look
like and how it's going to hang together.

186
00:10:39.895 --> 00:10:45.080
Cuz the last thing you need is me trying
to put a TV up on that wall over there.

187
00:10:45.080 --> 00:10:49.416
Or me asking for a TV on that wall up
there, and you can't because it's a solid

188
00:10:49.416 --> 00:10:53.237
brick wall, because I wanted it in brick,
all the external walls.

189
00:10:53.237 --> 00:10:56.180
And so the TV can't go on there,
it's gotta go on that wall.

190
00:10:56.180 --> 00:10:56.710
So Asset and

191
00:10:56.710 --> 00:11:00.540
Configuration Management tells me how
everything's going to hang together.

192
00:11:00.540 --> 00:11:04.260
So here in Service Transition,
we do all the build.

193
00:11:04.260 --> 00:11:08.118
And at the end of Service Transition,
what happens is,

194
00:11:08.118 --> 00:11:12.234
I'm the customer, and
somebody hands over the keys to me.

195
00:11:12.234 --> 00:11:17.121
And I walk in that house,
and I open the refrigerator,

196
00:11:17.121 --> 00:11:21.180
the one that was designed
in Service Design.

197
00:11:21.180 --> 00:11:25.250
I get out that bottle of wine that
was designed in Service Design but

198
00:11:25.250 --> 00:11:28.380
is being nicely chilled right now.

199
00:11:28.380 --> 00:11:31.832
And I go to the cupboard in the kitchen
where I said I wanted my glasses

200
00:11:31.832 --> 00:11:32.447
to be kept.

201
00:11:32.447 --> 00:11:35.100
And they've got the right
glasses in the right cupboard.

202
00:11:35.100 --> 00:11:37.510
And I take out a glass,
and I pour my wine.

203
00:11:37.510 --> 00:11:42.210
And I walk over to the couch that I
told Service Design that I wanted.

204
00:11:42.210 --> 00:11:44.910
And sit in front of the tv
with my glass of wine.

205
00:11:44.910 --> 00:11:49.644
And I pick up the controls because
the remote control are next to

206
00:11:49.644 --> 00:11:51.620
the instruction manual.

207
00:11:51.620 --> 00:11:57.650
And I just sit back and I watch TV
because all of my services are in place.

208
00:11:57.650 --> 00:12:03.125
I've got my contracts in place with the TV
company, and with the Internet, etc.

209
00:12:03.125 --> 00:12:06.362
And so now I'm into what
we call Service Operation,

210
00:12:06.362 --> 00:12:09.270
which is just business as usual.

211
00:12:09.270 --> 00:12:10.880
And business as usual is where,

212
00:12:10.880 --> 00:12:15.580
well I just carry on living in
my house without any problems.

213
00:12:15.580 --> 00:12:17.440
Okay that's not going to happen, right?

214
00:12:17.440 --> 00:12:20.130
We know that there
are going to be problems.

215
00:12:20.130 --> 00:12:22.770
And so during Service Operation,

216
00:12:22.770 --> 00:12:26.470
then I'm going to have systems that
are going to monitor Internet usage.

217
00:12:26.470 --> 00:12:33.947
And systems that are going to monitor
what TV that I watch and I set DVRs, etc.

218
00:12:33.947 --> 00:12:37.395
And then, if anything does go wrong,
I've got contractors, etc,

219
00:12:37.395 --> 00:12:40.310
that I can call if anything
goes wrong in the house.

220
00:12:40.310 --> 00:12:42.480
That's incident and problem management.

221
00:12:42.480 --> 00:12:47.940
I know who to call if I want something

And an external service is a service

00:26:37.610 --> 00:26:39.520

something that our customers use such as

00:26:57.050 --> 00:27:02.280
If we're in an industry where we are

00:27:02.280 --> 00:27:07.080

00:27:07.080 --> 00:27:11.440

00:27:52.298 --> 00:27:56.350

00:28:10.120 --> 00:28:11.780

00:28:17.585 --> 00:28:19.727

00:28:19.727 --> 00:28:21.640

00:28:28.590 --> 00:28:32.960

00:28:50.989 --> 00:28:55.600

00:28:55.600 --> 00:28:59.279
So these are our core and

00:29:05.810 --> 00:29:09.460

00:29:13.984 --> 00:29:17.469

00:31:31.340 --> 00:31:36.430

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo continue with the foundation refresher. Jo reviews asset, resource, capabilities and processes from the ITIL perspective. She emphasizes the process model and roles associated with processes. Lastly, she describes the accountability that belongs to the service owner as well.
