differentiation there, okay.

353
00:21:06.630 --> 00:21:12.160
And that service owner takes
accountability for the entire IT service.

354
00:21:13.170 --> 00:21:15.830
As we move through into
service operation and

355
00:21:15.830 --> 00:21:21.130
as we've looked previously at
the life cycle phases within ITIL,

356
00:21:21.130 --> 00:21:25.300
you'll see that there
were 20 odd processes.

357
00:21:25.300 --> 00:21:29.614
Well, that service owner does not take
accountability for all of those processes.

358
00:21:29.614 --> 00:21:33.390
Okay, that service owner takes
accountability for the service.

359
00:21:33.390 --> 00:21:36.220
In that diagram in the bottom
right hand corner there,

360
00:21:36.220 --> 00:21:42.420
you will see that each process
applies to each service.

361
00:21:42.420 --> 00:21:46.723
So if we looked to process one and we said
that that was incident management, well,

362
00:21:46.723 --> 00:21:49.616
incident management applies
to every single service.

363
00:21:49.616 --> 00:21:52.771
And problem management applies
to every single service, and

364
00:21:52.771 --> 00:21:55.980
request fulfillment applies
to every single service.

365
00:21:55.980 --> 00:22:00.517
But you will notice that each
service is separate, and so,

366
00:22:00.517 --> 00:22:05.889
each service or each silo, as it is there,
will have a service owner.

367
00:22:05.889 --> 00:22:11.360
And we use that word accountable again,
and we use the word ensure, okay?

368
00:22:11.360 --> 00:22:17.060
They ensure that value is delivered
to the organization, okay.

369
00:22:17.060 --> 00:22:19.350
So they'll liaise with the process owners,
but

370
00:22:19.350 --> 00:22:21.930
they'll liaise with business
relationship management.

371
00:22:21.930 --> 00:22:26.190
They will liaise with our organization,
and

372
00:22:26.190 --> 00:22:29.440
they will be present in our
service review meetings,

373
00:22:29.440 --> 00:22:33.580
which is where we review performance
against those service level targets.

374
00:22:33.580 --> 00:22:38.500
In service level management and
with our customer as well, so

375
00:22:38.500 --> 00:22:41.170
I expect the service owners
to be present for that.

376
00:22:41.170 --> 00:22:45.510
Ultimately, the service owner takes
accountability for a service.

377
00:22:47.080 --> 00:22:49.170
So in this particular section here then,

378
00:22:49.170 --> 00:22:54.250
well, in the last two sections we've
done a very, very brief overview of some

379
00:22:54.250 --> 00:22:59.199
of the fundamentals that we learned
within our ITIL foundation class.

380
00:23:00.380 --> 00:23:05.030
Now, I do understand that there
is a lot to learn there so

381
00:23:05.030 --> 00:23:09.730
please feel free to browse further
the ITIL foundation material

382
00:23:09.730 --> 00:23:13.300
that is available here through ITProTV.

383
00:23:13.300 --> 00:23:16.290
But what I would ask you
to do now is obviously

384
00:23:16.290 --> 00:23:19.750
to move into your service
operation material and

385
00:23:19.750 --> 00:23:23.600
to take a look at all of our
other service operation modules.

386
00:23:23.600 --> 00:23:27.170
>> All right, Jo, well, thank you again
for helping us out and reminding us of

387
00:23:27.170 --> 00:23:31.740
some of those foundational concepts
that we may be a little bit weak on.

388
00:23:31.740 --> 00:23:32.850
But now with this refresher,

389
00:23:32.850 --> 00:23:37.440
it means we're ready to head on
to our ITIL intermediate show.

390
00:23:37.440 --> 00:23:39.520
Well, great place for us to sign off then.

391
00:23:39.520 --> 00:23:42.480
For ITProTV I'm your host Ronnie Wong.

392
00:23:42.480 --> 00:23:43.680
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

393
00:23:43.680 --> 00:23:49.062
>> Stay tuned right now for
your ITIL intermediate introduction.

394
00:23:49.062 --> 00:23:54.270
[MUSIC]

395
00:23:54.270 --> 00:23:57.665
Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Cherokee and Jo explain some minimal improvement requirements including offering an embed continual improvement in all aspects of design. Jo also emphasis the importance of identifying  business trends that may offer up design improvements. In addition they discuss the scope of a service design and cover ways to provide business value.
episodes.title: Objectives, Scope and Value
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.330 --> 00:00:01.431
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.431 --> 00:00:02.672
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

3
00:00:02.672 --> 00:00:06.311
[CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:06.311 --> 00:00:08.273
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:08.273 --> 00:00:12.060
>> You're watching ITProTV.

6
00:00:12.060 --> 00:00:16.710
>> Welcome to your ITIL Intermediate
Series, I'm your show host Cherokee Boose.

7
00:00:16.710 --> 00:00:19.565
In this episode, we'll continue
down our Service Design track.

8
00:00:19.565 --> 00:00:24.725
And specifically, we'll be taking a look
at our objectives, scope, and value.

9
00:00:24.725 --> 00:00:28.440
And we have Mrs. Jo Peacock back
in studios to bring us the show.

10
00:00:28.440 --> 00:00:29.820
How's it going today, Jo?

11
00:00:29.820 --> 00:00:30.810
>> I'm great, thank you.

12
00:00:30.810 --> 00:00:31.660
How are you, Cherokee?

13
00:00:31.660 --> 00:00:33.640
>> I'm really excited, I've had my coffee.

14
00:00:33.640 --> 00:00:36.923
And I would like to take
a look at what we're gonna

15
00:00:36.923 --> 00:00:40.056
be covering throughout
Service Design here.

16
00:00:40.056 --> 00:00:43.862
>> Okay, well we're gonna start off right
at the very beginning by looking at our

17
00:00:43.862 --> 00:00:45.430
objectives of Service Design.

18
00:00:45.430 --> 00:00:48.247
Then we're gonna go into
the scope of Service Design.

19
00:00:48.247 --> 00:00:50.590
We're gonna look at
a value to the business.

20
00:00:50.590 --> 00:00:52.568
And then a little bit later on,

21
00:00:52.568 --> 00:00:56.765
we're gonna have a sort of a part
two to this particular episode.

22
00:00:56.765 --> 00:01:00.195
And we're gonna then carry on and look
at some of the functions and roles and

23
00:01:00.195 --> 00:01:02.550
responsibilities within Service Design,
also.

24
00:01:03.610 --> 00:01:07.470
So let's start off then right at
the very beginning understanding what

25
00:01:07.470 --> 00:01:10.690
Service Design is all about and
look at that purpose.

26
00:01:10.690 --> 00:01:16.260
Its purpose is to design the services,
to design the governing practices,

27
00:01:16.260 --> 00:01:20.580
to design the processes,
and design the policies.

28
00:01:20.580 --> 00:01:24.611
All of those that are gonna realize the
strategy, that thing that we just left,

29
00:01:24.611 --> 00:01:26.525
we just left Service Strategy.

30
00:01:26.525 --> 00:01:31.565
We want to realize that strategy now and
turn it into a reality, okay?

31
00:01:31.565 --> 00:01:34.915
So, it's not just about
designing services.

32
00:01:34.915 --> 00:01:38.886
That's the most important thing to
take out from that particular purpose,

33
00:01:38.886 --> 00:01:41.345
is it's not just about designing services.

34
00:01:41.345 --> 00:01:45.223
It's actually about designing the services
and their supporting processes.

35
00:01:45.223 --> 00:01:48.083
And all of the technology
that we will use,

36
00:01:48.083 --> 00:01:53.480
how we will measure the services and
the performance of those processes.

37
00:01:53.480 --> 00:02:01.220
And also all of the people, the skills,
etc, that are needed to deliver and

38
00:02:01.220 --> 00:02:07.060
to manage these services and to deliver
the processes and work with the processes.

39
00:02:07.060 --> 00:02:09.930
So it's absolutely everything.

40
00:02:09.930 --> 00:02:14.470
One of the first things that I want
to mention is right at the very top,

41
00:02:14.470 --> 00:02:15.460
that first bullet point,

42
00:02:15.460 --> 00:02:20.090
design services that are gonna have
minimal improvement requirements.

43
00:02:21.770 --> 00:02:26.630
Design for the future,
there's a challenge, isn't it?

44
00:02:26.630 --> 00:02:29.500
Minimal improvement requirements.

45
00:02:29.500 --> 00:02:33.250
Now we know if we take a look at
continual service improvement, and

46
00:02:33.250 --> 00:02:35.750
we looked at this in Foundation material.

47
00:02:35.750 --> 00:02:40.030
So right at the very start of our ITIL
journey, we looked at ITIL Foundation.

48
00:02:40.030 --> 00:02:43.360
And we know that we had

49
00:02:44.880 --> 00:02:48.435
continual service improvement that
looked at all of our services and

50
00:02:48.435 --> 00:02:51.635
all of our processes and
all of our skills, all of our people.

51
00:02:51.635 --> 00:02:55.715
And looked for opportunities and
places where we could improve.

52
00:02:55.715 --> 00:02:59.001
And now here I am as service design
saying that we should design for

53
00:02:59.001 --> 00:03:00.735
minimal improvement.

54
00:03:00.735 --> 00:03:05.285
Well, time kinda sounds conflicted,
but it's not.

55
00:03:05.285 --> 00:03:06.625
It's not really conflicting.

56
00:03:06.625 --> 00:03:10.140
What I mean by mean by that
is that when we design,

57
00:03:10.140 --> 00:03:14.220
we should design understanding
that things are gonna change.

58
00:03:16.060 --> 00:03:18.300
Which means that we should
be designing services and

59
00:03:18.300 --> 00:03:23.310
we should be designing processes that,
not that we don't want to improve, but

60
00:03:23.310 --> 00:03:27.450
that actually can accommodate
improvements easier.

61
00:03:27.450 --> 00:03:30.300
So when we talk about minimal
improvement requirements,

62
00:03:30.300 --> 00:03:34.560
I'm not saying we wanna design it
as best as we can right now, and

63
00:03:34.560 --> 00:03:37.470
then we never ever wanna
improve it in the future.

64
00:03:37.470 --> 00:03:40.370
No, we wanna design it as
best as we can right now,

65
00:03:40.370 --> 00:03:44.440
but we want to design it in
a way that it can be improved.

66
00:03:45.540 --> 00:03:47.080
We love modular design.

67
00:03:47.080 --> 00:03:53.400
We love being able to design individual
modules to be able to add on features

68
00:03:53.400 --> 00:03:59.520
in a way that does not impact the core
functionality of any service,

69
00:03:59.520 --> 00:04:04.760
or the core functionality or
activities of any process.

70
00:04:04.760 --> 00:04:07.210
So let me think about, and
I'm gonna be specific here,

71
00:04:07.210 --> 00:04:09.010
let me think about Microsoft Outlook.

72
00:04:09.010 --> 00:04:12.520
And Microsoft Outlook is
a component of a service.

73
00:04:12.520 --> 00:04:16.831
It's the software component
of our email service.

74
00:04:16.831 --> 00:04:20.784
If we want to improve that particular
email service, given that a service is

75
00:04:20.784 --> 00:04:24.555
a means of delivering value by
facilitating the outcomes that customers

76
00:04:24.555 --> 00:04:28.465
want to achieve without the ownership
of specific cost and risks.

77
00:04:28.465 --> 00:04:34.700
Well, if that's a service and we want to
design that service to deliver value,

78
00:04:34.700 --> 00:04:38.150
but then we want design it in a way
that we can add in functionality.

79
00:04:38.150 --> 00:04:40.300
Well, we're facilitating an outcome,

80
00:04:40.300 --> 00:04:44.980
which means that we are facilitating
that ability to send and receive email.

81
00:04:44.980 --> 00:04:48.140
So how could we make an improvement
without impacting that?

82
00:04:48.140 --> 00:04:49.090
Well, quite simply,

83
00:04:49.090 --> 00:04:53.150
we can make an improvement like we can
bring in shared calendars, for instance.

84
00:04:53.150 --> 00:04:54.650
That's an improvement.

85
00:04:54.650 --> 00:04:58.590
So we can bring in other
improvements in a modular way that

86
00:04:59.680 --> 00:05:03.720
will still improve the service,
will still add value to the service.

87
00:05:03.720 --> 00:05:09.420
But does not necessarily impact the core
functionality of that particular service.

88
00:05:09.420 --> 00:05:11.449
In other words,
the outcome that it facilitates.

89
00:05:12.970 --> 00:05:15.260
Sure we can add in other
additional modules.

90
00:05:15.260 --> 00:05:18.440
We can add in other
excitement features as well.

91
00:05:18.440 --> 00:05:23.227
We can upgrade our existing and
our current features

92
00:05:23.227 --> 00:05:28.122
in a way that will improve
our customer perception and

93
00:05:28.122 --> 00:05:31.075
improve the value perception.

94
00:05:31.075 --> 00:05:36.810
What we're looking to do is we're
looking to improve with minimal work.

95
00:05:36.810 --> 00:05:41.550
Or rather, minimal impact to
our customer environment,

96
00:05:41.550 --> 00:05:44.560
minimal negative impact,
maximum positive impact.

97
00:05:44.560 --> 00:05:46.110
So not necessarily minimal work, but

98
00:05:46.110 --> 00:05:49.210
minimal work in terms of
perception to our organization.

99
00:05:49.210 --> 00:05:51.540
So this is what design is about.

100
00:05:51.540 --> 00:05:56.570
Design is about designing services
that we can easily improve on.

101
00:05:56.570 --> 00:06:00.760
It's not just about not making
improvements, it's about easily improve.

102
00:06:00.760 --> 00:06:03.230
And as it mentions there then
in that second bullet point,

103
00:06:03.230 --> 00:06:06.240
it's about embedding CSI
into all aspects of design.

104
00:06:06.240 --> 00:06:10.110
So if you read that first particular
bullet point wrong then you could actually

105
00:06:10.110 --> 00:06:13.010
agree that as being two
contradictory bullet points.

106
00:06:13.010 --> 00:06:17.290
But, the business trends that are going
to offer up those design improvements,

107
00:06:17.290 --> 00:06:20.140
that's what we would be looking out for
in the future.

108
00:06:20.140 --> 00:06:23.430
So after we've designed the service,
we wanna make sure that,

109
00:06:23.430 --> 00:06:27.600
as I've already said, we design that
service that it can be improved so

110
00:06:27.600 --> 00:06:32.180
that business relationship management in
Service Strategy can identify the trends.

111
00:06:32.180 --> 00:06:35.040
And that can help us
with those improvements.

112
00:06:36.510 --> 00:06:41.143
So Service Design is about
designing innovative services

113
00:06:41.143 --> 00:06:45.961
that meet the need of the organization
now and in the future,

114
00:06:45.961 --> 00:06:49.757
aligning with our
organization requirement.

115
00:06:49.757 --> 00:06:54.595
I want to take us back to
Service Strategy for a moment.

116
00:06:54.595 --> 00:06:59.259
And if you remember, in Service Strategy
we had three very high-level

117
00:06:59.259 --> 00:07:03.535
strategies that we looked at in
regards to our organization, and

118
00:07:03.535 --> 00:07:06.120
then applying that to our IT services.

119
00:07:06.120 --> 00:07:09.849
In Service Strategy, we looked at
the strategies of running the business,

120
00:07:09.849 --> 00:07:12.725
maintaining the status quo,
growing the business.

121
00:07:12.725 --> 00:07:17.760
In other words, a business that wants to
grow and that wants to increase profit.

122
00:07:17.760 --> 00:07:21.890
And then transforming the business,
a business that wants to transform and

123
00:07:21.890 --> 00:07:26.740
move into other marketplaces,
and other industry sectors.

124
00:07:28.290 --> 00:07:32.200
Here in IT, we have to support
that business alignment.

125
00:07:32.200 --> 00:07:33.430
We have to be aligned in the business,

126
00:07:33.430 --> 00:07:36.160
we have to support the business vision,
sorry.

127
00:07:36.160 --> 00:07:42.160
So, we have to make sure that we
are as innovative as we need to be.

128
00:07:42.160 --> 00:07:47.849
And where it mentions in that first bullet
point there, about innovative services,

129
00:07:47.849 --> 00:07:52.432
just remember that in an organization
that is running the business,

130
00:07:52.432 --> 00:07:57.410
as opposed to growing, that organization
is less likely to want Proactive

131
00:07:57.410 --> 00:08:00.830
innovation than an organization
that is growing.

132
00:08:00.830 --> 00:08:06.612
An organization that is growing needs an
IT team that is going to be innovative and

133
00:08:06.612 --> 00:08:11.910
is going to recommend ways forward and
help drive that strategy.

134
00:08:11.910 --> 00:08:15.800
So we have to align IT with
the business requirement.

135
00:08:15.800 --> 00:08:21.664
But of course, service strategy, our first
life cycle phase, the one before this,

136
00:08:21.664 --> 00:08:26.233
that will tell us what the strategy is and
what the requirement is.

137
00:08:26.233 --> 00:08:30.238
The outcome from service design,
as the life cycle phase,

138
00:08:30.238 --> 00:08:33.140
is that service design package.

139
00:08:33.140 --> 00:08:36.604
And we mentioned the service design
package in our ITIL foundation material.

140
00:08:36.604 --> 00:08:41.029
And I want to refer you back to that for
the moment, but we're gonna spend some

141
00:08:41.029 --> 00:08:44.860
time looking at that in great
detail a little bit later on.

142
00:08:44.860 --> 00:08:47.610
So I'm not gonna go into too much
detail now except to say that

143
00:08:47.610 --> 00:08:50.100
that's the outcome from service design.

144
00:08:50.100 --> 00:08:51.940
It's a designed service.

145
00:08:53.570 --> 00:08:58.070
And then we also have our
service design model.

146
00:08:58.070 --> 00:09:02.710
And our service design model is
just a model for how we will

147
00:09:02.710 --> 00:09:08.380
design that particular service, and how
we will develop that particular service.

148
00:09:08.380 --> 00:09:12.370
As it says there, design and delivery
are opposite sides of the same coin.

149
00:09:12.370 --> 00:09:15.010
So we design something
before we develop it.

150
00:09:15.010 --> 00:09:17.761
We don't develop it on the fly.

151
00:09:20.117 --> 00:09:22.600
I know a lot of developers
that will do that.

152
00:09:22.600 --> 00:09:27.321
And what we're not trying to
do is say that Agile project

153
00:09:27.321 --> 00:09:32.349
management methodologies don't work,
because they do.

154
00:09:32.349 --> 00:09:36.271
But what we're we're telling you is
that no matter what project management

155
00:09:36.271 --> 00:09:41.000
methodology you use, whether it's Agile,
whether it's PMP, whether it's Prince2.

156
00:09:42.030 --> 00:09:44.590
Irrespective of the project
management methodology,

157
00:09:44.590 --> 00:09:48.230
you still need to design
something before you build it.

158
00:09:48.230 --> 00:09:50.158
You can't just build it on the fly.

159
00:09:50.158 --> 00:09:53.678
We have to have that structure in place,

160
00:09:53.678 --> 00:09:59.260
and we have to have a format for
the actual development.

161
00:09:59.260 --> 00:10:00.860
You don't just develop on the fly.

162
00:10:00.860 --> 00:10:03.367
We don't just develop
off the top of our head,

163
00:10:03.367 --> 00:10:05.826
because there'll be no consistency at all.

164
00:10:05.826 --> 00:10:08.140
We have to have
the relevant documentation.

165
00:10:08.140 --> 00:10:12.710
And we have to know what we're designing
and what we're developing, okay?

166
00:10:12.710 --> 00:10:16.760
So the design is driven not just
by the functional requirements.

167
00:10:16.760 --> 00:10:20.270
But also by the business requirements and
any design constraints.

168
00:10:20.270 --> 00:10:24.200
So we're gonna get into them in
a little bit more detail a little

169
00:10:24.200 --> 00:10:27.220
bit later on as we get
into service design.

170
00:10:28.240 --> 00:10:30.780
There's a difference there though
between functional requirements and

171
00:10:30.780 --> 00:10:32.160
business requirements.

172
00:10:32.160 --> 00:10:33.380
And I just want to point that out.

173
00:10:33.380 --> 00:10:38.504
You see the business will tell you
what outcome they want to facilitate.

174
00:10:38.504 --> 00:10:41.875
They'll tell you what outcome they need.

175
00:10:41.875 --> 00:10:45.738
So their outcome is the ability
to send and receive email.

176
00:10:45.738 --> 00:10:48.870
That's got absolutely nothing to
do with a functional requirement

177
00:10:48.870 --> 00:10:50.790
which is what we design.

178
00:10:50.790 --> 00:10:55.410
We have to understand the outcomes and
they need facilitating, but then we

179
00:10:55.410 --> 00:10:59.810
design the functional requirements that's
going to allow them to achieve that.

180
00:10:59.810 --> 00:11:03.700
And those functional requirements,
think about sending and receiving email.

181
00:11:03.700 --> 00:11:05.939
Think about the components
that are needed.

182
00:11:05.939 --> 00:11:09.770
You don't just need Outlook,
you also need Exchange Server.

183
00:11:09.770 --> 00:11:12.380
You also need to have PCs and laptops.

184
00:11:12.380 --> 00:11:14.450
You do need to have physical servers,

185
00:11:14.450 --> 00:11:16.680
you need to have an infrastructure and
a network.

186
00:11:16.680 --> 00:11:18.760
You need to have people to support it.

187
00:11:18.760 --> 00:11:23.110
You do need to have contracts in
place with external third parties for

188
00:11:23.110 --> 00:11:25.480
your network to get outside.

189
00:11:25.480 --> 00:11:29.970
Your Internet provider,
they are functional requirements.

190
00:11:29.970 --> 00:11:35.366
Functional requirements also include
things like storage space and

191
00:11:35.366 --> 00:11:37.887
maybe archive policies, etc.

192
00:11:37.887 --> 00:11:39.770
These are your functional requirements.

193
00:11:39.770 --> 00:11:40.850
What about backups?

194
00:11:40.850 --> 00:11:44.290
Are we talking full backups or
are we talking incremental backups?

195
00:11:44.290 --> 00:11:46.490
And when do we take both?

196
00:11:46.490 --> 00:11:50.592
All of these are your functional
requirements completely different to

197
00:11:50.592 --> 00:11:55.036
the business requirements which is
why they're mentioned differently, or

198
00:11:55.036 --> 00:11:56.487
mentioned separately.

199
00:11:58.580 --> 00:11:59.420
One thing that,

200
00:11:59.420 --> 00:12:04.130
these are kind of just points that we need
to note in this particular slide here,

201
00:12:04.130 --> 00:12:09.100
that not every single change within IT
is going to require service design.

202
00:12:09.100 --> 00:12:10.790
If it's just a simple change,

203
00:12:10.790 --> 00:12:15.690
where we're bringing in maybe a new
version of a piece of hardware,

204
00:12:15.690 --> 00:12:21.220
then if it's just a new mouse, then that
doesn't need to go through service design.

205
00:12:21.220 --> 00:12:24.370
But if we have to design
a complete new build for

206
00:12:24.370 --> 00:12:28.110
a laptop, then that will need
to go through service design.

207
00:12:28.110 --> 00:12:30.040
Think about scalability.

208
00:12:30.040 --> 00:12:33.600
Scalability is a word that
I use a lot within ITIL.

209
00:12:33.600 --> 00:12:37.660
You've already heard me talk about
scalability in service strategy.

210
00:12:37.660 --> 00:12:40.710
And I'll talk about it throughout
design and transition and

211
00:12:40.710 --> 00:12:44.950
operations and
continual service improvement.

212
00:12:44.950 --> 00:12:49.270
In England, we have a saying, you don't
use a sledge hammer to crack a nut.

213
00:12:49.270 --> 00:12:54.669
And that's exactly what we want you to
apply when you're implementing ITIL,

214
00:12:54.669 --> 00:12:57.850
and when you're using any
of these ITIL processes.

215
00:12:57.850 --> 00:13:00.540
You don't want bureaucratic processes.

216
00:13:00.540 --> 00:13:04.770
You don't want processes that
are going to hinder an outcome.

217
00:13:04.770 --> 00:13:09.010
You need processes that are going
to facilitate an outcome.

218
00:13:09.010 --> 00:13:15.660
And therefore, you don't necessarily need
to use design for every single change.

219
00:13:15.660 --> 00:13:17.910
Design, we're talking about new services.

220
00:13:17.910 --> 00:13:21.770
We're talking about changes
to service level targets.

221
00:13:21.770 --> 00:13:26.320
We're talking about services that need
availability plans and capacity plans, and

222
00:13:26.320 --> 00:13:32.610
need consideration for service continuity
and consideration for security.

223
00:13:32.610 --> 00:13:36.510
When I'm bringing in a new mouse,
I don't need all of that.

224
00:13:37.970 --> 00:13:40.040
I just need to know that
it's going to work.

225
00:13:40.040 --> 00:13:42.458
So think about scalability.

226
00:13:42.458 --> 00:13:46.290
And every organization's got to decide
what needs to go through formal service

227
00:13:46.290 --> 00:13:51.070
design and what can be managed
just within change management.

228
00:13:52.260 --> 00:13:56.980
But every single change
that we have has got to be

229
00:13:56.980 --> 00:14:01.960
assessed on their impact as it
says to service design activities.

230
00:14:01.960 --> 00:14:06.860
So we need to understand just
exactly how big that change is and,

231
00:14:06.860 --> 00:14:09.051
like I said, scalability.

232
00:14:09.051 --> 00:14:13.754
If it's gonna have a huge impact
in the live environment then we

233
00:14:13.754 --> 00:14:15.808
need to go through design.

234
00:14:15.808 --> 00:14:18.256
It's all about the value
of service design then.

235
00:14:18.256 --> 00:14:22.830
Well, these are what I call
my if we get it right slides.

236
00:14:22.830 --> 00:14:27.520
If we get it right,
then this is what we will deliver.

237
00:14:27.520 --> 00:14:28.630
If we get it right,

238
00:14:28.630 --> 00:14:32.710
then we design services that are aligned
to the needs of the business.

239
00:14:32.710 --> 00:14:36.060
If we are efficient in our
project management and

240
00:14:36.060 --> 00:14:39.930
in our design,
then we reduce total cost of ownership and

241
00:14:39.930 --> 00:14:44.010
we improve the quality of our services and
the consistency.

242
00:14:44.010 --> 00:14:48.630
If we get it right we can
improve our overall governance

243
00:14:48.630 --> 00:14:52.030
because you see we can manage
services that we've designed.

244
00:14:52.030 --> 00:14:55.250
If we've never designed the service,
then how do we know what we're managing?

245
00:14:56.630 --> 00:14:59.738
If we get it right, we've got information.

246
00:14:59.738 --> 00:15:05.256
We can therefore make better decisions,
if we get it right.

247
00:15:05.256 --> 00:15:09.606
If we get it wrong,
we don't achieve any of these.

248
00:15:09.606 --> 00:15:13.710
So we have to ensure that service design
is performed in a consistent way.

249
00:15:13.710 --> 00:15:17.070
And we will tell you,
and I've already said,

250
00:15:17.070 --> 00:15:21.660
we don't care what project
management methodology you use.

251
00:15:21.660 --> 00:15:25.820
We'd just like you to use
a project management methodology.

252
00:15:25.820 --> 00:15:28.200
We have to be focused on the organization.

253
00:15:29.320 --> 00:15:32.980
We have to ensure that we're aligned
with our organization's goals and

254
00:15:32.980 --> 00:15:34.060
with our business goals.

255
00:15:34.060 --> 00:15:38.600
We've got to support them, as it says,
supporting corporate governance.

256
00:15:40.100 --> 00:15:42.910
Think about our strategy,
think about running the business,

257
00:15:42.910 --> 00:15:45.370
growing the business and
transforming the business.

258
00:15:45.370 --> 00:15:50.636
We have to support that,
whatever that strategy may be.

259
00:15:50.636 --> 00:15:54.295
So sometimes we might be creating
competitive advantage and

260
00:15:54.295 --> 00:15:55.739
other times we may not.

261
00:15:55.739 --> 00:16:01.394
We may just be Treading water,
maintaining the status quo.

262
00:16:01.394 --> 00:16:07.123
It's up to the organization, certainly
after periods of aggressive growth,

263
00:16:07.123 --> 00:16:12.423
some organizations require a year or
two to just simply run the business,

264
00:16:12.423 --> 00:16:17.381
to just embed that particular new
methodology, new way or working,

265
00:16:17.381 --> 00:16:19.110
or new services, etc.

266
00:16:20.910 --> 00:16:23.999
It's not our role to dictate
the strategy of the organization.

267
00:16:23.999 --> 00:16:27.650
It's our role to ensure that we're
aligned with their strategy.

268
00:16:27.650 --> 00:16:29.910
That we're aligned with
all of their needs,

269
00:16:29.910 --> 00:16:35.100
including when it comes to things
like all of our data security, etc.

270
00:16:35.100 --> 00:16:41.330
If we have a competitive advantage, we
wanna maintain that competitive advantage

271
00:16:41.330 --> 00:16:46.590
and that means ensuring that we can,
I don't like to use the word guarantee,

272
00:16:46.590 --> 00:16:50.660
but ensuring that we can protect
the CIA or the confidentiality,

273
00:16:50.660 --> 00:16:55.410
the integrity and the availability of all
of our assets and all of our data as well.

274
00:16:55.410 --> 00:17:00.310
>> At least, performing due diligence and
making that dedicated attempt.

275
00:17:00.310 --> 00:17:00.910
>> Yes.

276
00:17:00.910 --> 00:17:01.977
Yeah, we've gotta be.

277
00:17:01.977 --> 00:17:06.767
And even when we're in an organization
where security is not a huge factor for

278
00:17:06.767 --> 00:17:11.264
them, we still have to recognize that
every single organization has got

279
00:17:11.264 --> 00:17:15.174
proprietary information and
has got proprietary services and

280
00:17:15.174 --> 00:17:20.320
systems that they will not want getting
into the hands of their competitors.

281
00:17:20.320 --> 00:17:23.840
So even as a minimum,
we should ensure that all employees, and

282
00:17:23.840 --> 00:17:29.445
that all contract staff,
etc are able to sign

283
00:17:29.445 --> 00:17:34.495
non-disclosure agreements etc, to ensure
that we do protect that confidentiality,

284
00:17:34.495 --> 00:17:37.236
the integrity, and
the availability of our services.

285
00:17:37.236 --> 00:17:43.610
And I say organization, I quite often
see organizations where contract staff

286
00:17:43.610 --> 00:17:49.120
within IT are treated completely
differently to permanent staff.

287
00:17:49.120 --> 00:17:52.630
And then I see organizations
where contract staff and

288
00:17:52.630 --> 00:17:55.800
permanent staff nobody would ever
know the difference between them.

289
00:17:58.060 --> 00:18:03.530
We have to just question what the
efficiencies are that you are looking for

290
00:18:03.530 --> 00:18:07.940
in bringing in contract stuff,
as opposed to permanent staff.

291
00:18:07.940 --> 00:18:10.011
And understand what their roles and
responsibilities are.

292
00:18:10.011 --> 00:18:15.041
And it's only then that you can
make the decision as to what levels

293
00:18:15.041 --> 00:18:20.173
of security etc that you afford
certain people and certain staff.

294
00:18:20.173 --> 00:18:23.693
Ultimately you've gotta be aligned
with the business need and so

295
00:18:23.693 --> 00:18:27.981
you've got to make decisions that will
align you with what the business wants.

296
00:18:27.981 --> 00:18:32.226
Our services and all of the people
that bought our services and

297
00:18:32.226 --> 00:18:36.877
all of the processes that support
those services have got to achieve

298
00:18:36.877 --> 00:18:39.870
absolutely every single one of these.

299
00:18:39.870 --> 00:18:41.970
We've got to satisfy
the business objectives.

300
00:18:41.970 --> 00:18:46.270
We've got to be,
I hate using the term future proof, but

301
00:18:46.270 --> 00:18:48.330
we've got to design for the future.

302
00:18:48.330 --> 00:18:53.540
And this is where we get into the cliches
and I absolutely hate using cliches, but

303
00:18:53.540 --> 00:18:56.250
we don't know anything about the future
other than it's going to change.

304
00:18:57.320 --> 00:19:00.190
And so in that respect then
if we're designing for

305
00:19:00.190 --> 00:19:04.310
the future we're designing for
change, that's what we're doing.

306
00:19:04.310 --> 00:19:07.780
So we have to ensure that we
design services that it says

307
00:19:07.780 --> 00:19:10.395
can be easily developed and
easily at hand.

308
00:19:10.395 --> 00:19:11.029
>> Right.

309
00:19:11.029 --> 00:19:13.500
>> Because we design for change.

310
00:19:13.500 --> 00:19:16.640
>> Like looking at things like
any kind of data transmission.

311
00:19:18.050 --> 00:19:20.630
What methodologies or
methods in order to do that?

312
00:19:20.630 --> 00:19:24.140
Well we know has their recommendations for
cabling standards,

313
00:19:24.140 --> 00:19:26.940
so at that point in time
that's what's available.

314
00:19:26.940 --> 00:19:28.730
We're going to make our judgement calls,
and

315
00:19:28.730 --> 00:19:31.160
say look this is the best
option that we have currently.

316
00:19:31.160 --> 00:19:31.840
But who knows?

317
00:19:31.840 --> 00:19:36.495
Like what if light bulbs are gonna be
transmitting Wi-fi or Li-fi in the future.

318
00:19:36.495 --> 00:19:39.800
>> [LAUGH]
>> We just have to make that call.

319
00:19:39.800 --> 00:19:40.780
>> Right, exactly.

320
00:19:40.780 --> 00:19:43.910
We've got to be aware of the future.

321
00:19:43.910 --> 00:19:47.092
But, let's face it, we don't
really know what the future holds.

322
00:19:47.092 --> 00:19:50.800
I mean, many, many, well,
not that many years ago,

323
00:19:50.800 --> 00:19:54.280
I would have considered in my own
personal life, not all that long ago,

324
00:19:54.280 --> 00:20:00.070
I would consider why when every single
room in the house are with a network port.

325
00:20:00.070 --> 00:20:01.410
Now would I do that?

326
00:20:01.410 --> 00:20:03.330
Absolutely not because we've got wi-fi.

327
00:20:03.330 --> 00:20:07.300
And in fact, now we've got to the point
where I have two routers installed in my

328
00:20:07.300 --> 00:20:13.320
home because I wanna make sure that
you know one's a secure router for me.

329
00:20:13.320 --> 00:20:16.990
>> I thought you were gonna say two
incoming lines for bandwidth saturation.

330
00:20:16.990 --> 00:20:18.855
That's a problem at my house.

331
00:20:18.855 --> 00:20:21.190
>> [LAUGH] No, I'm quite lucky.

332
00:20:21.190 --> 00:20:23.350
There's only two,
maybe three of us in our house.

333
00:20:23.350 --> 00:20:26.915
We don't have that much of
an issue at the moment.

334
00:20:26.915 --> 00:20:29.765
[LAUGH] Other than the fact
that I have priority

335
00:20:29.765 --> 00:20:30.681
over-
>> Of course.

336
00:20:30.681 --> 00:20:31.460
>> -absolutely everything.

337
00:20:31.460 --> 00:20:37.510
So [LAUGH] so yes,
we don't need too much of that right now.

338
00:20:37.510 --> 00:20:40.510
But what we do know is
that our service provider

339
00:20:41.910 --> 00:20:45.400
will implement certain
things like hotspots, etc.

340
00:20:45.400 --> 00:20:49.737
And so I will keep a router just for
a hotspot for other people to use, and

341
00:20:49.737 --> 00:20:52.933
I keep a router that is
perfectly secure just for me.

342
00:20:52.933 --> 00:20:56.527
Because as somebody who,
we all work from home now,

343
00:20:56.527 --> 00:21:01.110
I want to ensure that the integrity
of my transactions is assured.

344
00:21:02.390 --> 00:21:06.096
And so we all know what we
need from our services.

345
00:21:06.096 --> 00:21:10.180
And even on a personal level,
we design services that fit our need.

346
00:21:10.180 --> 00:21:11.680
But now we think about the future.

347
00:21:11.680 --> 00:21:15.010
And we think about what could
be happening in the future.

348
00:21:15.010 --> 00:21:18.860
And so we would never go out and
buy a router that just meets, or

349
00:21:18.860 --> 00:21:22.420
router as you might call it,
that just meets our needs right now.

350
00:21:22.420 --> 00:21:28.280
We will now think about the future devices
that we're going to bring into our home.

351
00:21:28.280 --> 00:21:31.225
I once did a calculation and my home is so

352
00:21:31.225 --> 00:21:37.046
wi-fi enabled that I have over 30
devices that connect through my router.

353
00:21:39.242 --> 00:21:42.350
And you think about this and
think how is that physically possible?

354
00:21:42.350 --> 00:21:44.441
And then you think about all of
the devices that you have and

355
00:21:44.441 --> 00:21:45.772
all of the technology that you have.

356
00:21:45.772 --> 00:21:46.620
>> Yeah the IoT.

357
00:21:46.620 --> 00:21:47.700
Yeah.

358
00:21:47.700 --> 00:21:50.220
>> My front door lock
connects through my router.

359
00:21:50.220 --> 00:21:53.065
[LAUGH]
>> Are your dogs connected to

360
00:21:53.065 --> 00:21:54.255
the internet?

361
00:21:54.255 --> 00:21:56.455
>> Not quite.
>> Not yet, they may be in the future.

362
00:21:56.455 --> 00:21:57.735
>> Yeah, they will be very, very soon.

363
00:21:57.735 --> 00:22:01.120
>> [LAUGH]
>> But we think about this and

364
00:22:01.120 --> 00:22:06.625
we have to design our services to
be future proof as much as we can.

365
00:22:06.625 --> 00:22:12.285
And while we still got organizations
in the world that do not use wi-fi.

366
00:22:12.285 --> 00:22:17.000
A lot of government organizations we don't
use wireless at all, because quite simply,

367
00:22:17.000 --> 00:22:18.740
it's just not safe to do so.

368
00:22:18.740 --> 00:22:22.070
So we're still using cables, but

369
00:22:22.070 --> 00:22:25.030
we still have to think about
the future and what that means.

370
00:22:25.030 --> 00:22:29.504
You wouldn't believe how many desktops
are now produced without network cards

371
00:22:29.504 --> 00:22:30.045
in them.

372
00:22:32.084 --> 00:22:35.409
And yet who would think it, so of course,

373
00:22:35.409 --> 00:22:41.492
these particular hardware providers
have to still create network cards for

374
00:22:41.492 --> 00:22:47.780
certain organizations, because these
organizations do not have wireless.

375
00:22:49.490 --> 00:22:54.230
And yet we've all thought that we've moved
on from that, because things change.

376
00:22:54.230 --> 00:22:57.940
And so we have to design,
as we've said, for the future.

377
00:22:57.940 --> 00:23:00.640
One thing that I want to mention there,
it's about halfway down,

378
00:23:00.640 --> 00:23:03.320
it talks about appropriate measures and
metrics.

379
00:23:04.480 --> 00:23:08.474
We have to design our services so
that they can be measured.

380
00:23:08.474 --> 00:23:14.952
And we have to be able to demonstrate that
our services are providing value, and

381
00:23:14.952 --> 00:23:19.982
that our processes are actually
underpinning our services,

382
00:23:19.982 --> 00:23:26.572
and that our processes are facilitating
the value provision of those services.

383
00:23:27.994 --> 00:23:31.700
We have to be able to demonstrate
the we're doing well.

384
00:23:31.700 --> 00:23:33.420
It's simple as that.

385
00:23:33.420 --> 00:23:36.730
Now when it comes to measurements we can
also demonstrate that we're not doing so

386
00:23:36.730 --> 00:23:37.800
well as well.

387
00:23:37.800 --> 00:23:40.140
You know, we demonstrate
that we're doing poorly too.

388
00:23:41.210 --> 00:23:44.780
But we design our measurements and
our metrics too.

389
00:23:44.780 --> 00:23:50.340
So we design what we're going to
measure and how we're going to measure,

390
00:23:50.340 --> 00:23:54.520
which means sometimes we have to design
the tools that underpin those services,

391
00:23:54.520 --> 00:23:57.340
cuz those tools will help us measure and
help us support.

392
00:23:58.530 --> 00:24:01.990
What we really want to do ultimately,
is as it says at the bottom there,

393
00:24:01.990 --> 00:24:05.460
contribute to the overall
quality of those services.

394
00:24:07.640 --> 00:24:11.310
Now I'm gonna leave it there for
this particular session.

395
00:24:11.310 --> 00:24:14.780
This is our foray into the meat and

396
00:24:14.780 --> 00:24:19.940
bones of service design,
after we completed our foundation recap.

397
00:24:19.940 --> 00:24:23.140
And so for this particular session,
I'm going to leave it there.

398
00:24:23.140 --> 00:24:27.610
And when we come back in part two,
we're going to be looking at functions.

399
00:24:27.610 --> 00:24:30.330
And for those of you that
aren't aware of functions,

400
00:24:30.330 --> 00:24:35.340
then I would like you to go back
to your foundation recaps that you

401
00:24:35.340 --> 00:24:40.380
did in the last episode and just
refresh your memory again on functions.

402
00:24:40.380 --> 00:24:42.990
And we're going to be looking
at those functional areas

403
00:24:42.990 --> 00:24:46.300
in a little bit more depth
in our following episode.

404
00:24:46.300 --> 00:24:48.360
>> All right, so ladies and
gentlemen you heard it.

405
00:24:48.360 --> 00:24:51.609
Jo said meat and bones,
I might say meat and potatoes.

406
00:24:51.609 --> 00:24:52.523
>> [LAUGH]
>> But

407
00:24:52.523 --> 00:24:54.486
either way you look at it we've got
some great information headed your way.

408
00:24:54.486 --> 00:24:57.270
But for this show we'll go ahead and
sign out.

409
00:24:57.270 --> 00:24:58.943
Remember I've been your
host Cherokee Boose.

410
00:24:58.943 --> 00:25:00.150
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

411
00:25:00.150 --> 00:25:02.631
>> See you next time here at ITProTV.

412
00:25:02.631 --> 00:25:08.389
[MUSIC]

413
00:25:08.389 --> 00:25:11.591

process owner as well as a process
manager as well as process practitioners.

235
00:14:08.140 --> 00:14:13.220
You might have a service management office
and a program management office as well.

236
00:14:13.220 --> 00:14:17.140
So you might have program management to
manage projects and you might have service

237
00:14:17.140 --> 00:14:23.220
management to manage all the operational
side of our IT services.

238
00:14:23.220 --> 00:14:25.463
You might, there is no right or

239
00:14:25.463 --> 00:14:29.700
wrong you will decide in your
organizational structure.

240
00:14:29.700 --> 00:14:35.750
Now what I can tell you is that if
you go back to your service strategy

241
00:14:35.750 --> 00:14:40.957
class then you will see in
the service strategy episode.

242
00:14:40.957 --> 00:14:45.424
We had a couple of episodes in there
that looked at organization and

243
00:14:45.424 --> 00:14:50.470
how you would define organization for
your particular service provider.

244
00:14:51.530 --> 00:14:52.672
That's just a guide line.

245
00:14:52.672 --> 00:14:56.232
It's just there to help
you there is no right or

246
00:14:56.232 --> 00:15:01.870
wrong as we say we organize for
what is best for your business itself.

247
00:15:01.870 --> 00:15:03.365
Not because we want to.

248
00:15:03.365 --> 00:15:07.482
And let's think about what this large
implementation might look like what

249
00:15:07.482 --> 00:15:09.835
the large organization might look like and

250
00:15:09.835 --> 00:15:13.400
here we have exactly as we've
just seen in that last slide.

251
00:15:13.400 --> 00:15:16.502
We've got a service management
office,we've got a project or

252
00:15:16.502 --> 00:15:19.502
program management office,we've
got all the teams there.

253
00:15:19.502 --> 00:15:23.352
And then we might have
individual support teams and

254
00:15:23.352 --> 00:15:28.368
individual project teams within
each particular geographic area

255
00:15:28.368 --> 00:15:33.820
in this particular example and
again, we use the words example.

256
00:15:33.820 --> 00:15:36.320
Nothing more than that.

257
00:15:36.320 --> 00:15:37.990
So I wanna leave that thought with you and

258
00:15:37.990 --> 00:15:43.190
I want you to download the material that's
come along with this particular episode.

259
00:15:43.190 --> 00:15:46.100
So now we've taken a look at our
organizational structures and

260
00:15:46.100 --> 00:15:49.820
we've looked at our and
responsibilities and our functional areas.

261
00:15:49.820 --> 00:15:53.618
And we're going to take a break for
this particular episode and

262
00:15:53.618 --> 00:15:58.348
when we come back in our following episode
we're going to look at our inputs and

263
00:15:58.348 --> 00:16:00.084
outputs to service design.

264
00:16:00.084 --> 00:16:03.644
And we are actually going to be looking
at what we do within service design and

265
00:16:03.644 --> 00:16:06.120
the documentation that we produce.

266
00:16:06.120 --> 00:16:10.573
So for now, what I'd like you to do is I'd
like you to take a look at the available

267
00:16:10.573 --> 00:16:12.451
material that you can download.

268
00:16:12.451 --> 00:16:16.070
And just recap over our
organizational structures.

269
00:16:16.070 --> 00:16:20.840
And if you have any questions then feel
free to contact me via the forum and

270
00:16:20.840 --> 00:16:22.760
I will answer any queries
that you may have.

271
00:16:24.320 --> 00:16:26.600
>> Except for
any kind of elephant recipes,

272
00:16:26.600 --> 00:16:29.475
we are advising against that ladies and
gentlemen.

273
00:16:29.475 --> 00:16:32.880
But no, Jo, seriously thank you for
your input and your information.

274
00:16:32.880 --> 00:16:35.660
We appreciate it, as always,
and you being here.

275
00:16:35.660 --> 00:16:37.360
But for this show, we are out of time.

276
00:16:37.360 --> 00:16:39.080
So we'll go ahead and sign out.

277
00:16:39.080 --> 00:16:41.046
I've been your host Cherokee Boose.

278
00:16:41.046 --> 00:16:44.459
>> And I'm Jo Peacock and looking forward
to my elephant dinner this evening.

279
00:16:44.459 --> 00:16:46.594
>> [LAUGH] Have a great day.

280
00:16:46.594 --> 00:16:48.495
See you next time, bye.

281
00:16:48.495 --> 00:16:54.308
[MUSIC]

282
00:16:54.308 --> 00:16:57.382
>> Thank you for watching ITPro.TV.

episodes.description: In this show, Jo and Cherokee spend time explaining the inputs and out puts of service design. Although, there are several inputs and outputs used through the lifecycles there is one particular output that simply can not be forgot about. The Service Design Package is the main deliverable from the service design stage. Tune to learn what it is and more!
episodes.title: Inputs and Outputs

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo look at Service Design Principles.  Jo describes and emphasizes the need for every part of the server solution fall under service design.  The design principles help us to not stray to far from the goals of ITIL, making us remember that we must keep people, partners, produces and processes in mind, says Jo.  She also describes the activities and the constraints that must be considered.
episodes.title: Service Design Principles
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.270 --> 00:00:03.831
Welcome to ITPro.TV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:03.831 --> 00:00:06.771
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.771 --> 00:00:08.299
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.299 --> 00:00:11.582
>> You're watching ITPro.TV.

5
00:00:11.582 --> 00:00:14.928
>> Welcome to another great episode,
right here on ITPro.TV.

6
00:00:14.928 --> 00:00:18.175
You're watching
the ITIL Intermediate Service Design show.

7
00:00:18.175 --> 00:00:20.900
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong.

8
00:00:20.900 --> 00:00:24.550
And today, we're taking a look
at service design principles.

9
00:00:24.550 --> 00:00:29.440
And here to help us again is gonna be
well, our ITIL master herself, Jo Peacock.

10
00:00:29.440 --> 00:00:30.810
Jo, welcome back to the show.

11
00:00:30.810 --> 00:00:32.300
>> Thanks very much for having me, Ronnie.

12
00:00:32.300 --> 00:00:33.371
How are you?

13
00:00:33.371 --> 00:00:34.178
>> I am doing fine, Jo.

14
00:00:34.178 --> 00:00:38.220
Now, we wanna get into this
idea of design principles.

15
00:00:38.220 --> 00:00:40.010
And since I always misspell the word,

16
00:00:40.010 --> 00:00:42.020
principles, you actually
have to help me out here.

17
00:00:42.020 --> 00:00:45.580
We're not really talking about the person
that's actually in charge of everything,

18
00:00:45.580 --> 00:00:47.440
but we're talking about
something else now, right?

19
00:00:47.440 --> 00:00:51.100
>> That's right, we're talking about
actually designing a new service.

20
00:00:51.100 --> 00:00:53.572
We're not talking about
a headmaster in school.

21
00:00:53.572 --> 00:00:55.818
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] But it's okay,

22
00:00:55.818 --> 00:00:58.720
if it's any consolation I
can never spell either.

23
00:00:58.720 --> 00:01:02.730
But that's just because of my lack of
education, nothing more than that,

24
00:01:02.730 --> 00:01:04.780
definitely not confusion.

25
00:01:04.780 --> 00:01:09.050
>> All right, so Jo when we start to
take a look at the idea of these design

26
00:01:09.050 --> 00:01:12.390
principles itself, where is the best
place for us to get started so

27
00:01:12.390 --> 00:01:15.070
that we know that we're actually
progressing in the right place?

28
00:01:15.070 --> 00:01:17.888
>> Well, I first of all want to
mention one simple word, and

29
00:01:17.888 --> 00:01:22.063
it's something that I want everybody to
remember when we're designing a service,

30
00:01:22.063 --> 00:01:23.624
and that is the word holistic.

31
00:01:23.624 --> 00:01:25.692
That's spell H-O-L.

32
00:01:25.692 --> 00:01:28.494
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] I know that the accents

33
00:01:28.494 --> 00:01:32.514
a little bit strange sometimes and
I have had somebody say to me,

34
00:01:32.514 --> 00:01:34.090
do you really mean that?

35
00:01:34.090 --> 00:01:37.145
No, I mean holistic,
I mean all encompassing.

36
00:01:38.530 --> 00:01:42.060
We look at the first slide here and
we talk about our 4 P's and

37
00:01:42.060 --> 00:01:44.540
our 4 P's being people,
process, products, and

38
00:01:44.540 --> 00:01:48.650
partners but actually I just want
to take that a little bit further.

39
00:01:48.650 --> 00:01:54.350
Let's think about the components of
a service or our configuration items

40
00:01:54.350 --> 00:01:59.160
as we call them when we look further at
service design, what makes up a service?

41
00:01:59.160 --> 00:02:00.730
A service, of course,

42
00:02:00.730 --> 00:02:04.060
is a means of delivering value by
facilitating the outcomes that

43
00:02:04.060 --> 00:02:08.110
customers want to achieve without
the ownership of specific costs and risks.

44
00:02:08.110 --> 00:02:12.380
So let's think of my service as
the ability to send and receive email.

45
00:02:12.380 --> 00:02:16.079
Well, what do I need to do in order
to be able to send and receive email?

46
00:02:16.079 --> 00:02:19.340
Or rather, what do I need to have?

47
00:02:19.340 --> 00:02:20.430
I need to have software.

48
00:02:20.430 --> 00:02:21.720
And I need to have hardware.

49
00:02:21.720 --> 00:02:25.970
And I need to have somewhere to
sit while I'm sending that email.

50
00:02:25.970 --> 00:02:28.610
I need to have somebody to support it for
me.

51
00:02:28.610 --> 00:02:30.160
I need to have a network.

52
00:02:30.160 --> 00:02:33.700
And I need to have contracts and
targets in place in order for

53
00:02:33.700 --> 00:02:35.009
me to be able do that.

54
00:02:36.500 --> 00:02:39.530
In other words,
I've got to design all of those.

55
00:02:39.530 --> 00:02:44.970
So I talk about our 4 P's as being
our four considerations, but

56
00:02:44.970 --> 00:02:47.410
we have to design absolutely everything.

57
00:02:48.790 --> 00:02:54.970
And in ITIL terms, the word holistic means
both technical and non-technical aspects.

58
00:02:54.970 --> 00:02:57.770
We sometimes get bogged down
in the technical aspects.

59
00:02:57.770 --> 00:02:59.400
And we're thinking about bandwidth, and

60
00:02:59.400 --> 00:03:02.265
we're thinking about
storage of these emails.

61
00:03:02.265 --> 00:03:06.875
We're thinking about things like,
archival sort of procedures,

62
00:03:06.875 --> 00:03:09.995
etc., and data retention policies.

63
00:03:09.995 --> 00:03:15.595
We're thinking about speed and the server
and yet what we actually need to be

64
00:03:15.595 --> 00:03:20.705
thinking about also, are things like the
fact that I cannot stand outside the front

65
00:03:20.705 --> 00:03:26.080
of the building without any power and
send and receive email for very long.

66
00:03:26.080 --> 00:03:27.900
I need to have somewhere to sit.

67
00:03:27.900 --> 00:03:32.140
I need to have electricity in order
to be able to send and receive email.

68
00:03:32.140 --> 00:03:36.600
I need to have a contract in place
with an Internet service provider

69
00:03:36.600 --> 00:03:39.420
in order to be able to send and
receive email.

70
00:03:39.420 --> 00:03:42.600
And I need to have somebody available
at the other end of the phone or

71
00:03:42.600 --> 00:03:48.090
the other end of a message if I've
got something wrong with my email,

72
00:03:48.090 --> 00:03:52.260
if something doesn't work when I
try to send and receive email.

73
00:03:52.260 --> 00:03:56.010
So, this is not just about having
a laptop, having a PC, and

74
00:03:56.010 --> 00:03:57.840
having some software on it.

75
00:03:57.840 --> 00:04:00.810
All of these other elements have
to come in to play as well.

76
00:04:00.810 --> 00:04:03.410
And a lot of these are not
technical element.

77
00:04:03.410 --> 00:04:04.641
But we still need to design them all.

78
00:04:04.641 --> 00:04:08.387
We still need to take all of these into
consideration when we're designing

79
00:04:08.387 --> 00:04:08.986
a service.

80
00:04:08.986 --> 00:04:12.576
When we're designing any
aspect of any service, and

81
00:04:12.576 --> 00:04:16.403
we'll look at the aspects of
the service in a moment, but

82
00:04:16.403 --> 00:04:21.459
when we design any aspect we need to
consider whose using that technology.

83
00:04:21.459 --> 00:04:24.386
Whose going to be
supporting that technology?

84
00:04:24.386 --> 00:04:26.437
Who are our partners?

85
00:04:26.437 --> 00:04:28.390
Who are our suppliers?

86
00:04:28.390 --> 00:04:30.554
Are they going to work with us?

87
00:04:30.554 --> 00:04:33.170
Are they a true supplier, or
are they more of a partner?

88
00:04:33.170 --> 00:04:36.200
Are they working with us,
or are they working for us?

89
00:04:36.200 --> 00:04:38.250
And how do we manage them?

90
00:04:38.250 --> 00:04:41.170
And what about the actual
technical products that we use?

91
00:04:42.230 --> 00:04:45.000
How compatible are they with each other?

92
00:04:45.000 --> 00:04:47.160
And when we're bringing in a new service,

93
00:04:47.160 --> 00:04:50.230
it's got to fit on our
current infrastructure.

94
00:04:50.230 --> 00:04:53.340
So we have to think about
all of that compatibility.

95
00:04:53.340 --> 00:04:55.260
And also think about our processes too.

96
00:04:55.260 --> 00:05:00.710
When we bring in a new service, we don't
design new processes from scratch.

97
00:05:00.710 --> 00:05:02.944
We've already got a change
management process, or

98
00:05:02.944 --> 00:05:05.500
we've already got an incident
management process.

99
00:05:05.500 --> 00:05:09.560
It may be just simply that we just have
to update our call logging system and

100
00:05:09.560 --> 00:05:13.860
add in that new service as a new
service in the call logging system

101
00:05:13.860 --> 00:05:15.300
in that drop down field.

102
00:05:16.320 --> 00:05:18.140
I can't tell you what you need, but

103
00:05:18.140 --> 00:05:20.330
I can tell you that this is
what you need to consider.

104
00:05:21.340 --> 00:05:23.510
So what is it that we actually design?

105
00:05:23.510 --> 00:05:25.080
Well, we design the service itself.

106
00:05:25.080 --> 00:05:28.960
That's the software, and the hardware,
and the environment, and the people, and

107
00:05:28.960 --> 00:05:31.350
the infrastructure, and the documentation.

108
00:05:31.350 --> 00:05:35.430
But then we also design our tools.

109
00:05:35.430 --> 00:05:39.168
What we're going to use to
support that new service.

110
00:05:39.168 --> 00:05:43.010
So our event management tools, the tools
that we're going to use to monitor

111
00:05:43.010 --> 00:05:46.740
things like backup, to monitor jobs that
are running, and monitor when people have

112
00:05:46.740 --> 00:05:52.120
logged in and when people have logged out,
and what licenses are being utilized, etc.

113
00:05:52.120 --> 00:05:55.930
You have to design also our
incident management tools,

114
00:05:55.930 --> 00:06:00.100
and our change management tools, and
our configuration management tools.

115
00:06:01.220 --> 00:06:05.080
As well as we design both the technology
architecture, that's our infrastructure,

116
00:06:05.080 --> 00:06:06.930
that's our network topology.

117
00:06:06.930 --> 00:06:10.508
But we also have to design how
we're organized ourselves.

118
00:06:11.670 --> 00:06:15.670
When I'm bringing a new service,
somebody's gotta support it.

119
00:06:15.670 --> 00:06:19.700
And that person or people, well,
they might be part of a team and

120
00:06:19.700 --> 00:06:22.340
they've got to work for somebody.

121
00:06:22.340 --> 00:06:25.290
And that person,
do they fit in application management or

122
00:06:25.290 --> 00:06:28.800
do they fit in technical management or
are they in a bit of both?

123
00:06:28.800 --> 00:06:31.120
And who do they work for?

124
00:06:31.120 --> 00:06:33.865
So think about an organization chart too.

125
00:06:33.865 --> 00:06:38.070
And then, as I've already mentioned,
we've got to design processes.

126
00:06:38.070 --> 00:06:40.850
And we never start off with a blank
piece of paper, not anymore.

127
00:06:40.850 --> 00:06:43.890
Maybe back in the 1980s we did,
but certainly not now.

128
00:06:45.080 --> 00:06:48.230
And then think about how we're
going to measure that new service.

129
00:06:49.520 --> 00:06:51.120
The end to end service metrics.

130
00:06:52.560 --> 00:06:56.730
The end to end service metrics include the
technology and they include the processes.

131
00:06:58.230 --> 00:07:02.570
If I want to know how my
service availability is doing,

132
00:07:02.570 --> 00:07:07.190
in other words, how long is my
service up for, how resilient is it?

133
00:07:07.190 --> 00:07:08.820
Or rather, how reliable is it?

134
00:07:08.820 --> 00:07:10.815
How often does it break down?

135
00:07:10.815 --> 00:07:15.033
Then I need to measure not only
the frequency of the incidents,

136
00:07:15.033 --> 00:07:17.422
the frequency of the failures, but

137
00:07:17.422 --> 00:07:22.210
I also need to measure how long it
takes me to restore an incident.

138
00:07:22.210 --> 00:07:27.640
So that's that technology metric and the
process metric on restoring that incident.

139
00:07:28.660 --> 00:07:31.210
So I need to measure
my end to end service.

140
00:07:31.210 --> 00:07:37.270
And that includes my technology metrics,
and it includes my process metrics too.

141
00:07:39.190 --> 00:07:40.910
So what about our plans, then?

142
00:07:40.910 --> 00:07:42.450
What do we need to include?

143
00:07:42.450 --> 00:07:44.828
Now, I've already mentioned
in a previous section,

144
00:07:44.828 --> 00:07:46.648
we looked at our service design package.

145
00:07:46.648 --> 00:07:48.591
And in our last episode, in fact,

146
00:07:48.591 --> 00:07:51.680
we looked more in depth at
the service design package.

147
00:07:51.680 --> 00:07:53.179
Take a look at all of these.

148
00:07:53.179 --> 00:07:57.127
All of these need to be in
our service design package.

149
00:07:57.127 --> 00:08:00.791
And when it talks about at the bottom
about the production of the service design

150
00:08:00.791 --> 00:08:03.580
package, I expect it to
include all of these.

151
00:08:03.580 --> 00:08:07.792
And in our previous episode we also
looked at the service acceptance criteria

152
00:08:07.792 --> 00:08:08.321
as well.

153
00:08:08.321 --> 00:08:13.233
So if you need more information about
those, then please feel free to go back

154
00:08:13.233 --> 00:08:18.550
to that previous episode and Investigate
these in a little bit more depth.

155
00:08:18.550 --> 00:08:22.226
But all of these I expect to see
in our service design package.

156
00:08:22.226 --> 00:08:26.995
So I need to ensure that we've
accommodated all of these.

157
00:08:26.995 --> 00:08:31.077
Including not just the technical
impact of that service, but

158
00:08:31.077 --> 00:08:34.937
including the impact to our
business of this new service.

159
00:08:34.937 --> 00:08:37.848
When we take a look at in
service transition, and

160
00:08:37.848 --> 00:08:42.676
I will want you to take a look at service
transition to look at change management,

161
00:08:42.676 --> 00:08:45.024
for how we implement this new service.

162
00:08:45.024 --> 00:08:50.144
But you will see that one of the things
that I talk about in service transition

163
00:08:50.144 --> 00:08:55.024
is ensuring that we have maximum
positive impact on an organization when

164
00:08:55.024 --> 00:08:58.713
we implement anything with
minimal negative impact.

165
00:08:58.713 --> 00:09:03.153
We also look at the emotional cycle
of change, and we look at things like

166
00:09:03.153 --> 00:09:07.679
Gartner's hype cycle as well about
that inflated peak of expectation.

167
00:09:07.679 --> 00:09:11.293
Here in design, this is where we design.

168
00:09:11.293 --> 00:09:12.874
And in transition,

169
00:09:12.874 --> 00:09:18.550
we've got our developers who will
simply build what has been designed.

170
00:09:19.680 --> 00:09:23.620
We have to expect that
there will always be

171
00:09:23.620 --> 00:09:27.610
a negative impact when we
implement any service.

172
00:09:28.680 --> 00:09:31.800
And it doesn't matter
what that service is.

173
00:09:32.920 --> 00:09:38.710
So we have got to design to reduce that
negative impact as much as possible.

174
00:09:38.710 --> 00:09:42.163
Let me put this into a real
life perspective for you.

175
00:09:42.163 --> 00:09:46.300
I was desperate a few years ago now.

176
00:09:46.300 --> 00:09:49.340
I was desperate for certain piece
of wearable technology, really,

177
00:09:49.340 --> 00:09:53.660
really desperate for it, to the point
where had I not ordered it online, I would

178
00:09:53.660 --> 00:09:59.104
have been somebody who was lining outside
