00:25:01.980 --> 00:25:06.860
Because that means that they can still
operate in a consistent way, and

409
00:25:06.860 --> 00:25:09.963
therefore, they can operate efficiently.

410
00:25:09.963 --> 00:25:18.262
So I think of perhaps one of the large
drug companies that we have globally.

411
00:25:18.262 --> 00:25:21.900
And the most stringent requirements for

412
00:25:21.900 --> 00:25:26.074
the testing of drugs
happens to lie in Canada.

413
00:25:26.074 --> 00:25:29.987
And so
what this particular organization does is,

414
00:25:29.987 --> 00:25:35.818
they use the Canadian requirements and
the Canadian legislative minimum.

415
00:25:35.818 --> 00:25:40.578
And that is applied throughout the entire
organization, right the way across

416
00:25:40.578 --> 00:25:45.351
Europe and right the way across North
America, and right the way across Asia.

417
00:25:45.351 --> 00:25:49.590
Because then that means that if they
can comply with Canadian requirements,

418
00:25:49.590 --> 00:25:51.950
they can comply with everything else.

419
00:25:51.950 --> 00:25:54.310
But they're still working consistently and

420
00:25:54.310 --> 00:25:58.710
to a standard and that's something
that we do within IT as well.

421
00:25:58.710 --> 00:26:02.553
For instance, those organizations
that operate in North America and

422
00:26:02.553 --> 00:26:04.647
also operate elsewhere in the world.

423
00:26:04.647 --> 00:26:10.611
And the most stringent recycling
requirements which happen to be in Europe,

424
00:26:10.611 --> 00:26:16.222
then they apply those globally,
across the whole of the organization.

425
00:26:16.222 --> 00:26:20.847
So for this particular episode then,
what we've looked at is we've looked more

426
00:26:20.847 --> 00:26:25.622
closely at our design constraints, and
we've looked at what we actually design.

427
00:26:25.622 --> 00:26:30.477
And what I'd like you to do right now is
just take a moment to go back through your

428
00:26:30.477 --> 00:26:31.345
notes.

429
00:26:31.345 --> 00:26:34.325
There will be an exercise in
your downloadable material

430
00:26:34.325 --> 00:26:36.315
once we have finished this section.

431
00:26:36.315 --> 00:26:39.585
So I'd like you to take sort
of the next 15, 20 minutes and

432
00:26:39.585 --> 00:26:44.525
just read through the notes that we've
already covered before we come back again.

433
00:26:44.525 --> 00:26:48.912
And then we start looking further
into the design principles.

434
00:26:48.912 --> 00:26:49.691
>> All right, Jo,

435
00:26:49.691 --> 00:26:53.257
well thank you again for helping us to
understand a bit more about this idea,

436
00:26:53.257 --> 00:26:57.270
the design principle that we really
need to start with designing everything.

437
00:26:57.270 --> 00:27:00.939
Taking into consideration all those
elements is really key along with

438
00:27:00.939 --> 00:27:02.624
the existing infrastructure.

439
00:27:02.624 --> 00:27:06.007
So that we can come up with a proper
solution that we need to that's actually

440
00:27:06.007 --> 00:27:07.094
gonna fit us end to end.

441
00:27:07.094 --> 00:27:11.337
And that's an important part, of course,
of anything that we're actually gonna

442
00:27:11.337 --> 00:27:15.400
be doing in IT, and service design is
a great place for us to begin here.

443
00:27:15.400 --> 00:27:18.899
But there's more to come in terms of,
well, service design but that's for

444
00:27:18.899 --> 00:27:20.003
another episode then.

445
00:27:20.003 --> 00:27:24.023
Signing off for ITProTV,
I'm your host Ronnie Wong.

446
00:27:24.023 --> 00:27:25.113
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

447
00:27:25.113 --> 00:27:30.946
>> Stay tuned right here for more
ITIL Intermediate Service Design Shows.

448
00:27:30.946 --> 00:27:35.278
[MUSIC]

449
00:27:35.278 --> 00:27:40.489
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo review the 5 aspects of service design.  Jo dives deeper into each of the 5 aspects to help us to understand the comprehensive nature of design.  She discusses the each particular aspect in depth to demonstrate how it fits into the overall value that ITIL delivers.
episodes.title: Service Design Principles Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.250 --> 00:00:03.464
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

2
00:00:03.464 --> 00:00:08.227
[CROSSTALK]
[SOUND]

3
00:00:08.227 --> 00:00:12.262
>> You're watching ITPro.TV.

4
00:00:12.262 --> 00:00:15.270
>> Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITPro.TV,

5
00:00:15.270 --> 00:00:19.020
you're watching
the ITIL Intermediate Service Design show.

6
00:00:19.020 --> 00:00:20.780
I'm your host Ronnie Wong, and

7
00:00:20.780 --> 00:00:25.050
today we're actually going to be taking
a look at five aspects of service design.

8
00:00:25.050 --> 00:00:29.110
Now we already talked about them briefly,
but here to help us understand in much

9
00:00:29.110 --> 00:00:33.280
more depth, is gonna be our ITIL
maven herself, Ms. Jo Peacock.

10
00:00:33.280 --> 00:00:34.550
Jo welcome to the show.

11
00:00:34.550 --> 00:00:36.880
>> Thank you very much for
having me Ronnie, how are you?

12
00:00:36.880 --> 00:00:37.790
>> I am doing fine.

13
00:00:37.790 --> 00:00:43.510
Now Jo we went over the basic
design principles themselves.

14
00:00:43.510 --> 00:00:46.670
We did mention the idea
of these five aspects but

15
00:00:46.670 --> 00:00:49.390
what are we actually gonna
take a look at and do now?

16
00:00:49.390 --> 00:00:52.790
>> So we're just gonna expand on what we
covered in a previous episode really.

17
00:00:52.790 --> 00:00:56.850
And just look a little bit more in
depth about what that actually entails.

18
00:00:56.850 --> 00:00:59.620
Each of the five aspects
of service design.

19
00:00:59.620 --> 00:01:04.310
>> All right so Joe as we get started here
once again where is the best place for us

20
00:01:04.310 --> 00:01:08.440
to get started on these different aspects
and take us through what we need to.

21
00:01:08.440 --> 00:01:12.260
>> Well, like always, best place to
start is right at the beginning, so

22
00:01:12.260 --> 00:01:13.990
we're gonna start with number one.

23
00:01:13.990 --> 00:01:18.480
And number one is the new or
changed service, as it says there.

24
00:01:18.480 --> 00:01:22.500
Now, in a previous slide in our
last episode, we looked at this and

25
00:01:22.500 --> 00:01:25.720
we said we design these service solution.

26
00:01:25.720 --> 00:01:27.690
And that's exactly what this is.

27
00:01:27.690 --> 00:01:31.420
This is actually designing
the service solution itself.

28
00:01:31.420 --> 00:01:35.650
On the service solution, as I've all ready
mentioned in the previous episode is made

29
00:01:35.650 --> 00:01:40.910
up of the components of the service or
what we call our configuration items.

30
00:01:40.910 --> 00:01:43.570
>> On those CIs are our software.

31
00:01:43.570 --> 00:01:45.820
What software are we going to use?

32
00:01:45.820 --> 00:01:49.730
And it doesn't just include the software
that's going to seat on our desktops for

33
00:01:49.730 --> 00:01:53.190
instance, we're not talking about just
client software we're talking about

34
00:01:53.190 --> 00:01:55.650
service software as well, okay.

35
00:01:55.650 --> 00:02:00.560
So, the software and the hardware and
again we now just talking about our

36
00:02:00.560 --> 00:02:04.780
hardware as in our desktop,
to our laptop, to our client hardware

37
00:02:04.780 --> 00:02:09.190
which can now includes tablets,
androids, or cellphones as well.

38
00:02:09.190 --> 00:02:12.130
But it will our server hardware too.

39
00:02:12.130 --> 00:02:15.560
And that includes, and we're going to
look at the infrastructure as well, but

40
00:02:15.560 --> 00:02:19.270
that includes anything that's
involved in the insfrastructure,

41
00:02:19.270 --> 00:02:23.980
like the routers or routers,
like all of our servers, etc.

42
00:02:23.980 --> 00:02:25.710
So that's a hardware.

43
00:02:25.710 --> 00:02:28.740
And then we're going to look
at our environment as well.

44
00:02:28.740 --> 00:02:32.200
Now our environment again is
part of our service solution.

45
00:02:32.200 --> 00:02:37.190
And as I always say you know I can't
use my services if I'm stood outside of

46
00:02:37.190 --> 00:02:42.015
the building for very long without my arms
getting tired from holding up my laptop,

47
00:02:42.015 --> 00:02:45.585
without my battery running out
because I've got no power, and

48
00:02:45.585 --> 00:02:47.825
without having some sort of connectivity.

49
00:02:47.825 --> 00:02:53.160
Because if I'm doing something secure then
perhaps I don't need to be using a WiFi.

50
00:02:53.160 --> 00:02:55.520
>> Perhaps I need some form of cable.

51
00:02:55.520 --> 00:02:57.010
But I also need somewhere to sit.

52
00:02:58.020 --> 00:03:00.900
And I don't mind standing all day long.

53
00:03:00.900 --> 00:03:02.010
But I need to be moving around.

54
00:03:02.010 --> 00:03:05.670
And if I've got a laptop like this and
then I can't do that.

55
00:03:05.670 --> 00:03:08.020
So yeah, I need some form of environment.

56
00:03:08.020 --> 00:03:11.450
I've gotta have that electricity and
I've gotta have somewhere to sit.

57
00:03:11.450 --> 00:03:16.260
And I know that that might sound as though
that's outside of the scope of IT, but

58
00:03:16.260 --> 00:03:17.200
it's not.

59
00:03:17.200 --> 00:03:19.220
We have to consider this and

60
00:03:19.220 --> 00:03:23.130
I wonder how many times has
a service has been designed.

61
00:03:23.130 --> 00:03:26.150
I know because I've seen this
where project management

62
00:03:26.150 --> 00:03:30.230
teams have forgotten to consider
how many electrical outlets,

63
00:03:30.230 --> 00:03:34.460
how many electrical sockets are in the
server room, or how much air conditioning

64
00:03:34.460 --> 00:03:37.609
is in the server room when they have gone
to put a new rack of servers in there.

65
00:03:38.870 --> 00:03:41.240
And we found out that, quite simply,

66
00:03:41.240 --> 00:03:47.000
the actual infrastructure in terms of
environment just simply cannot handle it,

67
00:03:47.000 --> 00:03:51.705
or maybe that UPS is not big enough for
that new rack of servers.

68
00:03:51.705 --> 00:03:55.775
And so whilst we might think about this
as just the fact that nobody wants to see

69
00:03:55.775 --> 00:04:00.325
outside, you know at the front of
the building, it's not really.

70
00:04:00.325 --> 00:04:04.370
We have to consider all the environmental
aspects, because without those

71
00:04:04.370 --> 00:04:09.250
I have been in plenty of server rooms
where the air conditioning has failed.

72
00:04:09.250 --> 00:04:13.830
I've been in mainframes where the air
conditioning has failed because we didn't

73
00:04:13.830 --> 00:04:17.000
plan the environmental
conditions in advance.

74
00:04:17.000 --> 00:04:19.060
We didn't plan for this.

75
00:04:19.060 --> 00:04:23.180
And then we have to pick up the pieces
when something catastrophically fails.

76
00:04:23.180 --> 00:04:25.200
When you're talking about
air conditioning failing,

77
00:04:25.200 --> 00:04:29.440
you're talking about taking down a lot
of services all at the same time and

78
00:04:29.440 --> 00:04:33.120
these can not be recolored in five
minutes, you've got to wait for

79
00:04:33.120 --> 00:04:36.710
that temperature to drop,
and that can take some time.

80
00:04:36.710 --> 00:04:39.270
So we've got to think about
the environmental aspects.

81
00:04:39.270 --> 00:04:42.280
We've also got to think about
the people aspects too.

82
00:04:43.330 --> 00:04:46.830
People are needed to not only build.

83
00:04:46.830 --> 00:04:49.270
And to implement that new service,

84
00:04:49.270 --> 00:04:54.140
people are needed to support
that service on a regular basis.

85
00:04:54.140 --> 00:04:56.710
And so people need training.

86
00:04:56.710 --> 00:04:58.530
Also people need to have believe it or

87
00:04:58.530 --> 00:05:01.770
not a capacity to be able to
pick up that new service.

88
00:05:02.970 --> 00:05:08.210
If I am running around,
8 hours a day or 12 hours a day.

89
00:05:08.210 --> 00:05:12.470
And I am so
busy that I have to take work home.

90
00:05:12.470 --> 00:05:16.530
You can't expect me to take on
the support of a new service as well.

91
00:05:16.530 --> 00:05:20.000
So, people have to have
the capacity to be able to do this.

92
00:05:20.000 --> 00:05:22.400
So, yeah, we have to consider.

93
00:05:22.400 --> 00:05:25.840
The people and
then consider our documentation, and

94
00:05:25.840 --> 00:05:27.730
consider our contracts as well.

95
00:05:27.730 --> 00:05:30.770
These are our contracts
with our suppliers,

96
00:05:30.770 --> 00:05:33.310
these are our existing services.

97
00:05:33.310 --> 00:05:35.740
Let me put this into perspective for you.

98
00:05:36.795 --> 00:05:43.570
If I am managing a service, and
I'm managing a financial service.

99
00:05:43.570 --> 00:05:46.190
So let's say for instance, SAP.

100
00:05:46.190 --> 00:05:48.120
And I'm managing SAP.

101
00:05:48.120 --> 00:05:53.758
And here I am with a customer, and
I have a four hour response target.

102
00:05:53.758 --> 00:06:01.140
In my current SLA with
my service desk team.

103
00:06:01.140 --> 00:06:03.090
Now, my service desk team then,

104
00:06:03.090 --> 00:06:08.590
well they will respond to me within four
hours if there was any issue with an SAP.

105
00:06:08.590 --> 00:06:12.980
So Ronnie is my service desk person,
he is my service desk manager.

106
00:06:12.980 --> 00:06:19.430
Now Ronnie will have a separate agreement
in OLA, in Operational Level Agreement

107
00:06:19.430 --> 00:06:24.130
with our server support team or
our infrastructure support team.

108
00:06:24.130 --> 00:06:31.870
To support that particular that particular
agreement that I have with him.

109
00:06:31.870 --> 00:06:35.710
So if I pass an incident to him,
he's got four hours.

110
00:06:35.710 --> 00:06:38.640
Which means that if he passes
it to the desktop guys and

111
00:06:38.640 --> 00:06:42.380
the desktop guys have got,
I don't know, maybe three hours.

112
00:06:42.380 --> 00:06:44.650
So they get back to Ronnie
within three hours.

113
00:06:44.650 --> 00:06:47.600
And then Ronnie comes back to me within
the four hours and we're all happy.

114
00:06:48.790 --> 00:06:52.990
Now let's just say now that we're
negotiating a brand new service.

115
00:06:52.990 --> 00:06:57.150
And that brand new service is email and
I want a 30 minute response.

116
00:06:58.540 --> 00:07:01.210
That means I negotiate a 30
minute response with Ronnie.

117
00:07:01.210 --> 00:07:05.740
And Ronnie might be okay as the service
desk manager to agree that with me,

118
00:07:05.740 --> 00:07:06.350
that's great.

119
00:07:07.630 --> 00:07:13.032
But he's got an existing agreement
with the server guys for three hours.

120
00:07:14.684 --> 00:07:18.590
Now this means that you've either got to
create another agreement with the server

121
00:07:18.590 --> 00:07:22.510
guys for that, well it's going to be
less than 30 minutes or like 15 minutes.

122
00:07:22.510 --> 00:07:25.600
They're probably not going
to want to agree to that.

123
00:07:26.680 --> 00:07:29.190
If we to go to modifier
existing agreement or

124
00:07:29.190 --> 00:07:31.890
you've got to create another
agreement with them.

125
00:07:31.890 --> 00:07:35.296
Well you don't wanna create another
agreement cause that means you could have

126
00:07:35.296 --> 00:07:40.020
5, 6, 20,
30 agreements between you the server guys.

127
00:07:41.220 --> 00:07:43.610
So we don't want that.

128
00:07:43.610 --> 00:07:47.890
I don't want to be as a customer
signing 15 different agreements either.

129
00:07:47.890 --> 00:07:54.336
But I'm not gonna be happy with four hours
with my service level agreement for email.

130
00:07:54.336 --> 00:07:55.963
I want it quicker than four hours.

131
00:07:55.963 --> 00:07:58.319
And that four hours that we've
got with financial management?

132
00:07:58.319 --> 00:08:01.434
Is not good enough for me, for email.

133
00:08:01.434 --> 00:08:06.696
So negotiating or service level targets
as it says in this new service,

134
00:08:06.696 --> 00:08:12.000
that's actually not going to be as
easy as we think that it would be.

135
00:08:12.000 --> 00:08:15.350
Because when I always say that we're not
starting off with a blank piece of paper,

136
00:08:15.350 --> 00:08:18.190
we're literally not starting off
with a blank piece of paper.

137
00:08:18.190 --> 00:08:20.940
And we have to consider that relationship

138
00:08:20.940 --> 00:08:23.160
between all of the components
of our services.

139
00:08:24.620 --> 00:08:26.475
So we think about the documentation.

140
00:08:26.475 --> 00:08:32.800
Now that's actually not complicated,
because Ronnie is an internal person.

141
00:08:32.800 --> 00:08:37.370
We both work for the same IT team or
we both work for the same organization.

142
00:08:37.370 --> 00:08:39.630
That's not complicated.

143
00:08:39.630 --> 00:08:45.360
Let's imagine now though that Ronnie's
desktop support team is outsourced.

144
00:08:45.360 --> 00:08:47.550
It's a third party.

145
00:08:47.550 --> 00:08:52.470
Then it becomes really complicated,
because we are talking about contract.

146
00:08:52.470 --> 00:08:57.160
We're talking about legally binding
contracts and they have to be negotiated.

147
00:08:59.070 --> 00:09:04.730
All of these considerations
form part of that new service.

148
00:09:04.730 --> 00:09:09.070
So when I looked at the service
design package in our last episode,

149
00:09:09.070 --> 00:09:12.620
I looked at everything that's needed for
that service design package, and

150
00:09:12.620 --> 00:09:18.400
that Is what we incorporate when we're
designing the service, including

151
00:09:18.400 --> 00:09:22.160
all of our service level targets,
including the time scales, including

152
00:09:22.160 --> 00:09:27.720

the outcomes that we are facilitating,

153
00:09:27.720 --> 00:09:32.320
including how much money we've got
to spend on that particular service.

154
00:09:33.770 --> 00:09:37.010
All of this has to be agreed.

155
00:09:37.010 --> 00:09:42.270
And all of this forms part of that
new service, absolutely everything.

156
00:09:43.610 --> 00:09:46.427
Of course we've got to come in on budget,

157
00:09:46.427 --> 00:09:49.815
cuz all projects come in on budget,
don't they?

158
00:09:49.815 --> 00:09:52.252
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] We've got to come in on budget.

159
00:09:52.252 --> 00:09:56.713
And we've gotta make sure that we consider
all of our warranty aspects as well,

160
00:09:56.713 --> 00:10:01.177
the availability, and the continuity,
and the security, and the capacity,

161
00:10:01.177 --> 00:10:02.920
we've got to consider those.

162
00:10:02.920 --> 00:10:04.930
And if you want to know
more about utility and

163
00:10:04.930 --> 00:10:08.250
warranty, then please take
a look at your foundation

164
00:10:08.250 --> 00:10:11.930
refresher that was right at the very
beginning of this particular show.

165
00:10:13.300 --> 00:10:16.980
We have to think about also our maturity.

166
00:10:16.980 --> 00:10:20.927
And it's not just about
a maturity of our processes,

167
00:10:20.927 --> 00:10:24.184
which we see a lot more
in depth in a CSI show.

168
00:10:24.184 --> 00:10:28.031
But we're also thinking about
the maturity of our all services, and

169
00:10:28.031 --> 00:10:31.358
how well aligned we are to
meet the organization's needs.

170
00:10:33.260 --> 00:10:33.970
So what about then?

171
00:10:33.970 --> 00:10:37.390
This is our first aspect with
designing that service solution.

172
00:10:37.390 --> 00:10:39.670
What about designing our tools then?

173
00:10:39.670 --> 00:10:40.910
The tools and

174
00:10:40.910 --> 00:10:46.930
the supporting systems that we are going
to use to be able to deliver that service.

175
00:10:48.430 --> 00:10:51.076
We've got one example here,
which is the service portfolio.

176
00:10:51.076 --> 00:10:55.882
And we've seen this particular
diagram in our service strategy

177
00:10:55.882 --> 00:10:58.150
downloadable material.

178
00:10:58.150 --> 00:11:01.400
And this simply is right in front
of us here, our service portfolio.

179
00:11:01.400 --> 00:11:03.093
That's split into three,

180
00:11:03.093 --> 00:11:07.658
that's split into pipeline which is
where we define our requirements and

181
00:11:07.658 --> 00:11:12.163
where we have those approved by way
of the business case being approved.

182
00:11:12.163 --> 00:11:17.165
And then in our catalogue
this is how our customer

183
00:11:17.165 --> 00:11:23.530
facing portion of our service portfolio,
should I say.

184
00:11:23.530 --> 00:11:26.725
And then we have our retired

the words that we just took
a glimpse out of a previous episode.

419
00:26:31.170 --> 00:26:33.330
And we're now seeing
where they can expand and

420
00:26:33.330 --> 00:26:38.000
where they do influence every area that
we have to consider when working and

421
00:26:38.000 --> 00:26:41.740
when coming up with the idea
of this service design.

422
00:26:41.740 --> 00:26:45.740
There's a lot more though to come, but
that is gonna be for another episode.

423
00:26:45.740 --> 00:26:49.870
So signing off for IT Pro TV,
I'm your host Ronnie Wong.

424
00:26:49.870 --> 00:26:50.900
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

425
00:26:50.900 --> 00:26:54.852
>> Stay tuned here for more
ITIL Intermediate Service Design shows.

426
00:26:54.852 --> 00:27:00.800
[MUSIC]

427
00:27:00.800 --> 00:27:04.622
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this show, Cherokee and Jo continue to discuss Service Design Principles. Jo recaps the previous episode where they covered the five aspects of Service Design. She then continues to explain the four separate technology domains including infrastructure, environmental, data and applications. She describes the business requirements stage, SOA approach, different Service Design Models and more!
episodes.title: Service Design Principles Part 3

29

30
00:01:08.078 --> 00:01:11.600
[LAUGH] Well as Cherokee said,
we're in service design principles.

31
00:01:11.600 --> 00:01:13.862
We're in a part three here, so

32
00:01:13.862 --> 00:01:19.082
in our last two sessions we looked
at the principles of service design.

33
00:01:19.082 --> 00:01:22.870
And in fact our four Ps of service design,
our people, process, products,

34
00:01:22.870 --> 00:01:23.960
and partners.

35
00:01:23.960 --> 00:01:28.020
And then we looked further into our
five aspects of service design.

36
00:01:28.020 --> 00:01:29.784
The five things that we design.

37
00:01:29.784 --> 00:01:32.690
And in part two we expanded on those.

38
00:01:32.690 --> 00:01:35.380
And now I'm gonna get
back to a word that I

39
00:01:35.380 --> 00:01:40.520
used in part one of our service design
principles which is that word holistic.

40
00:01:40.520 --> 00:01:43.640

the screen in front of you now.

41
00:01:43.640 --> 00:01:45.820
It's all about that holistic approach.

42
00:01:45.820 --> 00:01:49.680
It's ensuring that we
consider our four Ps.

43
00:01:49.680 --> 00:01:51.620
But more importantly than that, and

44
00:01:51.620 --> 00:01:56.110
I've already talked to this
extensively in part one and part two.

45
00:01:57.450 --> 00:02:02.155
We have to consider absolutely
everything that forms a service,

46
00:02:02.155 --> 00:02:04.860
all of our service components.

47
00:02:04.860 --> 00:02:07.110
But also there are interactions.

48
00:02:07.110 --> 00:02:12.570
We cannot make any change to
our infrastructure by bringing

49
00:02:12.570 --> 00:02:18.280
in a new service without impacting
another portion of our infrastructure.

50
00:02:18.280 --> 00:02:19.570
We just simply can't.

51
00:02:20.720 --> 00:02:24.860
And I also want to bring in items
here like right at the very,

52
00:02:24.860 --> 00:02:28.420
very bottom there,
our security levels, for instance.

53
00:02:28.420 --> 00:02:33.830
If we're bringing in a service that
has a specific security level,

54
00:02:33.830 --> 00:02:37.690
then that may affect the security
levels of our other services.

55
00:02:37.690 --> 00:02:41.250
Let's say that our organization,
just for example,

56
00:02:41.250 --> 00:02:45.040
was not just expanding but
actually transforming.

57
00:02:45.040 --> 00:02:48.060
And we want to do something
completely different.

58
00:02:48.060 --> 00:02:53.090
Then in that instance,
we may need to amend our security levels.

59
00:02:53.090 --> 00:02:56.700
I know of a certain group of companies,
and I always use this an example.

60
00:02:56.700 --> 00:02:57.990
The Virgin Group of companies,

61
00:02:57.990 --> 00:03:01.429
they are a brilliant example of
an organization that transforms.

62
00:03:02.442 --> 00:03:07.190
Now the Virgin Group of companies
use a shared services model for

63
00:03:07.190 --> 00:03:09.330
their IT service provision.

64
00:03:09.330 --> 00:03:15.110
And so every time that
organization transforms and

65
00:03:15.110 --> 00:03:17.870
does something completely different and

66
00:03:17.870 --> 00:03:24.290
brings in a new partner maybe by
acquisition or by franchisee etc.

67
00:03:24.290 --> 00:03:27.913
Every time they move into
a different industry sector,

68
00:03:27.913 --> 00:03:30.775
that IT service provider has to transform.

69
00:03:30.775 --> 00:03:32.835
Which means that as a service provider,

70
00:03:32.835 --> 00:03:36.170
they're bringing in
different security levels.

71
00:03:36.170 --> 00:03:40.510
For instance, we have the Virgin Atlantic.

72
00:03:40.510 --> 00:03:41.740
>> You're talking about Richard Branson?

73
00:03:41.740 --> 00:03:43.520
>> I'm talking Richard Branson, yes.

74
00:03:43.520 --> 00:03:47.910
So Virgin Atlantic, Virgin Atlantic
obviously we know about them.

75
00:03:47.910 --> 00:03:50.124
They're airplanes across the Atlantic,
believe it or not.

76
00:03:50.124 --> 00:03:51.868
How did they start?
Was it records originally?

77
00:03:51.868 --> 00:03:54.438
And then it kind of-
>> I think it was airplanes but

78
00:03:54.438 --> 00:03:56.130
it might have been records.

79
00:03:56.130 --> 00:03:56.785
>> Okay, yeah.

80
00:03:56.785 --> 00:03:57.796
>> Really showing our age now.

81
00:03:57.796 --> 00:04:00.002
>> Aren't they like going to space and
stuff now?

82
00:04:00.002 --> 00:04:03.291
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, well Virgin actually produce,

83
00:04:03.291 --> 00:04:06.770
well they do cell phones,
so you have Virgin Mobile.

84
00:04:06.770 --> 00:04:08.930
And we also have Virgin Finance.

85
00:04:08.930 --> 00:04:10.830
Virgin actually do finance,

86
00:04:10.830 --> 00:04:14.665
they do credit cards, etc.,
in Europe and throughout the UK as well.

87
00:04:14.665 --> 00:04:19.750
Virgin are actually the biggest,
I'm not too sure whether they're the only,

88
00:04:19.750 --> 00:04:24.830
but they are the biggest provider of
fiber-optic networks in the UK as well.

89
00:04:24.830 --> 00:04:26.173
>> Interesting.

90
00:04:26.173 --> 00:04:29.460
>> So every time,
they do something different, and

91
00:04:29.460 --> 00:04:32.602
as you said they are now
into aerospace as well.

92
00:04:32.602 --> 00:04:34.780
Now if you take a look at their website,

93
00:04:34.780 --> 00:04:38.476
I think they have well over a hundred
different organizations, or

94
00:04:38.476 --> 00:04:42.920
different companies within completely
different industry sectors.

95
00:04:42.920 --> 00:04:48.490
And every time they diversify, they have
to have different security requirements.

96
00:04:48.490 --> 00:04:51.660
And so you think of their
shared services organization,

97
00:04:51.660 --> 00:04:54.730
their IT organization that
supports all of this and

98
00:04:54.730 --> 00:04:58.510
the diverse skills that that
IT organization has to have.

99
00:04:58.510 --> 00:05:01.980
But then you think about every
time they bring in a new service,

100
00:05:01.980 --> 00:05:04.250
that will impact on their infrastructure.

101
00:05:04.250 --> 00:05:09.340
Now luckily, in the UK they provide
their own fiber optic cabling, so

102
00:05:09.340 --> 00:05:10.490
that's fantastic.

103
00:05:10.490 --> 00:05:13.930
But nevertheless, as a service provider,

104
00:05:13.930 --> 00:05:18.180
the IT service provider obviously
has a lot to keep up with.

105
00:05:18.180 --> 00:05:22.760
And so we have to make sure that,
in that particular environment,

106
00:05:22.760 --> 00:05:27.220
service design is done very,
very effectively and efficiently.

107
00:05:27.220 --> 00:05:30.780
And that we look at service design
from a holistic perspective,

108
00:05:30.780 --> 00:05:34.200
including all of those elements that
you have listed in front of you.

109
00:05:34.200 --> 00:05:39.500
And everything that we have covered
in the last two episodes too.

110
00:05:39.500 --> 00:05:44.140
So I do actually like this diagram and
I know that there is feedback that

111
00:05:44.140 --> 00:05:49.430
a lot of these diagrams can be
a little bit busy should we say.

112
00:05:49.430 --> 00:05:52.670
But let's start off right in
the middle here with our services,

113
00:05:52.670 --> 00:05:55.030
services A, B, and C.

114
00:05:55.030 --> 00:05:59.738
Now for every single service that
appears in our service pipeline or

115
00:05:59.738 --> 00:06:02.143
in our service portfolio rather.

116
00:06:02.143 --> 00:06:06.539
For every single service we should have
a service level agreement attached to that

117
00:06:06.539 --> 00:06:07.480
service.

118
00:06:07.480 --> 00:06:10.410
And every single service should
be articulated in the catalog,

119
00:06:10.410 --> 00:06:15.140
in terms of the business
process that it facilitates.

120
00:06:15.140 --> 00:06:21.000
But, underneath every single service

121
00:06:21.000 --> 00:06:24.320
we should have all of our
underpinning services.

122
00:06:24.320 --> 00:06:28.060
And our underpinning services
include things like our software and

123
00:06:28.060 --> 00:06:31.880
our hardware, also our infrastructure
is an underpinning service.

124
00:06:31.880 --> 00:06:36.940
And don't forget all of the environments,
the databases, etc that these sit on.

125
00:06:36.940 --> 00:06:41.810
And so we may have supporting
services with suppliers.

126
00:06:41.810 --> 00:06:46.880
And we might have some that are supported
internally within our own IT teams.

127
00:06:47.950 --> 00:06:51.000
So we do actually have,
when you think about this,

128
00:06:51.000 --> 00:06:56.120
quite a diverse set of relationships
between all of our services.

129
00:06:56.120 --> 00:07:00.140
And every time we bring in a new service
we have to think about this topology and

130
00:07:00.140 --> 00:07:01.940
exactly where that service will fit.

131
00:07:01.940 --> 00:07:06.660
But also what the relationships
are already impacts could be.

132
00:07:06.660 --> 00:07:10.790
Because no service can be designed and
transitioned in isolation.

133
00:07:10.790 --> 00:07:14.551
We don't start off with a blank
piece of paper anymore.

134
00:07:14.551 --> 00:07:18.250
Now of course and
I'm gonna go back to this previous slide.

135
00:07:18.250 --> 00:07:19.405
If I look at the bottom here,

136
00:07:19.405 --> 00:07:22.970
I've got three different suppliers
there in this particular example.

137
00:07:23.980 --> 00:07:28.815
But as it says in that bottom bullet point
there where we've got multiple external

138
00:07:28.815 --> 00:07:33.453
providers, external service providers,
then things can get quite tricky.

139
00:07:33.453 --> 00:07:35.630
Because we're talking about contracts and

140
00:07:35.630 --> 00:07:38.840
we're talking about
legally binding contracts.

141
00:07:38.840 --> 00:07:42.941
And those contracts and all of our
service level agreements internally,

142
00:07:42.941 --> 00:07:46.330
well we have to consider every
single aspect of the service.

143
00:07:46.330 --> 00:07:50.730
Including the four technology
domains as we like to call them,

144
00:07:50.730 --> 00:07:54.798
that are going to contribute
to the overall I don't like,

145
00:07:54.798 --> 00:08:00.042
performance I guess that's the right word,
but the overall activities.

146
00:08:00.042 --> 00:08:03.210
Absolutely everything that
happens within a service.

147
00:08:03.210 --> 00:08:06.780
And it's not just about performance but
it's also about maintainability and

148
00:08:06.780 --> 00:08:10.730
it's about being able to
support that service as well.

149
00:08:10.730 --> 00:08:13.904
So let's just break those down very,
very briefly.

150
00:08:13.904 --> 00:08:18.886
We've got to ensure that we
can accommodate in our designs

151
00:08:18.886 --> 00:08:22.049
any changes to our infrastructure.

152
00:08:22.049 --> 00:08:25.418
And I've already mentioned
changes to our environment.

153
00:08:25.418 --> 00:08:29.525
And this is things like the things
that easily get forgotten like the air

154
00:08:29.525 --> 00:08:31.587
conditioning in our server rooms.

155
00:08:31.587 --> 00:08:35.235
And making sure we've got enough
electrical outlets in our server rooms.

156
00:08:35.235 --> 00:08:40.511
And making sure that our UPS our
uniterrruptable power supply

157
00:08:40.511 --> 00:08:45.700
can accommodate any new servers and
any new hardware.

158
00:08:45.700 --> 00:08:46.980
And then think about our data.

159
00:08:46.980 --> 00:08:49.006
Think about the increase in data and

160
00:08:49.006 --> 00:08:52.122
think about how we're going
to store all of that data.

161
00:08:52.122 --> 00:08:54.540
And what about archiving that data?

162
00:08:54.540 --> 00:08:58.584
And what about data retention policies and
backups, etc.

163
00:08:58.584 --> 00:09:02.552
And then, of course, there's applications
and with any application, you know what?

164
00:09:02.552 --> 00:09:04.272
We need licensing.

165
00:09:04.272 --> 00:09:06.609
Now that's very obvious that you might,

166
00:09:06.609 --> 00:09:11.161
well okay we need to buy a new additional
licensing for that individual service.

167
00:09:11.161 --> 00:09:16.972
Yes you might, but what about if you need
additional operating system licenses?

168
00:09:16.972 --> 00:09:22.105
You brought a new service and
you brought in, maybe a new team within

169
00:09:22.105 --> 00:09:28.260
the organization to accommodate that
new service or to use that new service.

170
00:09:28.260 --> 00:09:32.730
And now all of a sudden you'll need
new operating system licenses as well.

171
00:09:34.750 --> 00:09:40.620
So in our business requirement stage,
the business case has been approved.

172
00:09:40.620 --> 00:09:44.840
This was approved at the end
of service strategy.

173
00:09:44.840 --> 00:09:47.270
And so in our business requirements stage,

174
00:09:47.270 --> 00:09:51.510
we're going to literally
agree on the requirements.

175
00:09:51.510 --> 00:09:54.393
We're going to agree
the statement of requirements and

176
00:09:54.393 --> 00:09:58.082
we're going to take a look at
the service acceptance criteria as well.

177
00:09:58.082 --> 00:10:02.260
So we're going to have
a project manager appointed.

178
00:10:02.260 --> 00:10:07.100
We're going to ensure that we
identify all of our stakeholders and

179
00:10:07.100 --> 00:10:11.350
that we understand how much money we've
got, we understand exactly when that new

180
00:10:11.350 --> 00:10:15.450
service is going to be delivered,
is going to be required by.

181
00:10:15.450 --> 00:10:18.160
And we understand who's
going to sign it off and

182
00:10:18.160 --> 00:10:23.140
we understand how we're going
to engage our customers.

183
00:10:23.140 --> 00:10:26.490
At the end of the service
design lifecycle phase,

184
00:10:26.490 --> 00:10:29.930
that's when we have finished designing.

185
00:10:29.930 --> 00:10:33.580
And we complete our service
design package, and

186
00:10:33.580 --> 00:10:39.120
then we move into transition,
we move into building.

187
00:10:39.120 --> 00:10:42.060
We don't accommodate scope creep.

188
00:10:42.060 --> 00:10:43.340
Once it's been signed off,

189
00:10:43.340 --> 00:10:47.290
it's been signed off and
anything else then is version two.

190
00:10:48.370 --> 00:10:52.140
So service design is when we
check that box is when we

191
00:10:52.140 --> 00:10:56.760
complete this design package.

192
00:10:56.760 --> 00:10:59.780
This is what happens and
then we move into service transition.

193
00:11:01.800 --> 00:11:04.240
So service orientated architecture.

194
00:11:04.240 --> 00:11:11.180
Well, it's considered to be best practice
by ensuring that all of our services,

195
00:11:11.180 --> 00:11:16.240
well, they're reuseable,
that we don't just think in silos.

196
00:11:16.240 --> 00:11:19.590
In terms of bringing in
individual services that we

197
00:11:19.590 --> 00:11:22.830
think about the relationships
between our services and

198
00:11:22.830 --> 00:11:26.870
we think about where we can
share common activities.

199
00:11:26.870 --> 00:11:32.680
So that includes things like, I mentioned
in a previous episode about databases for

200
00:11:32.680 --> 00:11:36.600
instance, and about having virtual
storage in our databases and

201
00:11:36.600 --> 00:11:40.140
we might only have one physical server,
but we might have three or

202
00:11:40.140 --> 00:11:45.150
four virtual servers that actually
sit on that one physical server.

203
00:11:45.150 --> 00:11:49.950
We might have three or four databases
that sit on that one physical server

204
00:11:49.950 --> 00:11:54.400
where we keep various data
from various services.

205
00:11:54.400 --> 00:11:58.810
Think about where we can share not
just our physical resources, but

206
00:11:58.810 --> 00:12:04.280
where we can share our virtual,
or our logical resources as well.

207
00:12:04.280 --> 00:12:09.705
So we want to incorporate, we want
Want to encourage a modular approach.

208
00:12:09.705 --> 00:12:14.542
Well, we have functionality that meets
the need of not just one service,

209
00:12:14.542 --> 00:12:16.971
but meets the need of many services.

210
00:12:16.971 --> 00:12:22.773
And by doing this, by incorporating
a flexible approach by incorporating

211
00:12:22.773 --> 00:12:28.951
relationships between services and
by incorporating shared functionality.

212
00:12:28.951 --> 00:12:33.719
Then it means that we can actually
be quicker to market as we deliver

213
00:12:33.719 --> 00:12:35.610
new solutions.

214
00:12:35.610 --> 00:12:39.010
And quite often nowadays a lot of our

215
00:12:39.010 --> 00:12:43.110
top providers most certainly
within IT working that way.

216
00:12:43.110 --> 00:12:46.150
And they work in the way
of a modular system and

217
00:12:46.150 --> 00:12:51.110
when we go to a service provider we
actually provide one modular at a time or

218
00:12:51.110 --> 00:12:53.442
we purchase one modular at a time.

219
00:12:53.442 --> 00:12:56.150
So we might purchase incident and
problem management.

220
00:12:56.150 --> 00:12:59.550
And then we'll purchase change management,
and then we'll purchase release and

221
00:12:59.550 --> 00:13:00.670
deployment management.

222
00:13:00.670 --> 00:13:03.262
And so as we implement ITIL,

223
00:13:03.262 --> 00:13:07.500
we're actually purchasing
the tool module by module.

Don't you call be an SME or
something like that?

454
00:26:54.470 --> 00:26:56.280
>> External Subject Matter Expert.

455
00:26:56.280 --> 00:27:00.315
>> There we go, yeah,
an Ex SME, that's even scarier.

456
00:27:00.315 --> 00:27:03.720
[LAUGH] Yeah, and
that's exactly what this is.

457
00:27:03.720 --> 00:27:05.330
Knowledge process outsourcing,

458
00:27:05.330 --> 00:27:08.240
it's where you work knowledge
within your organization.

459
00:27:08.240 --> 00:27:12.530
That you need some knowledge maybe for
a temporary basis or

460
00:27:12.530 --> 00:27:15.969
maybe it's something that
really you don't want to invest

461
00:27:17.500 --> 00:27:20.160
In training somebody
internally to be able to do.

462
00:27:20.160 --> 00:27:22.265
>> We always want to invest in you Jo.

463
00:27:22.265 --> 00:27:25.640
>> [LAUGH] I'm flattered or
scared, I'm not sure which.

464
00:27:26.860 --> 00:27:31.270
But, you know, we don't want to
invest in somebody internally, so

465
00:27:31.270 --> 00:27:36.210
we want to bring somebody in Just
to impart their knowledge or to

466
00:27:36.210 --> 00:27:41.390
set up a specific process or maybe to run
a process for us, because we acknowledge

467
00:27:41.390 --> 00:27:45.850
that they actually have better skills and
better experience than we do in house.

468
00:27:45.850 --> 00:27:50.230
And this is what we call knowledge
process outsourcing, just simply this.

469
00:27:50.230 --> 00:27:56.910
So, these are all options available to
us for sourcing for our service design.

470
00:27:56.910 --> 00:28:00.860
There are many different
combinations of sourcing.

471
00:28:00.860 --> 00:28:05.025
And it's not really down to me
to tell you which way is best.

472
00:28:05.025 --> 00:28:07.835
I mean obviously we can come
into your organisation and

473
00:28:07.835 --> 00:28:11.485
I can advice you which way is best
in your given circumstance, but

474
00:28:11.485 --> 00:28:14.515
I can't tell you the right way or
the wrong way from here.

475
00:28:14.515 --> 00:28:17.705
There's no one size fits all approaches,
I keep saying.

476
00:28:17.705 --> 00:28:22.440
It's up to you to mix and match and
find out what works best for you, but

477
00:28:22.440 --> 00:28:26.660
ultimately what you're doing is delivering
value to your organization, delivering

478
00:28:26.660 --> 00:28:31.620
value to your business so you have to
do what best meets their requirements.

479
00:28:33.180 --> 00:28:37.435
Now, we've reached the end of our
service design principles episodes.

480
00:28:37.435 --> 00:28:42.595
And so now what I'd like you to do is
to download your printed information.

481
00:28:42.595 --> 00:28:46.345
And you have an exercise in there that
looks at our service design principles.

482
00:28:46.345 --> 00:28:50.335
That's going to take you around
about an hour and a half to do.

483
00:28:50.335 --> 00:28:53.915
So that's 90 minutes to
undertake that exercise.

484
00:28:53.915 --> 00:28:56.035
So I'd like you to go away and

485
00:28:56.035 --> 00:29:00.180
to undertake that exercise
at your own leisure.

486
00:29:00.180 --> 00:29:04.010
And as Cherokee has said to me
numerous times before right,

487
00:29:04.010 --> 00:29:07.030
this is not about doing jumping
jacks in the corner of the room.

488
00:29:07.030 --> 00:29:11.580
Okay this is about testing your mental
agility and what you've learned so far.

489
00:29:11.580 --> 00:29:17.180
And if you have any queries on these
particular exercises then please feel free

490
00:29:17.180 --> 00:29:21.270
to join us in the forum and we will be
happy to help you out as best as we can,

491
00:29:21.270 --> 00:29:22.510
>> Like always Joan, thank you for

492
00:29:22.510 --> 00:29:23.740
being here, it was a pleasure.

493
00:29:23.740 --> 00:29:26.380
It was great with you here too but
don't go anywhere,

494
00:29:26.380 --> 00:29:28.350
we have more shows heading your way.

495
00:29:28.350 --> 00:29:31.454
We'llll go ahead and sign out to remember
I've been your host Cherokee Booth.

496
00:29:31.454 --> 00:29:32.180
>> And I am Jo Peacock.

497
00:29:32.180 --> 00:29:34.335
>> See you next time, here IT PRO TV.

498
00:29:34.335 --> 00:29:40.252
[MUSIC]

499
00:29:40.252 --> 00:29:43.733
Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: In this show, Jo and Cherokee introduce Design Coordination. Jo explains that the purpose is  to ensure the goals and objectives of service design are met by providing and maintaining a single point of coordination and control for all activities and processes within the Service Design phase.
episodes.title: SD Processes - Design Coordination

episodes.description: In this show, Jo and Cherokee continue to explain design coordination. They cover different types of criteria and responsibilities to outline in a Service Acceptance Criteria (SAC). Tune in for more!
episodes.title: SD Processes - Design Coordination Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.270 --> 00:00:03.085
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:03.085 --> 00:00:07.334
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:07.334 --> 00:00:11.674
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4

>> Welcome to your ITIL Intermediate
series, I'm your show host Cherokee Boose.

In this episode, we'll continue taking
a look at our service design processes,

00:00:28.460 --> 00:00:30.620

thank you Cherokee, how are you?

9
00:00:30.620 --> 00:00:31.790

in the last show we started talking

11
00:00:35.500 --> 00:00:39.660
Well, service design process,
the specific one of design coordination.

12
00:00:39.660 --> 00:00:44.092
If I can get this all squared away here,

00:00:44.092 --> 00:00:47.531
concept, so where is it that we'll
be picking up for this show?

14
00:00:47.531 --> 00:00:49.874
>> I just like testing you with

15

16

>> [LAUGH] Yeah, we are going to look at

00:00:54.990 --> 00:00:57.160
So specifically,
we're gonna look at the roles,

00:00:57.160 --> 00:00:59.990

00:00:59.990 --> 00:01:04.400
So in our last episode, we looked at that
interaction in-between design coordination

20
00:01:04.400 --> 00:01:08.770
and project management and
exactly what the two do.

21
00:01:08.770 --> 00:01:13.785
And now we're just gonna look at who
we need for design coordination,

22
00:01:13.785 --> 00:01:17.361
so we're gonna start off
with our process owner.

23
00:01:17.361 --> 00:01:21.984
Now I should hope that you have
completed your foundation recap or

24
00:01:21.984 --> 00:01:28.051
that you have recently completed your
foundation material, your foundation show.

25
00:01:28.051 --> 00:01:32.990
In which case you understand that the role
of a process owner is to be accountable

26
00:01:32.990 --> 00:01:34.900
for a specific process.

27
00:01:34.900 --> 00:01:39.860
So they are not necessarily responsible
for carrying out the activities of that

28
00:01:39.860 --> 00:01:44.620
process but they are accountable for
making sure the process happens.

29
00:01:44.620 --> 00:01:49.570
And they are accountable for ensuring that
the process produces the right output.

30
00:01:49.570 --> 00:01:53.000
In which case, with design coordination,

31
00:01:53.000 --> 00:01:55.360
we're talking about
the service design package.

32
00:01:55.360 --> 00:01:59.754
And we're also talking about improvement
initiatives within the whole of service

33
00:01:59.754 --> 00:02:00.262
design.

34
00:02:00.262 --> 00:02:05.050
As we looked on at the last slide of our
last episode we looked at the fact that

35
00:02:05.050 --> 00:02:09.536
service design coordination was
not just about individual designs.

36
00:02:09.536 --> 00:02:12.200
But it's also about
overseeing design the whole

37
00:02:12.200 --> 00:02:16.420
of the service design lifecycle
phase in its entirety.

38
00:02:16.420 --> 00:02:20.664
Now the process manager well,
they are responsible for

39
00:02:20.664 --> 00:02:25.460
carrying out the activities
required within service design.

40
00:02:25.460 --> 00:02:30.984
So take a look at this, there seems to
be a huge number of responsibilities

41
00:02:30.984 --> 00:02:34.520
there for the process manager
>> It sure does.

42
00:02:34.520 --> 00:02:42.230
>> Yes, so I'm only gonna pull out a few
of these for you to I guess, remember.

43
00:02:42.230 --> 00:02:45.365
>> Well I mean, you even covered a lot
of them in the previous show and

44
00:02:45.365 --> 00:02:48.770
that seems like a lot then,
a bit like a very big responsibility.

45
00:02:48.770 --> 00:02:54.467
>> We did and what we have to do
here is just ensure that we get the,

46
00:02:54.467 --> 00:02:56.118
how do I say this?

47
00:02:56.118 --> 00:03:00.817
That we actually get the responsibilities
defined between the process owner and

48
00:03:00.817 --> 00:03:02.138
the process manager.

49
00:03:02.138 --> 00:03:06.250
Because we also have the service design
manager role, which appears here.

50
00:03:06.250 --> 00:03:10.961
And it simply says that many organizations
will just have the job of service

51
00:03:10.961 --> 00:03:12.096
design manager.

52
00:03:12.096 --> 00:03:16.318
Which combines the process owner and
the process manager, and

53
00:03:16.318 --> 00:03:18.375
this is very, very true.

54
00:03:18.375 --> 00:03:21.857
There are very few organizations
other than large organizations.

55
00:03:21.857 --> 00:03:26.035
Where we have a separate process owner for
design coordination and

56
00:03:26.035 --> 00:03:28.879
a process manager for design coordination.

57
00:03:28.879 --> 00:03:33.610
Bearing in mind that what we have is
we have processes within service design

58
00:03:33.610 --> 00:03:34.221
such as.

59
00:03:34.221 --> 00:03:38.304
Service level management and
supplier management and

60
00:03:38.304 --> 00:03:43.600
availability and capacity and
we also have continuity and security.

61
00:03:43.600 --> 00:03:47.920
And these processes themselves all
produce their own outputs, and

62
00:03:47.920 --> 00:03:52.620
their outputs are inputs into
the service design package.

63
00:03:52.620 --> 00:03:55.850
So because we've got process managers and
process owners for

64
00:03:55.850 --> 00:03:57.920
each of those processes.

65
00:03:57.920 --> 00:04:03.570
Then quite often we don't actually
need a design coordination

66
00:04:03.570 --> 00:04:08.870
process owner and manager because that
sounds like a huge number of people.

67
00:04:10.270 --> 00:04:14.145
What does the process manager do other
than collating all of the outputs from

68
00:04:14.145 --> 00:04:17.355
every other process within service design?

69
00:04:17.355 --> 00:04:22.009
So quite often this will be combined, and
you can take a look at the activities here

70
00:04:22.009 --> 00:04:24.653
and what we're going to
do is we're going to.

71
00:04:24.653 --> 00:04:29.576
As we move forward into all of the other
processes, you'll see that the other

72
00:04:29.576 --> 00:04:34.512
processes are producing outputs
that are actually inputs into this.

73
00:04:34.512 --> 00:04:37.702
What we're doing is we're insuring
that there's consistent design and

74
00:04:37.702 --> 00:04:40.522
we're ensuring that we
use a common framework.

75
00:04:40.522 --> 00:04:43.049
Well of course, project management's
gonna help us with that.

76
00:04:43.049 --> 00:04:48.480
So having one person that dictates
how we are going to perform within

77
00:04:48.480 --> 00:04:55.266
service design, that's quite often all
that some organizations really require.

78
00:04:55.266 --> 00:05:00.140
And sometimes this sits within the role
of the program management office as well,

79
00:05:00.140 --> 00:05:00.830
with the PMO.

80
00:05:02.390 --> 00:05:07.070
So what do we have as inputs here
then into design coordination?

81
00:05:07.070 --> 00:05:12.030
Well, we want everything that's an output
from service strategy basically, so

82
00:05:12.030 --> 00:05:14.180
that's includes our change proposals.

83
00:05:14.180 --> 00:05:19.392
That includes our new ideas that come
into our service pipeline, that includes

84
00:05:19.392 --> 00:05:24.553
our business, I'd forgotten what the name
is right now off the top of my head.

85
00:05:24.553 --> 00:05:29.454
That thing, that justification for
a significant item of expenditure,

86
00:05:29.454 --> 00:05:30.560
what is that?

87
00:05:30.560 --> 00:05:33.082
>> That is going be your-
>> A business case, there you go,

88
00:05:33.082 --> 00:05:34.762
I knew that started with the word B.

89
00:05:34.762 --> 00:05:37.354
>> [LAUGH]
>> Wait, it's gonna be one of those

90
00:05:37.354 --> 00:05:41.080
sessions and I am sorry for
that, that's our business case.

91
00:05:41.080 --> 00:05:46.430
So that's an input into service design as
well as all of the business information

92
00:05:46.430 --> 00:05:51.550
and any business impact analysis
that service strategy does as well.

93
00:05:51.550 --> 00:05:55.080
Service strategy, hand in hand with
business relationship management is going

94
00:05:55.080 --> 00:05:57.790
to be performing business impact analysis.

95
00:05:57.790 --> 00:06:02.010
On what happens if we don't input
the implement that new service?

96
00:06:02.010 --> 00:06:05.660
What impact will there be when we
do implement that new service,

97
00:06:05.660 --> 00:06:07.300
and what if it fails?

98
00:06:07.300 --> 00:06:12.110
Is that service what we call a VBF,
a Vital Business Function or not, so

99
00:06:12.110 --> 00:06:13.770
what else have we got as inputs here?

100
00:06:13.770 --> 00:06:17.340
Well, we've got the change schedule,
and that change schedule,

101
00:06:17.340 --> 00:06:21.320
well that tells us what's coming
up from change management.

102
00:06:21.320 --> 00:06:24.830
And we have to ensure that we
coordinate all our designs and

103
00:06:24.830 --> 00:06:29.250
therefore, the timescales for
our designs in with that change schedule.

104
00:06:29.250 --> 00:06:34.196
Obviously we use the information from
our configuration management system, and

105
00:06:34.196 --> 00:06:37.862
we need to incorporate all of
the governance requirements.

106
00:06:37.862 --> 00:06:41.917
And all of our legal and ethical
requirements that we may have as well,

107
00:06:41.917 --> 00:06:45.240
so what starts off design
coordination then?

108
00:06:45.240 --> 00:06:49.240
Well, to put it simply,
it's that approved business case,

109
00:06:49.240 --> 00:06:53.590
I actually remembered the word just now
right, it's that approved business case.

110
00:06:53.590 --> 00:06:59.275
It's that RFC that request for change
that comes in from the change proposal,

111
00:06:59.275 --> 00:07:02.005
comes in from a service strategy.

112
00:07:02.005 --> 00:07:03.205
We have that approved and

113
00:07:03.205 --> 00:07:08.192
this is what starts us into service
design, designing that service.

114
00:07:08.192 --> 00:07:12.572
Just remember that here in service design,
we are designing the service.

115
00:07:12.572 --> 00:07:16.334
We're not building it, we hand that
over to service transition and

116
00:07:16.334 --> 00:07:18.581
it's service transition that builds.

117
00:07:18.581 --> 00:07:23.722
So what we're producing are SDPs for
each and every service.

118
00:07:23.722 --> 00:07:28.265
But don't forget,
those SDPs should be to a standard,

119
00:07:28.265 --> 00:07:33.690
a consistent format,
we want to have consistency in place.

120
00:07:33.690 --> 00:07:37.370
So of course,
when we talk about revised processes and

121
00:07:37.370 --> 00:07:39.931
we talk about revised systems, etc.

122
00:07:39.931 --> 00:07:44.779
Well that's because we want to improve and
we want to add in consistency to

123
00:07:44.779 --> 00:07:49.690
our designs overall,
as well as to each individual design.

124
00:07:49.690 --> 00:07:53.958
So now we've got a slide in front
of us that looks at the interfaces

125
00:07:53.958 --> 00:07:55.831
with design coordination.

126
00:07:55.831 --> 00:07:58.956
Now I've already mentioned,
service level management and

127
00:07:58.956 --> 00:08:02.338
availability and capacity and
service continuity management.

128
00:08:02.338 --> 00:08:04.943
And I'm hoping that somewhere up there.

129
00:08:04.943 --> 00:08:08.750
There isn't so I'm gonna mention
security management as well,

130
00:08:08.750 --> 00:08:11.930
because they are our for
warranty processes.

131
00:08:11.930 --> 00:08:14.090
Service level management and
supplier management,

132
00:08:14.090 --> 00:08:18.550
we are going to cover in later episodes.

133
00:08:18.550 --> 00:08:22.760
But let's take a look at strategy, let's
take a look at financial management and

134
00:08:22.760 --> 00:08:27.300
service portfolio, and business
relationship management for a moment.

135
00:08:27.300 --> 00:08:31.670
This particular process is
setting service strategy,

136
00:08:31.670 --> 00:08:35.028
and for those of you that have
done your service strategy,

137
00:08:35.028 --> 00:08:39.510
I was gonna say class, but
looked to your service strategy episodes,

138
00:08:39.510 --> 00:08:44.060
you will see in there what
outputs these provide.

139
00:08:44.060 --> 00:08:48.497
These are providing a direction for
us here in service design.

140
00:08:48.497 --> 00:08:53.070
They're providing the governance models
and they're providing our policies.

141
00:08:53.070 --> 00:08:56.500
And business relationship management and
service portfolio management,

142
00:08:56.500 --> 00:09:03.760
they are actually providing our new ideas
and that's what we're designing after all.

143
00:09:03.760 --> 00:09:04.770
Financial management,

144
00:09:04.770 --> 00:09:08.610
of course, gives us money, tells us
how much money we've got to spend.

145
00:09:08.610 --> 00:09:13.590
And we actually then will feed back to
financial management our cost models,

146
00:09:13.590 --> 00:09:16.320
in other words how much
money we are spending.

147
00:09:16.320 --> 00:09:19.890
And then if we look at the remainder we're
talking about release and deployment, and

148
00:09:19.890 --> 00:09:24.240
service validation and testing, and change
evaluation, and change management, and

149
00:09:24.240 --> 00:09:26.390
transition planning and support.

150
00:09:26.390 --> 00:09:31.840
Well, they're all in service transitions,
so they are building these new services.

151
00:09:31.840 --> 00:09:33.740
Now transition planning and support,

152
00:09:33.740 --> 00:09:39.250
I like to think of that as the sister
a process to design coordination.

153
00:09:39.250 --> 00:09:43.970
Because they're performing all of the same
activities for design coordination for

154
00:09:43.970 --> 00:09:47.720
transition as design coordination is for
service design.

155
00:09:47.720 --> 00:09:52.370
So transition planning and support, it's
kind of the other side to the same coin.

156
00:09:52.370 --> 00:09:56.300
Performing exactly the same activities
only for the build, and test and

157
00:09:56.300 --> 00:10:00.230
implementation as design coordination
does for the actual design.

158
00:10:01.540 --> 00:10:05.820
So what is it that we need to achieve
then within design coordination?

159
00:10:05.820 --> 00:10:11.213
Now don't forget, CSFs, and we covered
this in CSI within our foundation

160
00:10:11.213 --> 00:10:15.760
material, but we've also covered
this in service strategy.

161
00:10:15.760 --> 00:10:19.667
And we cover this again in our
CSI life cycle phase, too.

162
00:10:19.667 --> 00:10:22.610
A CSF is a critical success factor.

163
00:10:22.610 --> 00:10:27.090
It's something we want to achieve, but
it's something that is quite often fairly

164
00:10:27.090 --> 00:10:31.795
intangible and so we will measure whether
we are achieving our critical success

165
00:10:31.795 --> 00:10:36.990
factors by the achievement of KPIs,
our key performance indicators.

166
00:10:36.990 --> 00:10:40.940
And as a rule, we need at least
two to three KPIs per CSF,

167
00:10:40.940 --> 00:10:45.370
although over time we may
build on the number of KPIs.

168
00:10:45.370 --> 00:10:48.870
So what examples then have we got for
CSFs for this?

169
00:10:48.870 --> 00:10:53.444
And don't forget, these are just examples,
nothing more than that.

170
00:10:53.444 --> 00:10:55.012
Okay, we can only give you an example.

171
00:10:55.012 --> 00:10:58.800
Your CSFs are unique to your organization.

172
00:10:58.800 --> 00:11:01.624
So one of the CSFs that we
have here are accurate and

173
00:11:01.624 --> 00:11:03.850
consistent service design packages.

174
00:11:03.850 --> 00:11:09.110
It goes back to having the templates for
our service design packages.

175
00:11:09.110 --> 00:11:12.070
So what we want is a reduction
in the number of subsequent

176
00:11:12.070 --> 00:11:17.150
revisions of the content of the SDP,

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo discuss the basics of service catalog management. Also she emphasizes the use policies to help.
episodes.title: SD Processes - Service Catalog Mgmt

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo continue with Service Catalog Management.  Jo describes the different roles and responsibilities of managing the service catalogue. episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo begin to discuss service level management.  She describes managing the agreed upon targets by the customer and service is the goal of service level management.  This is normally accomplished in a process that begins with an Service Level Requirements that include Service Level Targets.  She also emphasizes the timeline using OLAs, UCs and SLAs.
episodes.title: SD Processes - Service Level Mgmt

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo, look more in-depth into the the SLM.  This includes discusses the different aspects of service management concepts: Service Based, Customer Based and then Multi-Level Service Management.  Jo re-emphasizes the timeline build of Service Level Management.
episodes.title: SD Processes - Service Level Mgmt Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo, look at triggers, input and output, challenge and risks for Service Level Management.  Jo discusses each particular element to help us to understand how to start and what to expect.  She also discusses the major challenges to overcome and the risk of not doing it too.
episodes.title: SD Processes - Service Level Mgmt Part 3

episodes.description: {Description}In this episode, Ronnie and Jo dive into Supplier Management.  Jo emphasizes the legal technical issues around contracts may require someone with specialized skills to help with this process.  She also describes the activities and considerations and different types of suppliers organizations will negotiate with for the service required.  Lastly, she describes the CSFs and KPIs as well as the challenges and risks to the organization in supplier management.
episodes.title: SD Processes - Supplier Management

episodes.description: In this show, Cherokee and Jo introduce Availability Management. Jo defines it as a means ensure the level of agreed IT Service availability meets the service level achievements, in a cost-effective and timely manner. She states it is so much more than just being available during set hours but also ensuring the agreed upon levels of quality.
episodes.title: SD Processes - Availability Management

episodes.description: In this show, Jo and Cherokee continue discussing Availability Management by reviewing the an Availability Management diagram. Jo explains the guiding principles such as holistically understanding the needs of the customer or organization and aspects of availability. The ladies also talk about serviceability terminology such as mean time between failure (MTBF), mean time to restore service (MTRS) and single points of failure (SPOFs).
