00:28:55.190 --> 00:28:56.610
Is that a true statement or not?

507
00:28:56.610 --> 00:28:59.210
Well, yes, I really do believe that.

508
00:28:59.210 --> 00:29:02.890
Because if you don't measure it,
if you can't work out with something

509
00:29:02.890 --> 00:29:07.170
is being delivered to any specific
targets, then that probably means that all

510
00:29:07.170 --> 00:29:09.990
you're interested in is just saying,
yes, it's there.

511
00:29:09.990 --> 00:29:13.758
It probably means that all you're
interested in doing is just checking

512
00:29:13.758 --> 00:29:15.090
the box or ticking a box.

513
00:29:15.090 --> 00:29:17.274
But the one thing that I will say is that,
of course,

514
00:29:17.274 --> 00:29:20.170
in ITIL we're interested in efficiency and
effectiveness.

515
00:29:20.170 --> 00:29:24.173
And so if you're not going to do
anything with it, then don't measure it.

516
00:29:24.173 --> 00:29:29.097
Take a look at knowledge management in
our service transition lifecycle phase.

517
00:29:29.097 --> 00:29:34.120
And you will hear me tell you quite
a lot that we only produce reports

518
00:29:34.120 --> 00:29:39.930
if we're going to be able to make
an informed decision from that report.

519
00:29:39.930 --> 00:29:41.300
In other words, we only produce a nice,

520
00:29:41.300 --> 00:29:44.030
pretty picture if we're
gonna do something with it.

521
00:29:44.030 --> 00:29:46.567
If we're not gonna do something
with it and we're not gonna

522
00:29:46.567 --> 00:29:49.128
make an informed decision, then we're-
>> We're wasting

523
00:29:49.128 --> 00:29:51.686
time generating the report,
and then wasting time for

524
00:29:51.686 --> 00:29:53.864
having people look at
these useless reports.

525
00:29:53.864 --> 00:29:55.969
>> Right, and in fact, people don't
look at these useless reports.

526
00:29:55.969 --> 00:29:58.698
>> [LAUGH]
>> So, what happens is that we see reports

527
00:29:58.698 --> 00:30:02.770
sitting on desks all the time
that are never, ever referred to.

528
00:30:02.770 --> 00:30:04.059
And so, we'll tell you in ITIL,

529
00:30:04.059 --> 00:30:06.697
don't produce a report unless
you're gonna do something with it.

530
00:30:06.697 --> 00:30:09.850
And that's exactly the same with
availability management reports.

531
00:30:09.850 --> 00:30:13.080
And that's why it's so important
that we get our targets perfect, so

532
00:30:13.080 --> 00:30:14.540
that we know what we're measuring.

533
00:30:14.540 --> 00:30:19.270
Because otherwise, and I'll say this in
service level management all the time,

534
00:30:19.270 --> 00:30:23.340
the color that I do not want to
see in a SLAM chart is green.

535
00:30:23.340 --> 00:30:26.020
Because that tells me that you're
achieving all of your targets, and

536
00:30:26.020 --> 00:30:28.750
I don't believe you, simple as that.

537
00:30:28.750 --> 00:30:29.930
Call me cynical.

538
00:30:29.930 --> 00:30:32.380
All right,
maybe I'm a glass half-empty type person.

539
00:30:32.380 --> 00:30:35.360
I'm not really, but
I don't wanna see green.

540
00:30:35.360 --> 00:30:39.138
Because I guarantee that I'll go to any
one of your customers and I'll say,

541
00:30:39.138 --> 00:30:43.459
are you happy with absolutely everything,
and they're gonna turn around and say no.

542
00:30:43.459 --> 00:30:45.542
If they're not happy but
your SLAM charts agree,

543
00:30:45.542 --> 00:30:48.725
then there's something wrong
with what you're measuring.

544
00:30:48.725 --> 00:30:50.320
So think about what we're measuring.

545
00:30:50.320 --> 00:30:52.790
I know that we look at this in
continual service improvement.

546
00:30:52.790 --> 00:30:55.460
And we looked at this in
service level management.

547
00:30:55.460 --> 00:31:00.260
But again, if we're going to agree
to deliver availability management

548
00:31:00.260 --> 00:31:04.230
to agreed target, then those targets
have gotta be meaningful, right?

549
00:31:04.230 --> 00:31:06.900
And we've gotta be able
to achieve those targets.

550
00:31:06.900 --> 00:31:11.680
Don't forget that acronym, SMART,
with all of our targets, our KPIs as well.

551
00:31:13.120 --> 00:31:15.796
So what I'm gonna leave you with
is exactly where we started.

552
00:31:15.796 --> 00:31:20.770
And this is gonna be exactly where we
start in our next episode as well.

553
00:31:20.770 --> 00:31:22.732
Just looking at the proactive and

554
00:31:22.732 --> 00:31:26.035
the reactive activities of
Availability Management.

555
00:31:26.035 --> 00:31:27.610
And in our next episode,

556
00:31:27.610 --> 00:31:32.722
we're going to focus on some reactive
activities of availability management.

557
00:31:32.722 --> 00:31:34.348
And then in subsequent episodes,

558
00:31:34.348 --> 00:31:38.560
we'll be looking at proactive activities
of availability management too.

559
00:31:38.560 --> 00:31:40.557
>> Well, it sounds like you
have everything planned out.

560
00:31:40.557 --> 00:31:44.072
Just like we should be doing when we're
talking about availability management, so

561
00:31:44.072 --> 00:31:45.430
thank you for that, Jo.

562
00:31:45.430 --> 00:31:47.340
But thank you for joining us as well.

563
00:31:47.340 --> 00:31:49.720
Stay tuned,
we have more information headed your way.

564
00:31:49.720 --> 00:31:51.440
For this show,
we'll go ahead and sign out.

565
00:31:51.440 --> 00:31:53.308
Remember I've been your host,
Cherokee Boose.

566
00:31:53.308 --> 00:31:54.307
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

567
00:31:54.307 --> 00:31:56.605
>> See you next time here at ITPRO.TV.

568
00:31:56.605 --> 00:32:02.608
[MUSIC]

569
00:32:02.608 --> 00:32:05.670
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: In this show, Cherokee and Jo  continue discussing Availability Management, however they emphasize reactive availability management. They discuss how the importance of monitoring, measuring, analyzing and more can help ensure actual availability compared to agreed targets. Jo explain the factors that influence the user view and what we can do improve that customer experience.
episodes.title: SD Processes - Availability Management Part 3
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:04.532
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:04.532 --> 00:00:06.801
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.801 --> 00:00:08.049
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.049 --> 00:00:11.009
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:11.009 --> 00:00:16.340
>> Welcome to your ITIL Intermediate
Series, I'm your show host Cherokee Boose.

6
00:00:16.340 --> 00:00:20.770
In this episode, we'll continue
talking about Availability Management,

7
00:00:20.770 --> 00:00:22.128
we're actually in a part three.

8
00:00:22.128 --> 00:00:24.793
So far Jo's given us some
pretty great tips, and

9
00:00:24.793 --> 00:00:28.764
we were able to get her back in studios
today to continue with this topic.

10
00:00:28.764 --> 00:00:29.820
How's it going today, Jo?

11
00:00:29.820 --> 00:00:31.340
>> Absolutely great Cherokee.

12
00:00:31.340 --> 00:00:32.156
How are you?

13
00:00:32.156 --> 00:00:33.746
>> I had to bribe her with cookies.

14
00:00:33.746 --> 00:00:35.483
>> Actually that's not a bad idea yeah.

15
00:00:35.483 --> 00:00:37.804
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] It's only joking right.

16
00:00:37.804 --> 00:00:42.570
>> All I had to say was Availability
Management and she was there spot on.

17
00:00:42.570 --> 00:00:43.569
>> It wasn't quite like that.

18
00:00:43.569 --> 00:00:44.724
>> [LAUGH]
>> He wasn't.

19
00:00:44.724 --> 00:00:46.456
It was the cookies but anyway.

20
00:00:46.456 --> 00:00:48.900
>> [LAUGH] So
what is the first will be looking out?

21
00:00:48.900 --> 00:00:51.747
I know we have talking about it,
a good amount here but

22
00:00:51.747 --> 00:00:56.009
we have a couple of other things at I
know you wouldn't cover here in the show.

23
00:00:56.009 --> 00:00:57.191
>> Believe me,
I've got more than a couple.

24
00:00:57.191 --> 00:00:58.735
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

25
00:00:58.735 --> 00:00:59.790
>> Of course you do.

26
00:00:59.790 --> 00:01:00.970
>> Yeah, of course I do.

27
00:01:00.970 --> 00:01:03.458
Come one, when have you only ever
known me to talk for two minutes?

28
00:01:03.458 --> 00:01:05.446
No, we got more than a couple
of things to cover here.

29
00:01:05.446 --> 00:01:11.550
I'm gonna start off by looking at
this favorite diagram of mine, okay?

30
00:01:11.550 --> 00:01:13.958
It's how we've ended up
our previous episode, and

31
00:01:13.958 --> 00:01:16.540
it's how we started off our
previous episodes as well.

32
00:01:16.540 --> 00:01:20.268
So we're gonna look at this same diagram,
and I just want to remind you that

33
00:01:20.268 --> 00:01:23.480
availability management is about
planning for availability.

34
00:01:23.480 --> 00:01:26.520
Down at the bottom there,
our proactive activities.

35
00:01:26.520 --> 00:01:31.780
But it's also about, well, acknowledging
the fact that availability can be

36
00:01:31.780 --> 00:01:35.120
hampered in the real world,
in our life production environment, and

37
00:01:35.120 --> 00:01:38.510
it doesn't matter how well
we plan things go wrong.

38
00:01:38.510 --> 00:01:42.630
So we have reactive activities for
availability management.

39
00:01:42.630 --> 00:01:45.050
So we're going to look at
this particular episode.

40
00:01:45.050 --> 00:01:49.063
We're going to focus on the reactive
activity of the extended or

41
00:01:49.063 --> 00:01:51.890
expanded incident lifecycle.

42
00:01:51.890 --> 00:01:52.650
It's an acronym.

43
00:01:52.650 --> 00:01:56.630
We call it EIL, and in some books it's
written extended and in some books it's

44
00:01:56.630 --> 00:02:01.240
written expanded, and it doesn't
really matter which one you use.

45
00:02:01.240 --> 00:02:04.382
But reactive availability management is

46
00:02:04.382 --> 00:02:09.160
all about monitoring our
live production service.

47
00:02:09.160 --> 00:02:14.270
Monitoring our live environment and
identifying when something's gone wrong.

48
00:02:14.270 --> 00:02:18.930
Now, incident management is going to
help us with that, and then to try and

49
00:02:18.930 --> 00:02:21.000
fix it when it does go wrong.

50
00:02:21.000 --> 00:02:24.570
Get it back up and
running as quickly as we possibly can.

51
00:02:24.570 --> 00:02:27.961
So we're monitoring,
we're measuring, we're analyzing and

52
00:02:27.961 --> 00:02:31.857
reporting on both service and
component availability, as it says there.

53
00:02:31.857 --> 00:02:34.870
Event management is
gonna help us with this.

54
00:02:34.870 --> 00:02:37.600
We're not gonna to be doing
the monitoring in Installation and

55
00:02:37.600 --> 00:02:41.750
in fact what we should be doing
is ensuring that event management

56
00:02:41.750 --> 00:02:45.970
has the right parameters in place to
actually do the monitoring for us.

57
00:02:45.970 --> 00:02:48.050
Remember ITILS is about two ways.

58
00:02:48.050 --> 00:02:50.126
It's about efficiency and effectiveness.

59
00:02:50.126 --> 00:02:54.333
And it's never going to be efficient for
us to well,

60
00:02:54.333 --> 00:02:59.560
to do something that duplicates
what somebody else is doing.

61
00:02:59.560 --> 00:03:03.670
So, if event management is actually
monitoring as specific service or

62
00:03:03.670 --> 00:03:08.855
a specific component then let's
leave event management to

63
00:03:08.855 --> 00:03:11.955
we don't have to do that as well
duplication is certainly not efficient.

64
00:03:13.025 --> 00:03:16.245
What we're going to be doing is we're
going to be taking what event management

65
00:03:16.245 --> 00:03:19.705
is monitoring, and we'll be telling event
management what to monitor as well.

66
00:03:19.705 --> 00:03:23.133
And then we're going to be
analyzing what's happening.

67
00:03:23.133 --> 00:03:27.796
And assisting incident and problem
management at the same time to ensure that

68
00:03:27.796 --> 00:03:33.460
our service is, well, we restored them
within our availability parameters.

69
00:03:33.460 --> 00:03:38.117
So we have got to initially when we start
off with any new service we as it says in

70
00:03:38.117 --> 00:03:41.714
that bullet point,
establish measures of availability.

71
00:03:41.714 --> 00:03:44.650
What is availability really look like?

72
00:03:44.650 --> 00:03:48.932
And I mentioned in previous episodes that
we've got to be very specific about what

73
00:03:48.932 --> 00:03:50.490
availability really means.

74
00:03:50.490 --> 00:03:55.593
And then we go to identify one
availability jobs, sometimes, not all

75
00:03:55.593 --> 00:04:01.920
the time, sometimes availability drops and
it's not being reported as an incident.

76
00:04:03.000 --> 00:04:06.307
Think about when we have
mirrored service for instance.

77
00:04:06.307 --> 00:04:08.270
So if we have a mirrored server and

78
00:04:08.270 --> 00:04:12.810
one goes down then management
should pick that up.

79
00:04:12.810 --> 00:04:14.070
I should hope they pick that up.

80
00:04:14.070 --> 00:04:18.810
If the Event Management do not pick
the fact up that a server has failed,

81
00:04:18.810 --> 00:04:21.420
then we seriously need to
look at Event Management.

82
00:04:21.420 --> 00:04:24.020
So Event Management should pick that up.

83
00:04:24.020 --> 00:04:26.933
Incident Management may not pick that up.

84
00:04:26.933 --> 00:04:30.510
Event Management, I should hope,
will raise an incident automatically.

85
00:04:30.510 --> 00:04:32.116
But I don't expect our users to notice.

86
00:04:32.116 --> 00:04:35.620
So I don't expect anybody to have
called the service desk to say,

87
00:04:35.620 --> 00:04:39.825
hey one of our servers has failed because
they should be carrying on business as

88
00:04:39.825 --> 00:04:41.782
usual as per normal.

89
00:04:41.782 --> 00:04:43.550
But event management
should pick that up and

90
00:04:43.550 --> 00:04:49.160
availability management then needs to
work towards restoring that service.

91
00:04:49.160 --> 00:04:52.836
Because we have to make sure that our
service is available as per what's agreed

92
00:04:52.836 --> 00:04:53.792
with the business.

93
00:04:53.792 --> 00:04:57.249
And if the business say that we should
have two-mirrored service then we should

94
00:04:57.249 --> 00:04:59.300
have two-mirrored service.

95
00:04:59.300 --> 00:05:03.281
So we should be identifying that
unacceptable level of availability, and

96
00:05:03.281 --> 00:05:05.948
then we should be trying
to do something about it.

97
00:05:05.948 --> 00:05:11.524
And then on a regular basis, probably
through the service review meeting that we

98
00:05:11.524 --> 00:05:17.350
have between service level management and
their customers on a regular basis.

99
00:05:17.350 --> 00:05:21.273
We should be discussing levels of
availability with our customers,

100
00:05:21.273 --> 00:05:25.412
because we should perhaps be doing
something to improve availability.

101
00:05:25.412 --> 00:05:28.031
Or maybe we want to adjust the targets and

102
00:05:28.031 --> 00:05:32.201
the parameters that we have agreed
to deliver a service within.

103
00:05:32.201 --> 00:05:36.179
We always want to ensure that we're
relying to the needs of the organization,

104
00:05:36.179 --> 00:05:39.740
and that's what CSI is about,
Continual Service Improvement.

105
00:05:39.740 --> 00:05:44.136
Which is why that's brought in, because
every single process is subject to CSI.

106
00:05:44.136 --> 00:05:46.184
So what do we look for?

107
00:05:46.184 --> 00:05:52.270
Well, traditionally we look for percentage
availability or percentage unavailability.

108
00:05:52.270 --> 00:05:54.820
And we're looking for
how many failures we've had,

109
00:05:54.820 --> 00:05:59.130
what the duration of those failures were,
what the impact of those failures were.

110
00:06:00.130 --> 00:06:04.710
But now, more than ever before, we have to

111
00:06:04.710 --> 00:06:09.560
demonstrate the cost effectiveness or
efficiency in terms of finances.

112
00:06:09.560 --> 00:06:15.326
In other words, we have to demonstrate
that we really are the best choice for

113
00:06:15.326 --> 00:06:16.870
the organization.

114
00:06:16.870 --> 00:06:21.919
So we also have to look at the impact
of unavailability and that impact of

115
00:06:21.919 --> 00:06:27.630
unavailability can be articulated in
terms of user minutes that were down.

116
00:06:27.630 --> 00:06:32.180
It can be articulated in terms of
business transactions that were lost It

117
00:06:32.180 --> 00:06:35.324
can also be articulated in
terms of money as well.

118
00:06:35.324 --> 00:06:37.650
So how much money was lost?

119
00:06:38.870 --> 00:06:43.930
It's easy to articulate how much money
was lost if were in a sales environment,

120
00:06:43.930 --> 00:06:47.553
if we were in a sales environment
you can say that, okay,

121
00:06:47.553 --> 00:06:51.270
our payment processing system was down for
10 minutes.

122
00:06:51.270 --> 00:06:56.039
We normally take in 5,000 pounds or
$5,000 in 10 minutes,

123
00:06:56.039 --> 00:07:00.207
therefore, we've lost 5,000 pounds or
$5,000.

124
00:07:00.207 --> 00:07:05.320
And that's easy enough to do but quite
often it's not just about that because

125
00:07:05.320 --> 00:07:09.370
we've actually got 10 minutes worth of
people sitting around doing nothing.

126
00:07:09.370 --> 00:07:13.992
So it's not just loss of sales but
it's also user minutes as well.

127
00:07:13.992 --> 00:07:18.570
Well that's 10 minutes worth of salary
across the board of say 5,000 people.

128
00:07:18.570 --> 00:07:21.609
Now all of a sudden that $5,000 or

129
00:07:21.609 --> 00:07:27.710
5,000 pounds is suddenly insignificant
when you compare it to that.

130
00:07:27.710 --> 00:07:29.110
Cherokee, you had a question?

131
00:07:29.110 --> 00:07:33.200
>> Yeah, Jo sometimes when you're talking
about being able to identify that

132
00:07:33.200 --> 00:07:35.830
particular loss and
we look at hard numbers,

133
00:07:35.830 --> 00:07:40.880
we're looking at qualitative analysis and
we can easily attach a monetary figure.

134
00:07:40.880 --> 00:07:42.686
But sometimes that's not always the case,
right?

135
00:07:42.686 --> 00:07:46.976
Just sometimes we have qualitative
analysis that we need to think

136
00:07:46.976 --> 00:07:50.799
about when it comes to things
like brand reputation loss.

137
00:07:50.799 --> 00:07:52.690
What did that cost us as an organization?

138
00:07:52.690 --> 00:07:57.682
>> Well, we like to try and take the
qualitative and turn it into quantitive.

139
00:07:57.682 --> 00:07:59.696
Which is not that easy.

140
00:07:59.696 --> 00:08:04.368
It's not that easy to say it either.

141
00:08:04.368 --> 00:08:04.877
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] Right?

142
00:08:04.877 --> 00:08:05.867
>> We wanna take that,

143
00:08:05.867 --> 00:08:09.900
and we'll use things like satisfaction
surveys to help us do that.

144
00:08:09.900 --> 00:08:14.220
Obviously, that's not really
the bottom line, though.

145
00:08:14.220 --> 00:08:15.960
Let's think about where we are right now.

146
00:08:15.960 --> 00:08:20.660
Here we are in a TV studio, and we're
doing two things, really, simultaneously.

147
00:08:20.660 --> 00:08:25.400
We are streaming live via the Internet,
via our website,

148
00:08:25.400 --> 00:08:28.040
via our-
>> Even Facebook.

149
00:08:28.040 --> 00:08:28.910
>> Yep.

150
00:08:28.910 --> 00:08:32.390
Yes so
hey everybody that's out there right now.

151
00:08:32.390 --> 00:08:34.640
We're streaming live, but
we're also recording so

152
00:08:34.640 --> 00:08:37.700
that people can watch
this at a later date.

153
00:08:37.700 --> 00:08:42.480
So let's just say for instance, in
a previous episode we were talking about,

154
00:08:42.480 --> 00:08:44.850
I had a reward for
getting through a previous episode.

155
00:08:44.850 --> 00:08:46.000
This is terrible by the way.

156
00:08:46.000 --> 00:08:47.745
She makes me sound like such a bad person.

157
00:08:47.745 --> 00:08:49.190
>> [LAUGH]
>> This time it was cookies.

158
00:08:49.190 --> 00:08:51.398
Last time it was watching a blooper reel.

159
00:08:51.398 --> 00:08:53.015
>> [LAUGH]
>> Well,

160
00:08:53.015 --> 00:08:57.700
in a previous episode we mentioned that,
we talked about blooper reels, and

161
00:08:57.700 --> 00:08:59.910
I'll be the first one to make a mistake.

162
00:08:59.910 --> 00:09:00.490
I always am.

163
00:09:02.310 --> 00:09:04.300
What's the cost of downtime?

164

all of the aspects that

00:17:53.120 --> 00:17:54.320
about where do you think we went wrong,

311
00:17:54.320 --> 00:17:59.880
what do you think we can do for
next time, to prevent it happen again.

312
00:17:59.880 --> 00:18:02.300
And you want to pick out
sort of ok individuals.

313
00:18:02.300 --> 00:18:04.330
You might also want to
pick out customers and

314
00:18:04.330 --> 00:18:06.940
users as well,
because they may have a part in it.

315
00:18:06.940 --> 00:18:10.330
They'll certainly have a part
in identifying the scope or

00:18:10.330 --> 00:18:12.500
the impact of any particular failure.

317
00:18:14.030 --> 00:18:19.110

exactly what it was went wrong.

319
00:18:24.590 --> 00:18:28.160

320
00:18:29.330 --> 00:18:32.340
As long as you've got
the evidence to back it up.

321
00:18:32.340 --> 00:18:33.560
We think it was this, and

322
00:18:33.560 --> 00:18:38.000
this is the reason why we've drawn this
conclusion, and here's our evidence.

323
00:18:38.000 --> 00:18:43.172
And it's okay to use those words, as
long as, I say, you've got the evidence.

324
00:18:43.172 --> 00:18:46.260
>> And Jo,
you mentioned earlier about being open and

325
00:18:46.260 --> 00:18:47.830
being transparent with them.

00:18:47.830 --> 00:18:52.050

00:18:52.050 --> 00:18:55.700
monitoring utility to verify and
provide those facts for you.

328
00:18:55.700 --> 00:18:57.870
So as long as someone doesn't feel hurt or

329
00:18:57.870 --> 00:19:00.421
betrayed that you
are running those utilities.

330
00:19:00.421 --> 00:19:03.709
You've already predefined that and
say, hey look,

331
00:19:03.709 --> 00:19:07.530
there is a correlation between x and
y and this is y.

332
00:19:07.530 --> 00:19:11.010
Yes, this is not, as I said,
about apportioning blame,

333
00:19:11.010 --> 00:19:16.240
it's about identifying the ways to
improve our service availability.

334
00:19:16.240 --> 00:19:21.290
And if we can be assured,
as just regular people.

335
00:19:21.290 --> 00:19:24.650
If we can be assured
that whatever we say and

336
00:19:24.650 --> 00:19:27.575
whatever evidence that we give is
actually gonna be used in the right way,

337
00:19:27.575 --> 00:19:31.320
then we're likely to be open and
we're likely to be transparent about it.

338
00:19:31.320 --> 00:19:34.880
People become very protected,
they become very self protected

339
00:19:34.880 --> 00:19:38.490
if they feel threatened and
that's just a natural instinct.

340
00:19:38.490 --> 00:19:41.450
So we wanna make sure that
we're doing this to improve.

341
00:19:41.450 --> 00:19:44.240
We're not doing this to point fingers and
apportion blame.

342
00:19:44.240 --> 00:19:45.750
That's not what we're doing.

343
00:19:45.750 --> 00:19:49.478
And our recommendations are always
going to be based on fact.

344
00:19:49.478 --> 00:19:54.678
We recommend that the failure was,
because, and in fact we had a huge

345
00:19:54.678 --> 00:20:00.510
failure last week and it was because
a virus came into our organization.

346
00:20:00.510 --> 00:20:04.480
And because Jo opened
that particular email.

And she shouldn't have done-
>> [CROSSTALK] those sites, Jo.

00:20:06.099 --> 00:20:06.932
>> Yeah, I know, right.

349
00:20:06.932 --> 00:20:10.378
Yeah, Jo opened his email and

00:20:10.378 --> 00:20:12.061

I thought that it looked

00:20:14.624 --> 00:20:19.080
Or what was it Cherokee was

00:20:19.080 --> 00:20:21.095
People declaring undying love to me.

>> [LAUGH]

355

[LAUGH] I open the email, and

356
00:20:28.605 --> 00:20:33.123
Service failure analysis is not about
apportioning fingers and saying, okay Jo,

it's time to go, bye.

358
00:20:34.423 --> 00:20:35.748
This is about saying, okay,

360

>> Provide that in user training for Jo.

361

>> Maybe yeah, maybe I need training or

>> There you go.

364
00:20:49.130 --> 00:20:54.047
Perhaps if we had upgraded our virus
detection when we were advised to do so

00:20:54.047 --> 00:20:58.586

have got us in to this position.

366
00:20:58.586 --> 00:20:59.168
>> True.

367
00:20:59.168 --> 00:21:02.305
>> But because we decided to
put it off for an extra week,

368
00:21:02.305 --> 00:21:05.590
because now wasn't a convenient time.

369
00:21:05.590 --> 00:21:06.920
And that's our recommendation.

370
00:21:06.920 --> 00:21:10.749
Our recommendation in that instance for
the future would be, when we get an email

371
00:21:10.749 --> 00:21:14.653
from the suppliers telling us we need to
upgrade virus protection, let's do it.

372
00:21:14.653 --> 00:21:17.943
[LAUGH] And
that could be something simple like that,

373
00:21:17.943 --> 00:21:21.622
that's what we're looking for
in our recommendations.

374
00:21:21.622 --> 00:21:27.200
And so the final report is what
we then present to our sponsors.

375
00:21:27.200 --> 00:21:31.170
A sponsor is somebody who is
a guiding stakeholder, so

376
00:21:31.170 --> 00:21:35.220
somebody like a service owner or
maybe even the customer, etc.

377
00:21:35.220 --> 00:21:38.130
Because what we need to show
that there has been a loss or

378
00:21:38.130 --> 00:21:41.180
that we need to show the impact
of a particular failure.

379
00:21:41.180 --> 00:21:44.260
Then that sponsor's gonna be
somebody who's interested

380
00:21:44.260 --> 00:21:49.710
In what that failure was and what the
impact was and therefore is going to be

381
00:21:49.710 --> 00:21:53.970
eager to do something about it and
to prevent it happening again.

382
00:21:54.970 --> 00:21:57.830
And that validation is
really just a comparison,

383
00:21:57.830 --> 00:22:02.170
as we've said, from the actual FSA itself,

384
00:22:02.170 --> 00:22:06.880
that Service Failure Analysis,
against our initial perspectives.

385
00:22:06.880 --> 00:22:09.752
So you know what, before we did
this Service Failure Analysis,

386
00:22:09.752 --> 00:22:11.410
it looked like John was the culprit.

387
00:22:11.410 --> 00:22:15.936
It looked like I was the one that opened
the email with the attachment, and

388
00:22:15.936 --> 00:22:19.660
I was the reason why we lost our
infrastructure for two days.

389
00:22:19.660 --> 00:22:25.006
When in fact, the reason why we lost our
infrastructure for two days was because we

390
00:22:25.006 --> 00:22:31.020
ignored data email from our supplier that
said update our virus protection service.

391
00:22:31.020 --> 00:22:34.450
So why do we do then the service failure
analyses, as I've already said it's

392
00:22:34.450 --> 00:22:37.890
not about pointing fingers, and
it's not about apportioning blame.

393
00:22:37.890 --> 00:22:42.183
It's just about identifying,
well that's proactive problem management,

394
00:22:42.183 --> 00:22:45.176
it's about identifying why
Something happened, and

395
00:22:45.176 --> 00:22:49.874
to detail recommendations about what we'd
do to prevent it happening in the future.

396
00:22:49.874 --> 00:22:53.520
What we want to do is
enhance availability.

397
00:22:53.520 --> 00:22:56.701
We wanna make sure that our services
are available and we want to.

398
00:22:56.701 --> 00:23:00.583
It says demonstrate a visible
commitment to improve, but

399
00:23:00.583 --> 00:23:04.320
we wanna really prevent
any impact in the future.

400
00:23:04.320 --> 00:23:05.810
That's what we want to do.

401
00:23:05.810 --> 00:23:11.200
It's part of a health check of our
processes and also our services as well.

402
00:23:11.200 --> 00:23:13.430
We want to prevent it happening again.

403
00:23:13.430 --> 00:23:16.800
So many times there are failures.

404
00:23:16.800 --> 00:23:18.950
And we address what's failed.

405
00:23:18.950 --> 00:23:22.130
And then we never go back to analyze
how we can prevent it happening

406
00:23:22.130 --> 00:23:22.850
again in the future.

407
00:23:24.010 --> 00:23:26.700
So, we know that we got
a virus on our network.

408
00:23:26.700 --> 00:23:30.390
And we got a virus on the network
because I opened an attachment that I

409
00:23:30.390 --> 00:23:31.450
shouldn't have done.

410
00:23:31.450 --> 00:23:34.390
So we know what caused the failure, okay?

411
00:23:34.390 --> 00:23:36.620
And what caused the failure
on the network was me.

412
00:23:36.620 --> 00:23:38.910
I was opening up attachments.

413
00:23:38.910 --> 00:23:39.620
But actually,

414
00:23:39.620 --> 00:23:45.010
the real root cause of this was because
we fail to update our virus protection.

415
00:23:46.450 --> 00:23:49.090
And this is what service
failure analysis does.

416
00:23:49.090 --> 00:23:53.460
You see,
problem management ill just identify me

417
00:23:53.460 --> 00:23:55.410
as being the root cause of that incident.

418
00:23:55.410 --> 00:23:58.950
Problem management will say, Joe was
the one that caused this because Joe

419
00:23:58.950 --> 00:24:02.410
opened up the e-mail, and
that e-mail had an attachment in it.

420
00:24:02.410 --> 00:24:06.600
Whereas Service Failure Analysis goes
one level further and says okay, and

421
00:24:06.600 --> 00:24:09.000
how was you able to do that?

422
00:24:10.290 --> 00:24:14.330
So Service Failure Analysis is
actually just as beneficial,

423
00:24:14.330 --> 00:24:16.650
if not more beneficial.

424
00:24:16.650 --> 00:24:20.620
Problem management addresses
the root cause and says okay,

425
00:24:20.620 --> 00:24:21.750
let's fix the root cause.

426
00:24:21.750 --> 00:24:27.060
Let's find out why something went wrong
and let's Fix that whereas availability

427
00:24:27.060 --> 00:24:32.558
management says, okay, let's prevent the
root cause from happening in the future.

428
00:24:32.558 --> 00:24:38.810
So Service Failure Analysis,
well, what I want you to do now

429
00:24:38.810 --> 00:24:44.840
is I want you to go back over this
particular session and I would like you

to refer to your Downloadable material,
and in your downloadable material you

431

have a exercise on service value
analysis in relation to that case study.

432
00:24:56.670 --> 00:25:00.760
What I'd like you to do is I would like
you to spend at this point in time before

00:25:00.760 --> 00:25:05.530
we move further into proactive activities
availability management in our next

434
00:25:05.530 --> 00:25:09.640
episode I'd like you to spend about
an hour looking at your case study and

435
00:25:09.640 --> 00:25:14.700

on service value analysis.

436
00:25:14.700 --> 00:25:18.150
Now, as I say at the end

00:25:18.150 --> 00:25:22.020
certainly where I've asked you to go
away and look a something again or

00:25:22.020 --> 00:25:25.700
perhaps perform an exercise,

00:25:25.700 --> 00:25:29.040
So please feel free to chat to us,

440
00:25:29.040 --> 00:25:32.930
highlight any concerns that you may have,
any questions that you may have, and

00:25:32.930 --> 00:25:36.750
we will do our best to get back to
you as quickly as we possibly can.

442
00:25:36.750 --> 00:25:38.170
>> All right, thank you for your time, Jo.

443
00:25:38.170 --> 00:25:42.510
Thank you for explaining those

steps that we need to take.

00:25:43.600 --> 00:25:45.420
Especially when we're
going to dive deep and

00:25:45.420 --> 00:25:49.140
perform the particular service
failure analysis there.

00:25:49.140 --> 00:25:51.230
So, thank you, and
thank you for joining us.

448
00:25:51.230 --> 00:25:53.302
But for this show,

00:25:53.302 --> 00:25:55.023
Remember, I've been your host,
Cherokee Boose.

00:25:55.023 --> 00:25:55.805
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

00:25:55.805 --> 00:25:57.688

episodes.description: In this show, the ladies shift gears and move from reactive to proactive methods of availability management. They explain the importance of  identifying Vital Business Functions (VBFs) and how to integrate availability from the onset. Jo explains the how the maturity level of an organization can help increase availability. She also encorages not to just design for availability but also recovery.

So let's first start off with,

00:01:06.245 --> 00:01:08.930

>> Kind of like our incident
life cycle that we had seen?

>> Yeah.
>> From beginning to end there, so

yeah, we're kind of circling back around.

30

31

60

00:03:27.840 --> 00:03:30.450

69
00:03:33.780 --> 00:03:38.167

70

71
00:03:42.120 --> 00:03:46.198
Remember, we are delivering value to
the organization, to the business.

72
00:03:46.198 --> 00:03:49.250

they're going to

74
00:03:53.820 --> 00:03:56.230
So really we have to
work with the business,

75
00:03:56.230 --> 00:03:59.240

to agree on this.

76
00:04:00.450 --> 00:04:04.930
If we wanted, in IT we like to have

00:04:04.930 --> 00:04:08.340
we want to deliver the best
service to the organization.

78

to have resilience options in for

79
00:04:13.390 --> 00:04:16.360

there was on the network.

80
00:04:16.360 --> 00:04:19.856
Or maybe we even wanted it to
have a failover network, well,

81
00:04:19.856 --> 00:04:21.510
how much would that cost us?

82
00:04:22.800 --> 00:04:28.690
We would have to go back to the business

83
00:04:28.690 --> 00:04:30.580
We need to understand what

84
00:04:30.580 --> 00:04:35.380
Do they really need that level of

00:31:04.700 --> 00:31:08.640

secure that they could possibly be.

548

549

552

553

It wasn't until that footage was shown

554
00:31:27.900 --> 00:31:30.770
yes, they did have a vulnerability there.

Because any breach of security will

558

available to those that should

559
00:31:49.070 --> 00:31:54.150

to those that shouldn't have access.

560
00:31:55.440 --> 00:31:58.055
So security, yeah,
we've all gotta work together this.

561
00:31:58.055 --> 00:32:01.240
These warranty processes
have got to work together.

562

563

And we're going to look a little
bit more in our next episode at

564
00:32:07.610 --> 00:32:09.400
the specific techniques.

565

But things like component failure
impact analysis, for instance.

566
00:32:12.520 --> 00:32:18.220
Which these techniques we used to try and
predict the impact on an IT service.

567
00:32:18.220 --> 00:32:21.870
And we use these techniques to predict
the impact on our new services and

568
00:32:21.870 --> 00:32:26.170
on changes to existing services,
and on a regular basis.

569

So in our next episode, we're gonna
take a little bit more of an in-depth

570
00:32:31.110 --> 00:32:36.290
look in these techniques that we use for
PROACTIVE Availability Management.

the difference between proactive and

reactive availability management, and

How are we doing with

579

>> [LAUGH]

we're gonna look at component failure

factors, and yeah, we've got-

down memory lane and-

go with availability management,

episodes.description: In this show, Cherokee and Jo  continue discussing proactive availability management. First Jo shares an examples how to perform component and advanced component failure analysis, single point of failure analysis modeling/simulation/load testing and more! Jo encourages adopting a "no-blame" approach and offers other suggestions such as M_o_R (Management of Risk) ti integrate in your availability management.

Yeah,

18

19

Right now, in this particular episode, we
are going to be spending a little bit more

20
00:00:44.756 --> 00:00:48.465
time looking at the proactive
sides to availability management.

21
00:00:48.465 --> 00:00:51.520
We've had quite a few episodes
looking at the reactive side.

22
00:00:51.520 --> 00:00:55.016
We've looked at one episode
on proactive techniques.

23
00:00:55.016 --> 00:00:55.552
And now,

24
00:00:55.552 --> 00:01:00.186
we're going to look a little bit further
at component failure impact analysis and

25
00:01:00.186 --> 00:01:04.433
actually preparing for failure,
because we need to be able to predict it.

26
00:01:04.433 --> 00:01:05.050
>> That's right.

27
00:01:05.050 --> 00:01:09.580
And when we're talking about components
with hardware, with moving components,

28
00:01:09.580 --> 00:01:13.920
mechanic devices, eventually,
there's wear and tear on these devices.

29
00:01:13.920 --> 00:01:15.164
We need to be prepared for that.

30
00:01:15.164 --> 00:01:17.193
>> Bit like my knees, really.

31
00:01:17.193 --> 00:01:20.467
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] Anyway,

32
00:01:20.467 --> 00:01:24.018
let's take a look at
availability management then and

33
00:01:24.018 --> 00:01:28.892
let's take a look at planning for
our moveable components, not my knees.

34
00:01:28.892 --> 00:01:34.362
I looked at this particular, how should I
say, the theory in our last episode and

35
00:01:34.362 --> 00:01:37.909
I just want to explore this or
remind you about this.

36
00:01:39.210 --> 00:01:43.352
Right now right at the very start,
remember that we are either designing for

37
00:01:43.352 --> 00:01:46.341
availability or
that we're designing for recovery.

38
00:01:46.341 --> 00:01:50.540
If you remember availability was all
about keeping things up and running.

39
00:01:50.540 --> 00:01:53.560
Whereas recovery is acknowledging
that things are going to fail and

40
00:01:53.560 --> 00:01:56.250
picking up the pieces after they failed.

41
00:01:56.250 --> 00:02:01.040
So do we want to design for What you might
consider to be continuous availability.

42
00:02:01.040 --> 00:02:03.937
In other words trying to
prevent something from failing,

43
00:02:03.937 --> 00:02:05.599
or do you want to allow it to fail?

44
00:02:05.599 --> 00:02:08.530
And then just pick up the pieces
really quickly afterwards.

45
00:02:08.530 --> 00:02:11.832
So this ties in very closely
with service continuity,

46
00:02:11.832 --> 00:02:14.570
as well one of our other
warranty processes.

47
00:02:14.570 --> 00:02:16.858
Why do we differentiate between the two?

48
00:02:16.858 --> 00:02:20.843
Well because there's significant
difference in cost in the two.

49
00:02:20.843 --> 00:02:22.907
And so we have to make decisions very,

50
00:02:22.907 --> 00:02:25.229
very early on as to what
we are going to do and

51
00:02:25.229 --> 00:02:29.205
we will use risk management techniques
to help us make those decisions.

52
00:02:29.205 --> 00:02:32.481
But lets take a look at
a technique that we use quiet

53
00:02:32.481 --> 00:02:36.931
extensively in availability
management food planning purposes.

54
00:02:36.931 --> 00:02:41.460
And it is what we call component
failure impact analysis.

55
00:02:41.460 --> 00:02:44.235
Now you've got a grid
on the left hand side,

56
00:02:44.235 --> 00:02:47.910
what I like to do with component
failure impact analysis,

57
00:02:47.910 --> 00:02:53.040
I have to say is that I like to look at
this from our network topology diagram.

58
00:02:53.040 --> 00:02:56.715
So give me a network topology
diagram which I guess is a very,

59
00:02:56.715 --> 00:03:00.331
very basic form in the diagram
to the right, in the middle.

60
00:03:00.331 --> 00:03:05.964
And then we look at each individual
component and we ask the question,

61
00:03:05.964 --> 00:03:11.229
if that component fails,
what will the impact to the service be?

62
00:03:11.229 --> 00:03:14.210
This is why we call it component
failure impact analysis really.

63
00:03:14.210 --> 00:03:16.649
I know it sounds as though
it's fairly straight forward.

64
00:03:17.750 --> 00:03:20.972
So in this particular example,
and this is just an example,

65
00:03:20.972 --> 00:03:25.395
you'll see here that in the greater they
go listed on the right hand side, they've

66
00:03:25.395 --> 00:03:29.270
put in an X where a component failure
will bring down the entire service.

67
00:03:29.270 --> 00:03:33.528
And A where there is redundancy or
resilient option, and

68
00:03:33.528 --> 00:03:38.772
an M where it needs manual intervention
to get to at redundant option.

69
00:03:38.772 --> 00:03:41.824
And in this particular diagram,
the next one,

70
00:03:41.824 --> 00:03:45.730
well this is an advance component
failure impact analysis.

71
00:03:45.730 --> 00:03:51.340
Because this looks at, wow, look we've
got a probability of failure here.

72
00:03:51.340 --> 00:03:55.361
So what's the probability that
this could actually fail?

73
00:03:55.361 --> 00:03:58.960
And in CI,
remember that's a Configuration Item.

74
00:03:58.960 --> 00:04:01.750
This CI is gonna weight in at 100%.

75
00:04:01.750 --> 00:04:04.940
In other words,
if it fails it's definitely going to bring

76
00:04:04.940 --> 00:04:06.330
the service down.

77
00:04:06.330 --> 00:04:10.639
And the likelihood of failure is a red.

78
00:04:10.639 --> 00:04:12.614
So a likelihood of failure,

79
00:04:12.614 --> 00:04:17.319
well what that actually means is
that it's probably going to fail.

80
00:04:17.319 --> 00:04:20.000
Cuz it's red, that's worrying.

81
00:04:20.000 --> 00:04:23.458
So we're gonna have recovery
procedures in place.

82
00:04:23.458 --> 00:04:26.695
Because in this instance,
then if it's going to fail, well,

83
00:04:26.695 --> 00:04:29.950
we need to do something about it,
we need to pick up the pieces.

84
00:04:29.950 --> 00:04:32.868
And so
we talk about recovery procedures or

85
00:04:32.868 --> 00:04:36.279
we may talk about resilience
procedures as well.

86
00:04:36.279 --> 00:04:40.097
Now, the actual wording in this
particular diagram, I wouldn't say

87
00:04:40.097 --> 00:04:45.300
is very explicit but you certainly get
the gist of what it is we're trying to do.

88
00:04:45.300 --> 00:04:49.660
We're taking what happened in the last
diagram, which is this one here.

89
00:04:49.660 --> 00:04:53.300
And instead of just saying, hey, look
there's a manual intervention here that

90
00:04:54.970 --> 00:04:58.965
we can use to switch over
to in case of a failure.

91
00:04:58.965 --> 00:05:03.235
What we're actually saying here is, look,
this is which component is more important.

92
00:05:03.235 --> 00:05:07.215
And therefore, this is where we need
to consider recovery procedures or

93
00:05:07.215 --> 00:05:08.995
redundancy procedures.

94
00:05:08.995 --> 00:05:12.785
So here, in this particular diagram,
we're just looking at the component.

95
00:05:12.785 --> 00:05:15.574
And there's nobody that's actually
given any weight into any one

96
00:05:15.574 --> 00:05:16.526
of these components.

97
00:05:16.526 --> 00:05:20.411
So at no point in time have we
outlined the VBF, as we call it,

98
00:05:20.411 --> 00:05:22.930
that vital business function.

99
00:05:22.930 --> 00:05:26.840
We'd never outlined the priority
of any service or any component.

100
00:05:26.840 --> 00:05:29.639
In this one here,
we're giving it a weighting.

101
00:05:29.639 --> 00:05:33.434
And that's exactly what it does,
it outlines that priority,

102
00:05:33.434 --> 00:05:36.310
the importance of that
particular component.

103
00:05:37.880 --> 00:05:43.751
Here what we have, then, is another
one of our proactive techniques and

104
00:05:43.751 --> 00:05:47.134
this is what we call fault tree analysis.

105
00:05:47.134 --> 00:05:51.749
Now where as the previous one looked at
the component failure impact analysis

106
00:05:51.749 --> 00:05:54.802
looked very much at
the network topology and said,

107
00:05:54.802 --> 00:05:57.578
if I take out this
component what will happen?

108
00:05:57.578 --> 00:06:02.431
This one here says okay then
let's take a look at what would

109
00:06:02.431 --> 00:06:06.530
happen that could cause a service to fail.

110
00:06:06.530 --> 00:06:10.938
So let's look at what we call basic
events, then resulting events, and

111
00:06:10.938 --> 00:06:13.483
conditional events and trigger events.

112
00:06:13.483 --> 00:06:18.796
So we'll use things like and, and
or, or here so in this case then,

113
00:06:18.796 --> 00:06:25.640
if a service is down it stop people in
logging in that's the inhibiting part.

114
00:06:25.640 --> 00:06:28.548
We have to consider what
are normal service hours are.

115
00:06:28.548 --> 00:06:31.890
But if the service is there it's
because the system is down.

116
00:06:31.890 --> 00:06:36.590
And if the system is down it's
because in this where OR is.

117
00:06:36.590 --> 00:06:40.701
Either the server is down or the
application's down or the network's down.

118
00:06:40.701 --> 00:06:42.850
And let's follow that network tree down.

119
00:06:42.850 --> 00:06:48.290
And if the server is down, it's because
either the primary line is down and,

120
00:06:48.290 --> 00:06:52.270
this one would be an and, and
the failover is down as well.

121
00:06:52.270 --> 00:06:55.870
Because if the network is down,
then both of these have to be down.

122
00:06:55.870 --> 00:07:02.030
So this one's looking at, as we say here,
the Boolean functions of OR and IF etc.

123
00:07:02.030 --> 00:07:06.193
So this is looking at what will
take this server down, and

124
00:07:06.193 --> 00:07:09.937
that's what your fault
tree analysis looks like.

125
00:07:09.937 --> 00:07:11.320
Then we also have modeling.

126
00:07:12.640 --> 00:07:15.681
It says here that this is known
as simulation or load testing,

127
00:07:15.681 --> 00:07:17.149
I like to call this, what if?

128
00:07:17.149 --> 00:07:20.118
Or let's pretend,
this is my modeling I like,

129
00:07:20.118 --> 00:07:25.480
let's pretend that we've added 500
additional users onto our infrastructure.

130
00:07:25.480 --> 00:07:29.630
What will our infrastructure do,
how will it react if we do that.

131
00:07:29.630 --> 00:07:33.778
Let's pretend that we
are taking away 500 users.

132
00:07:33.778 --> 00:07:36.830
Let's pretend we've added
in that new service and

133
00:07:36.830 --> 00:07:41.580
let's look to see how our
infrastructure as whole will perform.

134
00:07:41.580 --> 00:07:43.639
So don't call me on that one, okay?

135
00:07:43.639 --> 00:07:47.231
That's not the official term but
that's what I like to call moderate.

136
00:07:47.231 --> 00:07:52.805
Let's pretend what if, a simulation or
low testing for instance just to assess

137
00:07:52.805 --> 00:07:59.270
whether Any particular component will
actually meet its required functionality.

138
00:07:59.270 --> 00:08:01.930
Modeling is a very difficult thing to do.

139
00:08:01.930 --> 00:08:06.630
Because modeling will, in some respects,
when we're talking about modeling for

140
00:08:06.630 --> 00:08:08.700
data sizing for instance,

141
00:08:08.700 --> 00:08:12.840
application sizing You're gonna be
doing this on maybe a test server.

142
00:08:12.840 --> 00:08:17.650
Well your test server will not mimic
your live environment exactly, so

143
00:08:17.650 --> 00:08:19.360
that's gonna be quite challenging.

144
00:08:19.360 --> 00:08:22.420
You may bring in a supplier to
help you with modeling, and

145
00:08:22.420 --> 00:08:26.860
a supplier will tell you how
a particular service, an application,

146
00:08:26.860 --> 00:08:30.439
has performed in their
other customer sites.

147
00:08:32.300 --> 00:08:36.428
But all you're going to get a customer
site to another customer site that's

148
00:08:36.428 --> 00:08:37.599
identical to yours.

149
00:08:37.599 --> 00:08:41.782
You might even use reference sites and
you might try and find someone yourself or

150
00:08:41.782 --> 00:08:44.500
again on the recommendation
of the supplier.

151
00:08:44.500 --> 00:08:47.230
Well, you will go and
you will ask pertinent questions and

152
00:08:47.230 --> 00:08:51.880
you'll ask them how a particular component
performs its certain functions or

153
00:08:51.880 --> 00:08:53.720
in certain conditions.

154
00:08:53.720 --> 00:08:56.590
Again, it's very, very difficult.

155
00:08:56.590 --> 00:09:00.770
Modeling is fantastic as a technique,
but it's something that's very,

156
00:09:00.770 --> 00:09:06.120
very difficult to predict because no
two environments are exactly the same.

157
00:09:06.120 --> 00:09:10.740
So we can use it to determine performance
and to forecast availability.

158
00:09:10.740 --> 00:09:15.580
However it's very, very difficult
to do because it's very difficult

159
00:09:15.580 --> 00:09:19.860
to get an environment that's exactly
the same as your environment.

160
00:09:19.860 --> 00:09:23.587
So sometimes we just choose
to do modeling theoretically,

161
00:09:23.587 --> 00:09:26.800
which is why I mention
a spreadsheet will suffice.

162
00:09:26.800 --> 00:09:31.695
And some tools will offer a modeling
capability, but in a lot of instances when

163
00:09:31.695 --> 00:09:36.800
we're talking about these tools,
this capability is really theoretical.

164
00:09:36.800 --> 00:09:41.821
This capability is not by actually testing
in the live environment because you

165
00:09:41.821 --> 00:09:47.083
don't have your live environment available
for you to perform that modeling in.

166
00:09:47.083 --> 00:09:50.027
Because then well,
you're in the live environment so

167
00:09:50.027 --> 00:09:52.720
you're not modeling,
if you get my drift there.

168
00:09:54.390 --> 00:09:57.910
Part of this is all about risk analysis.

169
00:09:57.910 --> 00:09:59.950
And I've mentioned this
in previous episodes.

170
00:09:59.950 --> 00:10:02.810
And I know that here we
are in proactive availability

171
00:10:02.810 --> 00:10:06.848
management where we're planning for
the availability of our services.

172
00:10:06.848 --> 00:10:11.988
And so availability management in
a nutshell Its role is to detect points

173
00:10:11.988 --> 00:10:17.380
of failure and then to decide what
to do about those points of failure.

174
00:10:17.380 --> 00:10:24.920
So the component failure impact analysis,
or CFIA, as we call it.

175
00:10:24.920 --> 00:10:28.710
That will allow us to detect
the impact if a component fails.

176
00:10:29.990 --> 00:10:35.540
Now, risk analysis will come along and
will help us decide what to do about it,

177
00:10:35.540 --> 00:10:40.170
because we will look at our components,
these are our assets.

178
00:10:40.170 --> 00:10:44.310
And then we'll look at the failures that
could happen, these are our threats.

179
00:10:44.310 --> 00:10:47.100
So maybe a security breach is a failure.

180
00:10:47.100 --> 00:10:48.900
And then we'll look at the vulnerability.

181
00:10:48.900 --> 00:10:54.490
And the vulnerability is actually what
we would consider to be the likelihood,

182
00:10:54.490 --> 00:10:57.920
the likelihood of that failure occurring.

183
00:10:59.050 --> 00:11:02.320
And then by understanding
the likelihood of that failure,

184
00:11:02.320 --> 00:11:06.660
that allows us to then
allocate a risk score

185
00:11:06.660 --> 00:11:11.210
based on the severity of the impact and
the likelihood of it failing.

186
00:11:11.210 --> 00:11:14.291
And that then allows us to
decide on counter measures.

187
00:11:14.291 --> 00:11:20.360
Now, there is no in terms ITIL and
in terms of Management.

188
00:11:20.360 --> 00:11:24.960
There is no defined way of
performing risk management.

189
00:11:24.960 --> 00:11:27.273
We'll tell you that you have
to perform risk management.

190
00:11:27.273 --> 00:11:31.252
And there are other ways of performing
risk management, such as M_o_R,

191
00:11:31.252 --> 00:11:33.390
which is management of risk.

192
00:11:33.390 --> 00:11:36.450
Now M_o_R is a sister publication to ITIL.

193
00:11:36.450 --> 00:11:39.550
It comes out of the AXELOS background.

194
00:11:39.550 --> 00:11:45.920
It came out of the OGC originally, the
Office of Government Commerce in the UK.

195
00:11:45.920 --> 00:11:48.090
And it is just a technique for
managing risk,

196
00:11:48.090 --> 00:11:52.780
but there are lots more of
the frameworks to managing risks.

197
00:11:52.780 --> 00:11:53.440
>> Most definitely.

198
00:11:53.440 --> 00:11:57.953
I've seen some risk matrices that are very
basic, and then some that are extremely

199
00:11:57.953 --> 00:12:02.159
difficult to even understand what
information you're getting out of them.

200
00:12:02.159 --> 00:12:06.410
But it really just depends on how
detailed that information needs to be.

201
00:12:06.410 --> 00:12:11.660
>> And we'll always tell you, think of
the CSI guiding principles within ITIL,

202
00:12:11.660 --> 00:12:14.360
and one of our first guiding
principles is keep it simple.

203
00:12:14.360 --> 00:12:18.090
And so we will tell you quite
happily to start off simple,

204
00:12:18.090 --> 00:12:21.150
to start off very very basic as you were.

205
00:12:21.150 --> 00:12:26.310
So use something like MOR, and
MOR is this particular diagram here

206
00:12:26.310 --> 00:12:29.240
Just use this and
just look at that and say, okay.

207
00:12:29.240 --> 00:12:33.160
From a very simplistic level let's list
down our components or our assets.

208
00:12:33.160 --> 00:12:35.700
Let's list down what could happen and

209
00:12:35.700 --> 00:12:39.790
then how likely are each
of those threats to happen.

210
00:12:39.790 --> 00:12:41.510
And then we can work out a risk matrix.

211
00:12:41.510 --> 00:12:46.367
Now what we'll tell you in MOR
is that we will give our assets.

212
00:12:46.367 --> 00:12:47.839
On a scale of one to ten,

213
00:12:47.839 --> 00:12:52.630
we'll give them a score based on
their importance to the organization.

214
00:12:52.630 --> 00:12:59.010
We also give our threats a score as well,
based on their impact.

215
00:12:59.010 --> 00:13:02.728
And then we will give the vulnerabilities
a score of one to ten based on their

216
00:13:02.728 --> 00:13:03.440
likelihood.

217
00:13:03.440 --> 00:13:05.540
And then we can use that.

218
00:13:05.540 --> 00:13:09.380
We combine those scores and we can
use that to create our risk register.

219
00:13:09.380 --> 00:13:13.320
And that's really essentially how
management of risk works in a nutshell.

220
00:13:13.320 --> 00:13:15.190
And we'll tell you, keep it simple.

221
00:13:15.190 --> 00:13:16.660
Really do keep it simple.

222
00:13:16.660 --> 00:13:19.210
It should be an approach
to risk management, so

223
00:13:19.210 --> 00:13:21.720
somebody should be
nominated to do that but

224
00:13:21.720 --> 00:13:25.970
then at the same time We're talking
about designing an infrastructure.

225
00:13:25.970 --> 00:13:28.140
We're talking about designing a service.

226
00:13:28.140 --> 00:13:31.440
The only people that can really
do this are the technical people,

227
00:13:31.440 --> 00:13:34.990
the project team that are actually
designing the service.

228
00:13:34.990 --> 00:13:39.600
Whilst it says here, nominate the senior
management as risk owners, yes,

229
00:13:39.600 --> 00:13:40.617
that's great.

230
00:13:40.617 --> 00:13:44.457
But nevertheless, the people that
are identifying risk and are doing

231
00:13:44.457 --> 00:13:49.077
the risk analysis of the people that are
working with these individual components,

232
00:13:49.077 --> 00:13:53.720
senior management are not gonna understand
necessarily how each component works.

233
00:13:53.720 --> 00:13:57.378
And they normally aren't going to
understand the vulnerabilities,

234
00:13:57.378 --> 00:14:00.670
which is why we need to have some
form of recognized technique.

235
00:14:02.160 --> 00:14:06.060
But I do really like and I have mentioned
this in a number of occasions on previous

236
00:14:06.060 --> 00:14:10.190
episodes, about this null blame approach,
about the fact that we are not using this

237
00:14:10.190 --> 00:14:14.730
to point fingers or to highlight where
somebody is really not doing their job.

238
00:14:14.730 --> 00:14:17.120
We're doing this to highlight
other vulnerabilities and

239
00:14:17.120 --> 00:14:21.250
to ensure that we actually
do something about that,

240
00:14:21.250 --> 00:14:25.480
that we're considerate even if the
decision that we make is to do nothing.

241
00:14:25.480 --> 00:14:27.480
And there is nothing wrong
with making that decision,

242
00:14:27.480 --> 00:14:29.600
do nothing is definitely an option.

243
00:14:31.100 --> 00:14:34.280
So what else do we do then
in availability management?

244
00:14:34.280 --> 00:14:36.483
Because it strikes me
that we are doing a lot.

245
00:14:36.483 --> 00:14:40.040
Well what about planned
preventative maintenance.

246
00:14:42.940 --> 00:14:45.938
People like to avoid it, okay, I avoid it.

247
00:14:45.938 --> 00:14:49.598
I got a Windows machine at home and
every now and then it will tell me, and

248
00:14:49.598 --> 00:14:53.809
in fact this happens in all operating
systems, there's a new update available,

249
00:14:53.809 --> 00:14:55.350
do you want to install it now?

250
00:14:55.350 --> 00:14:58.548
And invariably my response
is absolutely not.

251
00:14:58.548 --> 00:15:00.547
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] What is this, no,

252
00:15:00.547 --> 00:15:02.324
I don't want to do that.

253
00:15:02.324 --> 00:15:03.530
>> I'm busy, leave me alone.

254
00:15:03.530 --> 00:15:05.640
>> Right, and you put it off,
and you put it off, and

255
00:15:05.640 --> 00:15:08.250
you put it off,
because you don't want to do it.

256
00:15:08.250 --> 00:15:12.110
We do the same in our
work environment too.

257
00:15:12.110 --> 00:15:13.730
We don't want to do that right now.

258
00:15:13.730 --> 00:15:16.550
Or, I haven't got time right now,
I'm busy.

259
00:15:16.550 --> 00:15:20.660
Yeah, there's always 101 different
reasons why we don't perform

260
00:15:20.660 --> 00:15:23.820
preventative maintenance or
any plans maintenance.

261
00:15:23.820 --> 00:15:28.900
And its generally something to do will
cost or time, or maybe even skills.

262
00:15:28.900 --> 00:15:31.568
I don't want to go on that
training just yet, so

263
00:15:31.568 --> 00:15:35.128
therefore I'm not going to
implement this particular patch.

264
00:15:35.128 --> 00:15:38.028
Cuz it means that I've got to
learn something new and I haven't

265
00:15:38.028 --> 00:15:41.490
got a time cuz I'm busy delivering
training, to actually take training.

266
00:15:42.540 --> 00:15:43.729
Now being in that position before.

267
00:15:43.729 --> 00:15:45.149
>> True story.

268
00:15:45.149 --> 00:15:45.786
>> [LAUGH]
>> Yeah, right.

269
00:15:45.786 --> 00:15:47.860
>> [LAUGH]
>> It's a position we're in all the time.

270
00:15:47.860 --> 00:15:52.838
Too busy giving training to
actually do any training ourselves.

271
00:15:52.838 --> 00:15:57.480
It's a dilemma that in organizations
we're faced with on a daily basis.

272
00:15:57.480 --> 00:16:02.055
So we will tell you that as part of your
availability plan you have to consider

273
00:16:02.055 --> 00:16:03.847
preventative maintenance.

274
00:16:03.847 --> 00:16:07.230
And what about in 24 hour
operational environment?

275
00:16:07.230 --> 00:16:10.183
Where we're running our
organization 24 hours and

276
00:16:10.183 --> 00:16:12.289
we have to ensure high availability.

277
00:16:12.289 --> 00:16:13.520
>> That's exactly what I was thinking.

278
00:16:13.520 --> 00:16:17.571
They're like hey, I gotta take this
machine down, because of maintenance.

279
00:16:17.571 --> 00:16:20.235
>> Right, and
whoever will allow you to do that?

280
00:16:20.235 --> 00:16:22.190
>> [LAUGH]
>> It's really difficult, and

281
00:16:22.190 --> 00:16:26.130
the thing is, it tells you in
these last two bullet points,

282
00:16:26.130 --> 00:16:28.310
it's easy to achieve
with today's technology.

283
00:16:28.310 --> 00:16:33.040
And there are ways of ensuring that
the service is up and running, but

284
00:16:33.040 --> 00:16:33.790
it's not cheap.

285
00:16:35.310 --> 00:16:40.715
If you're going to maintain 24 by 7
operations and you want to have so

286
00:16:40.715 --> 00:16:46.391
much resilience in those operations
that you want to be able to perform PM,

287
00:16:46.391 --> 00:16:52.632
preventative maintenance, without your
existing operations being affected.

288
00:16:52.632 --> 00:16:55.012
That's not gonna be a cheap option, but

289
00:16:55.012 --> 00:16:59.774
then at the same time we don't want to
impact on our live operating environment.

290
00:16:59.774 --> 00:17:02.550
So again, you have to make a decision.

291
00:17:02.550 --> 00:17:04.750
And that's what's most
important is the decision.

292
00:17:04.750 --> 00:17:09.725
>> Jo, virtualization technologies
have really been a game changer for

293
00:17:09.725 --> 00:17:10.950
that last bullet point, too.

294
00:17:10.950 --> 00:17:15.030
Just thinking about how it really has
impacted the industry all together because

295
00:17:15.030 --> 00:17:17.011
in the past it was much more difficult.

296
00:17:17.011 --> 00:17:21.321
You'd have to have an additional physical
server to provide those services for

297
00:17:21.321 --> 00:17:22.500
any kinda down time.

298
00:17:22.500 --> 00:17:26.360
Now with virtualization and you have your
images that you can just redirect and

299
00:17:26.360 --> 00:17:29.184
point to different machines,
it really helps out a lot.

300
00:17:29.184 --> 00:17:31.973
But still, yes, expense.

301
00:17:31.973 --> 00:17:35.490
>> Well virtualization does
help with a lot of things.

302
00:17:35.490 --> 00:17:40.493
Virtualization doesn't help us though,
with, hardware failure.

303
00:17:40.493 --> 00:17:43.202
And quite often,
hardware failure is a result of

304
00:17:43.202 --> 00:17:47.311
the fact that we just haven't performed
any preventative maintenance.

305
00:17:47.311 --> 00:17:49.275
Because we haven't
actually done anything for

306
00:17:49.275 --> 00:17:51.796
such a long time that it's
caused the hardware failure.

307
00:17:51.796 --> 00:17:56.230
And so yes, virtualization really,
really does help, but at the same time,

308
00:17:56.230 --> 00:17:58.810
sometimes we rely on
virtualization as an option.

309
00:17:58.810 --> 00:18:03.887
And we can say well, that's okay
because I partitioned my drive.

310
00:18:03.887 --> 00:18:06.663
And so that's not a problem
cuz I can update this half and

311
00:18:06.663 --> 00:18:09.810
then I can start running things
on this particular partition.

312
00:18:09.810 --> 00:18:12.530
And that's okay, that's not a problem.

313
00:18:12.530 --> 00:18:16.452
But then you get a hardware failure and
everything's affected anyway.

314
00:18:16.452 --> 00:18:18.652
So-
>> Looking at those spin-up times,

315
00:18:18.652 --> 00:18:22.787
it definitely does help, but yes, we're
not gonna use that as a catch-all for

316
00:18:22.787 --> 00:18:24.471
all of our problems, for sure.

317
00:18:24.471 --> 00:18:28.058
>> I know I sound like some sort of
harbinger of doom and gloom right now.

318
00:18:28.058 --> 00:18:28.601
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

319
00:18:28.601 --> 00:18:30.183
>> But then this is all about planning,

320
00:18:30.183 --> 00:18:32.082
okay, it's about planning for the worst.

321
00:18:32.082 --> 00:18:33.403
And that's what we're trying to do.

322
00:18:33.403 --> 00:18:36.212
Is we're trying to plan to ensure
that the service is available.

323
00:18:36.212 --> 00:18:37.980
>> That's a good quality
to have though Jo.

324
00:18:37.980 --> 00:18:41.470
Even in like with when you're taking
a look at from a security perspective,

325
00:18:41.470 --> 00:18:44.040
being able to think like an attacker.

326
00:18:44.040 --> 00:18:47.600
So you're just yeah,
being motherly in that sense, right?

327
00:18:47.600 --> 00:18:48.704
Maybe that'll help a little bit.

328
00:18:48.704 --> 00:18:51.485
>> Well, I prefer motherly to attacker,
I think.

329
00:18:51.485 --> 00:18:53.012
>> [LAUGH]
>> I'm not too sure.

330
00:18:53.012 --> 00:18:55.071
Okay, let's carry on.

331
00:18:55.071 --> 00:18:56.440
>> I thought they were one and
the same, Jo.

332
00:18:56.440 --> 00:18:59.617
>> Well, actually, in my house,

333
00:18:59.617 --> 00:19:00.889
yes [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

334
00:19:00.889 --> 00:19:02.429
>> Let's carry on with some CSI.

335
00:19:02.429 --> 00:19:04.079
>> Shall we?
>> Yeah, yeah,

336
00:19:04.079 --> 00:19:06.786
let's leave that topic here.

337
00:19:06.786 --> 00:19:09.411
And I hate the cliche that says that,

338
00:19:09.411 --> 00:19:14.380
the only thing that we know about the
future is that the future is gonna change.

339
00:19:14.380 --> 00:19:17.950
But unfortunately, especially with IT,
is that is so true.

340
00:19:17.950 --> 00:19:20.715
The only thing that we do know
is that things are gonna change.

341
00:19:20.715 --> 00:19:25.137
And so we've gotta make sure that our
availability plans are flexible enough to

342
00:19:25.137 --> 00:19:25.998
allow change.

343
00:19:25.998 --> 00:19:28.384
And, of course, it's a plan,
it's a document so

344
00:19:28.384 --> 00:19:30.281
it has to go through change management.

345
00:19:30.281 --> 00:19:35.209
But we have to ensure that we can change
because our organization changes and

346
00:19:35.209 --> 00:19:39.530
we need to make sure that we are aligned
to their needs all the time.

347
00:19:40.950 --> 00:19:43.700
Availability management
has got to be recognized.

348
00:19:43.700 --> 00:19:49.010
It's got to be recognized that we need
to deliver availability of our services.

349
00:19:50.130 --> 00:19:53.460
Of course it has, and yet
you saw in a previous episode

350
00:19:53.460 --> 00:19:56.730
where I went through the evolution
of availability management.

351
00:19:56.730 --> 00:19:58.140
And I said that, you know what?

352
00:19:58.140 --> 00:20:03.002
Sometimes we start off not investing any
money in availability management at all.

353
00:20:03.002 --> 00:20:06.122
And therefore we just think
about our individual components.

354
00:20:06.122 --> 00:20:09.908
And if one of them fails then we think,
okay, then that's not a problem,

355
00:20:09.908 --> 00:20:11.163
we'll just swap it out.

356
00:20:11.163 --> 00:20:14.033
That's bad availability planning.

357
00:20:14.033 --> 00:20:20.710
We need to ensure that availability
is tested on a regular basis.

358
00:20:20.710 --> 00:20:26.223
And we have what we call this projected or
predicted service outage document.

359
00:20:26.223 --> 00:20:28.330
This is a little bit of a gray area,

360
00:20:28.330 --> 00:20:33.580
because it mentions this document is
produced in availability management.

361
00:20:33.580 --> 00:20:36.913
And it's all about scheduled downtime.

362
00:20:36.913 --> 00:20:41.606
I'm often asked, and for those of you
that have looked at service transition,

363
00:20:41.606 --> 00:20:44.070
you may have done, you may not have done.

364
00:20:44.070 --> 00:20:48.270
But in service transition, you learned in
your foundation material that there was

365
00:20:48.270 --> 00:20:50.890
a document called the change schedule.

366
00:20:50.890 --> 00:20:56.720
And the change schedule was a schedule
of planned changes, upcoming changes.

367
00:20:56.720 --> 00:21:00.500
And I'm often asked if the change
schedule is the same thing as the PSO,

368
00:21:00.500 --> 00:21:03.280
the projected service outage document.

369
00:21:03.280 --> 00:21:07.900
I want you to think of this PSO as
a subset of the change schedule.

370
00:21:07.900 --> 00:21:11.191
The change schedule is a list
of all upcoming changes.

371
00:21:11.191 --> 00:21:16.095
Whereas your PSO is a list of all
of those changes that are going

372
00:21:16.095 --> 00:21:18.850
to impact availability.

373
00:21:18.850 --> 00:21:21.650
Not all changes impact availability, but

374
00:21:21.650 --> 00:21:26.380
your PSO is just a plan
of availability impacts.

375
00:21:27.570 --> 00:21:30.880
When I say think of this as
a subset of your change schedule

376
00:21:30.880 --> 00:21:35.730
it's because every single
scheduled maintenance.

377
00:21:35.730 --> 00:21:41.220
Every single scheduled downtime should
have an associated request for change.

378
00:21:41.220 --> 00:21:43.920
It should have an associated
change record.

379
00:21:43.920 --> 00:21:48.860
So, of course, this should be
a subset of your change schedule.

380
00:21:48.860 --> 00:21:53.762
So think of this as part of your change
schedule that shows what changes

381
00:21:53.762 --> 00:21:55.433
impact availability.

382
00:21:55.433 --> 00:21:58.933
And this is what your PSO is.

383
00:21:58.933 --> 00:22:03.183
So for this particular episode
I'm going to leave it there.

384
00:22:03.183 --> 00:22:05.464
And when we come back in our next episode,

385
00:22:05.464 --> 00:22:09.790
and I think our next episode is episode
seven, for availability management.

386
00:22:09.790 --> 00:22:13.253
So yeah, we've got quite a lot
to look at here in availability.

387
00:22:13.253 --> 00:22:16.883
We're going to look in episode
seven at the imputs and outputs and

388
00:22:16.883 --> 00:22:19.330
what starts off availability management.

389
00:22:19.330 --> 00:22:21.540
And also the critical success factors and

390
00:22:21.540 --> 00:22:25.911
interactions that availability management
has with all of our other processes.

391
00:22:25.911 --> 00:22:27.360
>> All right, sounds like a plan, Jo.

392
00:22:27.360 --> 00:22:28.431
Thank you for sharing that with us.

393
00:22:28.431 --> 00:22:30.660
And thank you for being with us as well.

394
00:22:30.660 --> 00:22:32.785
For this show,
we're gonna go ahead and sign out.

395
00:22:32.785 --> 00:22:34.322
I've been your host, Cherokee Boose.

396
00:22:34.322 --> 00:22:35.217
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

397
00:22:35.217 --> 00:22:37.639
>> See you next time here at ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this show, Cherokee and Jo introduce capacity management. Jo explains the value of capacity management to the business. She explains it as a means of ensuring that the capacity of IT services and the IT infrastructure meets the agreed capacity and performance related requirements in cost-effective and timely manner. She also explains the thre sub-process of business capacity management, service capacity management, and component capacity management.

00:04:31.860 --> 00:04:35.690

is looking at new technology and

85
00:04:35.690 --> 00:04:37.940
looking at ways to meet demand.

86
00:04:37.940 --> 00:04:40.250
I mean, let's think about this just for

00:04:40.250 --> 00:04:43.572

89
00:04:48.280 --> 00:04:49.200

responding to your complaint doesn't

00:04:57.670 --> 00:05:00.600

97

98
00:05:23.370 --> 00:05:26.210

00:05:26.210 --> 00:05:30.195

100
00:05:30.195 --> 00:05:35.150
requirements that's much more efficient

101
00:05:35.150 --> 00:05:38.340
So yes, anything is possible nowadays.

102
00:05:38.340 --> 00:05:41.930
And that's not something that we would

103
00:05:41.930 --> 00:05:44.890

104
00:05:46.130 --> 00:05:50.100
So what we're also gonna look at,

we're gonna look at working
with availability management to

106

our new service models.

107
00:05:58.420 --> 00:06:01.050

108

110
00:06:10.880 --> 00:06:14.270

111

bringing in more capacity.

113
00:06:19.130 --> 00:06:22.354
So we're gonna work hand in hand
with availability management, and

114
00:06:22.354 --> 00:06:23.800
with financial management and

115
00:06:23.800 --> 00:06:26.981
business relationship management,
to justify any expenditure.

116
00:06:26.981 --> 00:06:29.880
And to be able to satisfy any expenditure,

117
00:06:31.130 --> 00:06:35.220
Take a look at the activities

00:07:37.850 --> 00:07:41.900
And then, we perform any fine tuning,

which means workload balancing, maybe

00:07:47.990 --> 00:07:53.270

00:07:53.270 --> 00:07:56.976

control,

this is going to be helped here

00:08:13.530 --> 00:08:17.730
Looking at alert management, the words

145
00:08:17.730 --> 00:08:22.240
And if you're not too sure about that,

00:08:27.060 --> 00:08:30.690

00:08:32.000 --> 00:08:33.560

151
00:08:43.850 --> 00:08:46.550
Because we don't want any jobs to

00:08:46.550 --> 00:08:50.950

153
00:08:50.950 --> 00:08:56.430

load balancing on our network as well.

154
00:08:56.430 --> 00:09:01.370
So again, we'd start using things

155
00:09:01.370 --> 00:09:04.294
And as we've already mentioned,
demand management.

156
00:09:04.294 --> 00:09:06.155
What about response time monitoring?

157
00:09:06.155 --> 00:09:11.651
Again, it's part of monitoring and

00:09:11.651 --> 00:09:17.247

00:09:17.247 --> 00:09:20.515

160
00:09:20.515 --> 00:09:25.250
One thing that I will just wanna mention
about monitoring and about capacity

00:09:25.250 --> 00:09:28.790

162

163

00:09:40.980 --> 00:09:43.368

165
00:09:43.368 --> 00:09:47.600
If you've got something sitting in your

166
00:09:47.600 --> 00:09:51.260

bandwidths, simple as that.

167
00:09:52.660 --> 00:09:53.848
Don't overlook that.

168
00:09:53.848 --> 00:09:56.740
If you're bringing in a monitoring tool,
it's gonna use capacity,

169
00:09:56.740 --> 00:10:00.460
it's gonna use the exact thing
that you're monitoring for.

170
00:10:00.460 --> 00:10:03.880
So don't overlook that, you have
to think about those requirements.

171
00:10:03.880 --> 00:10:08.090
Every time you download an app

00:10:08.090 --> 00:10:13.280

173
00:10:13.280 --> 00:10:14.940
But the actual app itself,

174
00:10:14.940 --> 00:10:19.450
it doesn't sit there in the ether
somewhere, it's on your phone.

175
00:10:19.450 --> 00:10:20.820
It's using your capacity.

176
00:10:20.820 --> 00:10:25.020
>> That kinda goes back to the old adage
of measure your measuring tools, so

177
00:10:25.020 --> 00:10:27.815
you gotta think about that,
kind of coincides with that.

178
00:10:27.815 --> 00:10:32.280
>> Right, and any tool that we use to
measure our measuring tools is actually

179
00:10:32.280 --> 00:10:37.490
going to require some configuration so
that we can measure our measuring tools.

180
00:10:37.490 --> 00:10:39.980
And it kind of just goes back all the way.

181
00:10:39.980 --> 00:10:42.150
Whenever we bring in a tool
to monitor something,

182
00:10:42.150 --> 00:10:44.710
it's gonna use whatever
it is it's monitoring.

183
00:10:44.710 --> 00:10:45.550
Just remember that.

184
00:10:46.840 --> 00:10:50.690
So capacity management has got,
as we've already said, proactive and

185
00:10:50.690 --> 00:10:51.910
reactive elements.

186
00:10:51.910 --> 00:10:57.266
And so here, if we look at these bullet
points here, we're actually monitoring

187
00:10:57.266 --> 00:11:02.017
our usage right now, we're responding
to any outages that may occur.

188
00:11:02.017 --> 00:11:07.619
But we are also researching and
modeling into new technologies and

189
00:11:07.619 --> 00:11:12.320
into new ways of meeting
the capacity requirements, or

190
00:11:12.320 --> 00:11:15.815
what we might call the demand.

191
00:11:15.815 --> 00:11:17.720
Let's not forget demand management.

192
00:11:17.720 --> 00:11:21.520
Demand management's focus is
to influence customer demand,

193
00:11:21.520 --> 00:11:23.480
it's used to influence behavior.

194
00:11:24.770 --> 00:11:26.980
That's what demand management is for.

195
00:11:26.980 --> 00:11:29.250
Now if you need to know more
about demand management,

196
00:11:29.250 --> 00:11:32.690
then I would suggest you go
back to service strategy.

197
00:11:32.690 --> 00:11:37.830
And in the service strategy show, we had
episodes on the demand management process.

198
00:11:37.830 --> 00:11:43.110
But in a nutshell, demand management will
monitor patterns of business activity.

199
00:11:44.230 --> 00:11:49.000
And then will seek to adjust
user behavior or influence user

200
00:11:49.000 --> 00:11:54.460
behavior in order to meet the capacity
requirements of the organization.

201
00:11:54.460 --> 00:12:00.020
So this is a way of changing behavior
to meet capacity requirements,

202
00:12:00.020 --> 00:12:03.330
rather than just bringing
in more capacity.

203
00:12:03.330 --> 00:12:05.490
Demand management is optional.

204
00:12:05.490 --> 00:12:09.210
It's not something that we're going to
tell you that you have to utilize, okay?

205
00:12:09.210 --> 00:12:10.200
You don't have to do that.

206
00:12:10.200 --> 00:12:13.140
You don't have to
implement load balancing.

207
00:12:13.140 --> 00:12:16.330
You don't have to implement
differential charging.

208
00:12:16.330 --> 00:12:20.390
But demand management is an option
that is available to you,

209
00:12:20.390 --> 00:12:23.020
as a capacity management process manager.

210
00:12:24.230 --> 00:12:30.150
And then of course, proactively
predicting capacity requirements.

211
00:12:30.150 --> 00:12:34.400
We're going to perform modelling and
we're going to perform trending as well.

212
00:12:34.400 --> 00:12:38.050
Modelling looks at, what if I do this?

213
00:12:38.050 --> 00:12:43.047
And I like to call this the,
let's pretend version.

214
00:12:43.047 --> 00:12:47.200
Or, sorry, the let's pretend method,
not version, for capacity management.

215
00:12:47.200 --> 00:12:51.950
And it really is just about, well,
what's gonna happen in the future.

216
00:12:51.950 --> 00:12:53.950
What if I do that?

217
00:12:53.950 --> 00:12:56.660
My baseline is where am I right now, and

218
00:12:56.660 --> 00:13:01.500
then I will, well,
I'll look at different scenarios.

219
00:13:01.500 --> 00:13:06.830
I will hypothesize,
what if I add in 500 additional users?

220
00:13:06.830 --> 00:13:09.780
What if I take away 500 users?

221
00:13:09.780 --> 00:13:14.908
What if I increase my workload by 500%?

222
00:13:14.908 --> 00:13:17.170
These are what-ifs.

223
00:13:17.170 --> 00:13:18.964
And so we will hypothesize,

224
00:13:18.964 --> 00:13:23.018
we'll use information from our
suppliers to help us with this.

225
00:13:23.018 --> 00:13:27.826
We will use information from maybe our
competitors, maybe industry standards,

226
00:13:27.826 --> 00:13:31.320
and they will help us
perform modelling exercises.

227
00:13:31.320 --> 00:13:35.040
Ultimately what we're trying to do is
ensure that we have enough capacity

228
00:13:35.040 --> 00:13:36.130
for the future.

229
00:13:36.130 --> 00:13:38.882
We're trying to predict
capacity utilization and

230
00:13:38.882 --> 00:13:41.140
ensure that we've got enough.

231
00:13:41.140 --> 00:13:43.400
So we're going to use any method and

232
00:13:43.400 --> 00:13:47.640
any technique that we have at our
disposal to allow us to do that.

233
00:13:49.000 --> 00:13:51.450
And then we've also got
application sizing.

234
00:13:51.450 --> 00:13:56.950
Which again, is about looking to
the future at our requirements and

235
00:13:59.160 --> 00:14:03.090
ensuring that we have enough space,

236
00:14:03.090 --> 00:14:08.630
enough capacity in our applications,
to meet the needs of the organization.

237
00:14:08.630 --> 00:14:11.899
What we have to do is that we have to,
in service design,

238
00:14:11.899 --> 00:14:13.930
look at the lifespan of a service.

239
00:14:15.220 --> 00:14:21.900
How much capacity do we need for
the service in its entirety?

240
00:14:21.900 --> 00:14:24.760
It's proactive, it's predictive.

241
00:14:25.870 --> 00:14:27.360
Here's a challenge, though, for you,

242
00:14:27.360 --> 00:14:31.410
because when you bring in a new service,
you're designing a new service.

00:14:33.250 --> 00:14:34.630
Let's think about the reality of this.

244
00:14:34.630 --> 00:14:37.290
First things first,
is when you're designing a new service,

00:14:37.290 --> 00:14:41.890

takes longer than a year, then

246
00:14:41.890 --> 00:14:45.520
