from the day that you first implement it.

247
00:14:47.330 --> 00:14:48.110
There's one problem.

248
00:14:49.410 --> 00:14:52.710
From the minute you implement that
service, if you designed it a year ago,

249
00:14:52.710 --> 00:14:53.770
then it's already out of date.

250
00:14:54.780 --> 00:14:56.440
There's challenge number one.

251
00:14:56.440 --> 00:15:00.290
Challenge number two is trying to
predict how long you're going to

252
00:15:00.290 --> 00:15:01.840

253
00:15:01.840 --> 00:15:06.970
So let's say then for,

254
00:15:08.110 --> 00:15:11.169
Well, by the time we brought in
that new email service, well,

255
00:15:11.169 --> 00:15:13.092

256
00:15:13.092 --> 00:15:16.761

257
00:15:16.761 --> 00:15:20.526
Cuz I'll guarantee that in five years'
time something else has already come along

258
00:15:20.526 --> 00:15:23.230
that's newer and bigger and
brighter, and you want that.

259
00:15:24.840 --> 00:15:28.520
So we have to then work out
what the lifespan is of, or

00:15:28.520 --> 00:15:33.375

261
00:15:33.375 --> 00:15:39.750

262
00:15:39.750 --> 00:15:44.800

263
00:15:44.800 --> 00:15:50.090

265
00:15:54.350 --> 00:15:57.620

266
00:15:57.620 --> 00:16:03.956
So what we've looked at so far in these
previous few slides in this episode so

very high level to predict our

00:16:09.203 --> 00:16:14.450

our future business requirements.

269
00:16:15.610 --> 00:16:19.574

270
00:16:19.574 --> 00:16:24.277

00:16:39.018 --> 00:16:42.690

00:16:47.620 --> 00:16:50.640

277
00:16:50.640 --> 00:16:54.080

00:16:54.080 --> 00:16:57.340

is I would like you just to review

00:16:57.340 --> 00:17:00.230

assign a business recovery priority for
each service.

482
00:27:05.760 --> 00:27:07.400
And then we'll do a risk assessment.

483
00:27:07.400 --> 00:27:11.230
Now, for further information about
risk assessment, I want you to

484
00:27:11.230 --> 00:27:16.140
take a look at
the Availability Management Process.

485
00:27:16.140 --> 00:27:18.790
We looked in some of the episodes
in availability management

486
00:27:18.790 --> 00:27:20.260
at risk assessment.

487
00:27:20.260 --> 00:27:22.330
So, I'm not gonna repeat myself there.

488
00:27:22.330 --> 00:27:24.000
However, what I am gonna say is,

489
00:27:24.000 --> 00:27:28.310
draw your attention to the diagram
on the right-hand side.

490
00:27:28.310 --> 00:27:31.422
You'll notice that in the UK
government we like the use of wheels.

491
00:27:31.422 --> 00:27:34.726
Or, as we would call this,
a washing machine approach.

492
00:27:34.726 --> 00:27:36.710
>> A washing machine, okay.
>> Yeah, we use this in ITIL.

493
00:27:36.710 --> 00:27:42.000
We have the same type of diagram in
ITIL and we have this one in MOR.

494
00:27:42.000 --> 00:27:43.710
MOR is Management of Risk and

495
00:27:43.710 --> 00:27:49.180
it's just one example of
a Risk Management Framework.

496
00:27:49.180 --> 00:27:54.034
And we have another example of
MOR just displayed from another

497
00:27:54.034 --> 00:27:56.940
angle in Availability Management.

498
00:27:56.940 --> 00:28:00.710
So, I'd like you to go back to
Availability Management and

499
00:28:00.710 --> 00:28:03.410
just review the Risk Management
section there.

500
00:28:03.410 --> 00:28:07.478
But ultimately,
we have to assess the vulnerability and

501
00:28:07.478 --> 00:28:09.522
the likelihood of any risk.

502
00:28:09.522 --> 00:28:12.943
And that will help us determine
what we will do about that risk,

503
00:28:12.943 --> 00:28:15.150
whether we want to mitigate against it.

504
00:28:15.150 --> 00:28:16.690
Whether we want to just accept it.

505
00:28:16.690 --> 00:28:18.130
Whether we want to transfer it.

506
00:28:18.130 --> 00:28:20.550
Or whether we want to share
it with somebody else.

507
00:28:22.840 --> 00:28:24.870
And then again,
as part of our requirements, then

508
00:28:25.920 --> 00:28:31.090
we look at the Service Continuity Strategy
with a focus

509
00:28:31.090 --> 00:28:36.930
on Business Continuity,
how will we support the business.

510
00:28:36.930 --> 00:28:41.730
Think about prevention, as well as
disaster recovery, as we've already said.

511
00:28:41.730 --> 00:28:45.090
So, prevention in terms of UPS,
Uninterruptible Power Supply.

512
00:28:45.090 --> 00:28:48.560
You know, fault tolerant or
resilient systems.

513
00:28:48.560 --> 00:28:52.150
RAID arrays for our disks,
for our servers.

514
00:28:52.150 --> 00:28:55.220
Think in terms of mirroring for
our servers as well.

515
00:28:55.220 --> 00:28:57.660
Think about offsite storage.

516
00:28:57.660 --> 00:29:02.710
A lot of organizations will use cloud
now and will use virtualization.

517
00:29:02.710 --> 00:29:07.481
A lot of organizations will still
use what we call redundant systems.

518
00:29:07.481 --> 00:29:11.938
And I know many, many global organizations
have what we call redundant data centers,

519
00:29:11.938 --> 00:29:14.808
where you've got two data
centers In different parts of

520
00:29:14.808 --> 00:29:17.150
the world that are actually mirroring.

521
00:29:17.150 --> 00:29:19.420
And they're doing full mirroring as well.

522
00:29:19.420 --> 00:29:22.730
So, they're both processing
at exactly the same time.

523
00:29:22.730 --> 00:29:24.595
Obviously, that's expensive.

524
00:29:24.595 --> 00:29:27.670
That's not something that
is cheap to maintain.

525
00:29:29.110 --> 00:29:31.180
It's entirely up to the organization.

526
00:29:31.180 --> 00:29:37.650
And it depends on how much you want to
invest in service continuity, okay.

527
00:29:39.030 --> 00:29:41.610
Again, up to your organization.

528
00:29:41.610 --> 00:29:43.510
So, now let's think about
implementation then.

529
00:29:43.510 --> 00:29:48.658
And we're just simply going through
that diagram that we first saw.

530
00:29:48.658 --> 00:29:51.857
And the implementation of
service continuity well,

531
00:29:51.857 --> 00:29:56.200
as I keep saying it's all about
reflecting business continuity plans.

532
00:29:57.680 --> 00:30:00.100
It's more than just about recovery.

533
00:30:00.100 --> 00:30:04.020
It's also about continuing
in the case of a disaster.

534
00:30:05.690 --> 00:30:11.960
Even if we have continuity in place and we
are continuing in the case of a disaster,

535
00:30:11.960 --> 00:30:17.320
we still need to be aware that
there has been a disaster.

536
00:30:17.320 --> 00:30:21.619
We can't just ignore that disaster, okay?

537
00:30:21.619 --> 00:30:24.790
We still have to acknowledge
that it has happened.

538
00:30:24.790 --> 00:30:28.230
So, now let's just take
a quick look at recovery then.

539
00:30:29.270 --> 00:30:32.230
This is what should be
in your recovery plans.

540
00:30:32.230 --> 00:30:34.400
I mean, it's got the usual in there.

541
00:30:34.400 --> 00:30:37.630
Lots of documents such as revisions,
and a circulation list,

542
00:30:37.630 --> 00:30:41.988
and as I've already said,
clear conditions for

543
00:30:41.988 --> 00:30:48.520
the invocation etc.

544
00:30:48.520 --> 00:30:52.330
And then let's take another look
at more information in there.

545
00:30:52.330 --> 00:30:53.640
Who's going to be doing what?

546
00:30:53.640 --> 00:30:55.170
What about security?

547
00:30:55.170 --> 00:30:56.890
What about sites?

548
00:30:56.890 --> 00:30:58.380
How do we get access to sites?

549
00:30:58.380 --> 00:31:04.580
And the one thing that we don't wanna
forget, how do we go back, yeah?

550
00:31:04.580 --> 00:31:09.080
That's something that
needs testing as well.

551
00:31:09.080 --> 00:31:10.780
How do we actually get
back to our live site.

552
00:31:10.780 --> 00:31:12.870
Or there's the ultimate question,
of course,

553
00:31:12.870 --> 00:31:15.260
is do we actually go
back to our live site?

554
00:31:15.260 --> 00:31:17.070
>> Not in the case of that oil refinery.

555
00:31:17.070 --> 00:31:19.670
>> Right [LAUGH] yeah,
there is no live site, yeah.

556
00:31:19.670 --> 00:31:23.240
But sometimes, if we've got live
mirroring that's happening,

557
00:31:23.240 --> 00:31:26.920
especially across data sites,
we have data centers across the world,

558
00:31:26.920 --> 00:31:28.760
we might choose not to go
back to the live site.

559
00:31:28.760 --> 00:31:32.440
We just might maintain that one now and
that's our live site.

560
00:31:32.440 --> 00:31:37.185
And then, the next time something happens,
then we just switch over.

561
00:31:37.185 --> 00:31:39.890
And again, that choice is up to you.

562
00:31:39.890 --> 00:31:43.860
>> You have to plan for
the implementations of

563
00:31:43.860 --> 00:31:48.810
your service continuity or
your disaster recovery implementation.

564
00:31:48.810 --> 00:31:53.110
Including things like accommodation,
crisis management, communication.

565
00:31:53.110 --> 00:31:53.976
What about money?

566
00:31:53.976 --> 00:31:58.104
Is there any money that's been put
aside to actually move stuff to another

567
00:31:58.104 --> 00:31:58.778
location?

568
00:31:58.778 --> 00:32:03.570
If your DR site Is 100 miles away,
you're gonna have to pay for hotels.

569
00:32:03.570 --> 00:32:05.972
And you're going to have
a hotel on standby as well,

570
00:32:05.972 --> 00:32:08.661
because you never know when
something is going to happen.

571
00:32:08.661 --> 00:32:11.861
And if you have to relocate
500 people at the last minute,

572
00:32:11.861 --> 00:32:14.330
then you better have a few
hotels on your list.

573
00:32:16.370 --> 00:32:17.770
And think about who's gonna be doing what.

574
00:32:17.770 --> 00:32:22.430
As I've already said, your role might
not exist in the case of a disaster.

575
00:32:22.430 --> 00:32:25.970
So you might be deployed
to do something else.

576
00:32:25.970 --> 00:32:27.790
So think about who's going to do what.

577
00:32:27.790 --> 00:32:31.275
What happens if you are on what
we call the executive team, and

578
00:32:31.275 --> 00:32:33.440
you're managing the migration.

579
00:32:35.612 --> 00:32:39.330
Everybody should have very defined
roles and responsibilities.

580
00:32:40.700 --> 00:32:44.460
And this process should be
audited on a regular basis.

581
00:32:46.560 --> 00:32:48.700
At least once a year we should ensure, and

582
00:32:48.700 --> 00:32:52.500
after any major change, that our
service continuity plans are valid.

583
00:32:52.500 --> 00:32:56.820
And, of course, I've already mentioned, we
should what we call walkthrough tests and

584
00:32:56.820 --> 00:33:00.310
we should have full tests,
at least once a year.

585
00:33:00.310 --> 00:33:06.140
That's when somebody actually presses that
big red button, at least once a year.

586
00:33:06.140 --> 00:33:09.700
You can have partial tests and
you can have scenario tests as well.

587
00:33:09.700 --> 00:33:14.810
We're not going to tell you exactly how
you need to do that because we can't,

588
00:33:14.810 --> 00:33:17.860
every single organization
works completely differently.

589
00:33:17.860 --> 00:33:21.993
However, we will tell you that
you do need to undertake this.

590
00:33:21.993 --> 00:33:25.540
And then don't forget change management.

591
00:33:25.540 --> 00:33:28.949
Change management,
every time we make a major change,

592
00:33:28.949 --> 00:33:34.027
I've already mentioned this, if you're
upgrading your operating system, then

593
00:33:34.027 --> 00:33:38.981
you need to make sure that your operating
system in your DR site is also upgraded.

594
00:33:38.981 --> 00:33:42.972
And any changes to our
service continuity plans,

595
00:33:42.972 --> 00:33:47.923
they've also got to be managed
by change management, okay?

596
00:33:47.923 --> 00:33:51.792
And for any new service then we have
to conduct that risk assessment as

597
00:33:51.792 --> 00:33:53.070
we've already said.

598
00:33:54.140 --> 00:33:59.040
And then the last part to this program and
these next two slides in this

599
00:33:59.040 --> 00:34:02.640
particular part, that's where we're gonna
leave it for this particular episode.

600
00:34:02.640 --> 00:34:07.120
And that is just the ongoing
operation of service continuity.

601
00:34:07.120 --> 00:34:12.280
You have to be aware that this could
be invoked at any point in time,

602
00:34:12.280 --> 00:34:15.940
and that third bullet point there about
service continuity tends to be driven as

603
00:34:15.940 --> 00:34:20.320
a project and then forgotten about,
that's very, very true.

604
00:34:20.320 --> 00:34:23.780
That's exactly what happens, so we have
to make sure that our education and

605
00:34:23.780 --> 00:34:25.720
our awareness is always there.

606
00:34:27.030 --> 00:34:30.490
If you wanted to pass an ISO20000 audit,
which, of course,

607
00:34:30.490 --> 00:34:33.960
is the international standard for
service management, then an auditor,

608
00:34:33.960 --> 00:34:37.130
somebody like myself,
is going to walk into your organization.

609
00:34:37.130 --> 00:34:41.890
And we'll ask anybody within your service
provider organization where your service

610
00:34:41.890 --> 00:34:43.630
continuity plans are.

611
00:34:43.630 --> 00:34:49.070
And if they can't show anyone, if they
can't show the auditor, then you fail.

612
00:34:49.070 --> 00:34:50.460
It's as simple as that.

613
00:34:50.460 --> 00:34:52.920
There should be ongoing awareness.

614
00:34:52.920 --> 00:34:54.510
And that's within the organization.

615
00:34:54.510 --> 00:34:57.660
And I don't expect to see
it on the Intranet either.

616
00:34:57.660 --> 00:35:02.190
I expect to see it somewhere off-site
in some virtual environment, perhaps.

617
00:35:02.190 --> 00:35:05.698
I also expect to see testing programs,
as well.

618
00:35:05.698 --> 00:35:11.920
And I expect to see that change control
is controlling service continuity.

619
00:35:12.940 --> 00:35:18.000
So as I've already said, we've now looked
at the process for service continuity,

620
00:35:18.000 --> 00:35:19.690
IT service continuity.

621
00:35:19.690 --> 00:35:21.005
And in our next episode,

622
00:35:21.005 --> 00:35:25.138
we're going to look at those different
recovery options that you mentioned,

623
00:35:25.138 --> 00:35:28.914
Cherokee, and we're going to be
looking at some of that terminology.

624
00:35:28.914 --> 00:35:31.304
But for now what I'd like you to do,

625
00:35:31.304 --> 00:35:35.340
is I'd like you just to recap
over the process itself.

626
00:35:35.340 --> 00:35:37.520
Look at the stages within the process.

627
00:35:37.520 --> 00:35:41.527
There is an exercise in your downloadable
material which should take you around

628
00:35:41.527 --> 00:35:42.619
about 30 minutes.

629
00:35:42.619 --> 00:35:46.730
And if you have any questions as per
usual we are available on the forum.

630
00:35:46.730 --> 00:35:51.990
And I will do as much as I can within my
power to help any questions you may have.

631
00:35:51.990 --> 00:35:53.880
>> Perfect Jo, thank you so much.

632
00:35:53.880 --> 00:35:57.920
But when it comes to IT service continuity
management, we're not quite finished yet.

633
00:35:57.920 --> 00:36:00.622
So ladies and gentlemen,
stay tuned for more information.

634
00:36:00.622 --> 00:36:02.600
For this show,
we'll go ahead and sign out.

635
00:36:02.600 --> 00:36:04.080
I've been your host, Cherokee Boose.

636
00:36:04.080 --> 00:36:04.840
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

637
00:36:04.840 --> 00:36:06.977
>> See you next time here at ITPRO.TV.

638
00:36:06.977 --> 00:36:13.360
[MUSIC]

639
00:36:13.360 --> 00:36:15.904
Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: In this show, Cherokee and Jo continue discussing  ITSCM. Specifically, they look at recovery options. Jo encourages incorporating manual work arounds to maintain continuity. The ladies also suggest reciprocal agreements and varying levels of backup sites such as cold, warm and hot standbys. Tune in for more!
episodes.title: SD Processes - IT Service Continutiy Mgmt Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.300 --> 00:00:02.155
Welcome to ITProTV, I'm your host.

2
00:00:02.155 --> 00:00:05.475
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:05.475 --> 00:00:08.424
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.424 --> 00:00:12.176
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:12.176 --> 00:00:15.095
>> Welcome to your ITIL intermediate
series, I'm your show host,

6
00:00:15.095 --> 00:00:16.460
Cherokee Boose.

7
00:00:16.460 --> 00:00:21.910
In the last episode, Jo introduced us to
our IT service continuity management.

8
00:00:21.910 --> 00:00:24.270
In this episode,
we'll continue taking a look at that, and

9
00:00:24.270 --> 00:00:26.130
she's back in studios with us today.

10
00:00:26.130 --> 00:00:27.890
Thank you for joining us, Jo, how are you?

11
00:00:27.890 --> 00:00:29.580
>> I'm fine, thank you Cherokee,
how are you?

12
00:00:29.580 --> 00:00:32.250
>> I'm doing great,
I'm excited to keep the momentum here,

13
00:00:32.250 --> 00:00:34.300
because you've given us
a lot to think about.

14
00:00:34.300 --> 00:00:38.420
In case of a disaster, and how we can
even maintain that continuity there.

15
00:00:38.420 --> 00:00:41.110
So what are we going to be
looking at first here today, Jo?

16
00:00:41.110 --> 00:00:44.559
>> Well, what we're actually going to do,
at the beginning of our last episode,

17
00:00:44.559 --> 00:00:46.060
you mentioned some terminology.

18
00:00:46.060 --> 00:00:47.134
>> That's right.

19
00:00:47.134 --> 00:00:50.330
>> And so now,
we're gonna go over our recovery options.

20
00:00:50.330 --> 00:00:53.770
And we're just actually gonna go
over the terminology that we use

21
00:00:53.770 --> 00:00:55.260
in service continuity.

22
00:00:55.260 --> 00:00:59.930
We're gonna be doing that, and
then we're going to look at the inputs and

23
00:00:59.930 --> 00:01:01.660
outputs to service continuity.

24
00:01:01.660 --> 00:01:04.510
Although, to be honest, we covered
a lot of that in our last episode.

25
00:01:04.510 --> 00:01:08.963
And you know what, service continuity is
our third warranty process that we've

26
00:01:08.963 --> 00:01:11.790
looked at in this particular
service design show.

27
00:01:11.790 --> 00:01:15.610
So the same principles
apply to all of them,

28
00:01:15.610 --> 00:01:20.130
really, in that we've got to be hand in
hand with the needs of the organization.

29
00:01:20.130 --> 00:01:23.279
And we've gotta look at the warranty
levels that are required by

30
00:01:23.279 --> 00:01:24.281
the organization.

31
00:01:24.281 --> 00:01:31.536
So everything in service continuity is
matched to the needs of the organization.

32
00:01:31.536 --> 00:01:36.740
It's really what they want to see,
and what they need us to provide.

33
00:01:36.740 --> 00:01:38.810
So let's take a look at our
recovery options, then,

34
00:01:38.810 --> 00:01:41.510
and we're gonna get straight into it.

35
00:01:41.510 --> 00:01:43.785
And the first one is a manual workaround,

36
00:01:43.785 --> 00:01:47.525
[LAUGH] be surprised how
many people still do this.

37
00:01:47.525 --> 00:01:52.124
>> Jo, I was at a gas station one time,
and their computer systems went down,

38
00:01:52.124 --> 00:01:54.899
so I had to stay there
until they came back up.

39
00:01:54.899 --> 00:01:57.058
>> Great [LAUGH].

40
00:01:57.058 --> 00:01:58.192
>> I mean, you think about it, but

41
00:01:58.192 --> 00:02:00.844
a lot of companies just really aren't
prepared to deal with this anymore.

42
00:02:00.844 --> 00:02:04.034
>> No, and a lot of companies just do
not think about service continuity,

43
00:02:04.034 --> 00:02:05.429
they really, really don't.

44
00:02:05.429 --> 00:02:08.079
>> [LAUGH]
>> And I mean to be perfectly honest,

45
00:02:08.079 --> 00:02:10.618
if somebody had said to me,
you're gonna stay here.

46
00:02:10.618 --> 00:02:12.748
>> [LAUGH]
>> I'd be saying, do you know what,

47
00:02:12.748 --> 00:02:14.410
you need to call the police,
cuz I'm leaving.

48
00:02:14.410 --> 00:02:18.750
[LAUGH] There is no way that
I would just stay there.

49
00:02:18.750 --> 00:02:22.500
But this is a problem,
a lot of people don't think about this.

50
00:02:22.500 --> 00:02:26.620
There are a lot of independent shops,
for instance, independent stores,

51
00:02:26.620 --> 00:02:29.880
where we rely so
much on our credit cards now.

52
00:02:29.880 --> 00:02:33.080
Well, you know what, that's IT,
it's IT that manages that,

53
00:02:33.080 --> 00:02:35.889
and when it doesn't work,
they don't know what to do.

54
00:02:35.889 --> 00:02:38.654
In that instance,
they just don't know what to do.

55
00:02:38.654 --> 00:02:43.887
You see, a manual recovery, it just
simply involves getting the paper out,

56
00:02:43.887 --> 00:02:46.970
and I've seen a lot of
service desks do this.

57
00:02:46.970 --> 00:02:47.620
Okay then,

58
00:02:47.620 --> 00:02:52.350
well, if the service desk call login goes
down, we'll get our Excel spreadsheet.

59
00:02:52.350 --> 00:02:53.970
Which is absolutely great, but

60
00:02:53.970 --> 00:02:57.930
then you've gotta input that information
back into the call logging system.

61
00:02:57.930 --> 00:03:01.410
And so, it actually does require
not just higher levels of staff,

62
00:03:01.410 --> 00:03:03.170
because you're doing things manually, but

63
00:03:03.170 --> 00:03:08.100
it also requires a lot more
intervention in the long run.

64
00:03:08.100 --> 00:03:12.530
Because all of that information's gotta
be put into your systems when you

65
00:03:12.530 --> 00:03:13.950
come back up.

66
00:03:13.950 --> 00:03:17.680
That's not to say that we should
eliminate it, it is a valid option for

67
00:03:17.680 --> 00:03:21.160
some organizations, and
think about this in terms of scale.

68
00:03:21.160 --> 00:03:25.130
The smaller organizations are more
likely to do something like this.

69
00:03:25.130 --> 00:03:28.590
If this doesn't happen right now,
if something's not working right now,

70

I'm just going to write it down for

particular slide, I always really like.

00:16:33.967 --> 00:16:36.155
I always start up with my triggers and

301
00:16:36.155 --> 00:16:39.128
what starts off service
continuity management.

302
00:16:39.128 --> 00:16:43.716
Well, I've already mentioned in
availability management and capacity

303
00:16:43.716 --> 00:16:48.830
management, we've got exactly the same
criteria that starts off this process.

304
00:16:48.830 --> 00:16:52.510
And that is newer change services,
new targets,

305
00:16:52.510 --> 00:16:57.768
any major incident if something's
gone wrong, lessons learned, and

306
00:16:57.768 --> 00:17:03.131
service continuity and CSI,
Continual Service Improvement.

307
00:17:03.131 --> 00:17:07.910
These will all start
off service continuity.

308
00:17:07.910 --> 00:17:10.020
And when I say start
off service continuity,

309
00:17:10.020 --> 00:17:15.580
I don't mean that these are all
considered to be invocation criteria, no.

310
00:17:15.580 --> 00:17:20.124
These all start service continuity into
either reviewing existing plans or

311
00:17:20.124 --> 00:17:21.409
creating new plans.

312
00:17:21.409 --> 00:17:25.096
Including things like periodic
business impact analysis, or

313
00:17:25.096 --> 00:17:30.043
changes in direction from organization and
changes rights or business functions.

314
00:17:30.043 --> 00:17:35.100
These sort of changes will come in
through business relationship management.

315
00:17:35.100 --> 00:17:39.310
So, all of that, well,
we'll consider those to be inputs.

316
00:17:39.310 --> 00:17:41.073
And like availability management and

317
00:17:41.073 --> 00:17:45.151
capacity management that we've already
covered, we've got business information,

318
00:17:45.151 --> 00:17:49.330
we've got patterns of business activity,
we've got vital business functions.

319
00:17:49.330 --> 00:17:50.928
They should all be inputs.

320
00:17:50.928 --> 00:17:53.474
And of course, another major input, and

321
00:17:53.474 --> 00:17:58.202
its number five in this process as well
as it is in availability management and

322
00:17:58.202 --> 00:18:01.930
capacity management,
it's that financial information.

323
00:18:01.930 --> 00:18:06.880
How much money have we got to
spend in service continuity?

324
00:18:06.880 --> 00:18:08.440
Obviously that's gonna play a big part.

325
00:18:08.440 --> 00:18:11.650
If we don't have the money to
have to have a hot standby,

326
00:18:11.650 --> 00:18:14.120
then we're not going to
have a mirrored site.

327
00:18:14.120 --> 00:18:15.190
It's as simple as that.

328
00:18:15.190 --> 00:18:18.020
We've got to be able to pay for it.

329
00:18:18.020 --> 00:18:20.990
And the outputs then,
well, are a policy and

330
00:18:20.990 --> 00:18:25.700
a revised policy if we've already got one,
business impact analysis results and

331
00:18:25.700 --> 00:18:30.160
risk assessment results as well,
and then testing schedules.

332
00:18:30.160 --> 00:18:33.970
Yeah, and
don't forget the testing reports.

333
00:18:33.970 --> 00:18:37.480
What happened when we tested?

334
00:18:37.480 --> 00:18:38.580
Simple as that.

335
00:18:38.580 --> 00:18:39.840
You have to test.

336
00:18:39.840 --> 00:18:43.890
And it's not just a case of
a walk through of your plans.

337
00:18:43.890 --> 00:18:49.250
We should be doing a test of
our service continuity at least

338
00:18:49.250 --> 00:18:52.490
once a year, and
after any major change as well.

339
00:18:53.990 --> 00:18:56.010
So what about our processes then?

340
00:18:56.010 --> 00:18:58.536
What sort of interactions do
we have with other processes?

341
00:18:58.536 --> 00:19:03.430
Well, absolutely anything could and

342
00:19:03.430 --> 00:19:09.900
does need to be backed up, and
then recovered in the case of a disaster,.

343
00:19:09.900 --> 00:19:12.630
So all of these will have an input and

344
00:19:12.630 --> 00:19:16.010
will have a relationship into
Service Continuity Management.

345
00:19:16.010 --> 00:19:19.160
Well, let's think about, let's start
with capacity management, for instance.

346
00:19:19.160 --> 00:19:21.060
Capacity management, well,

347
00:19:21.060 --> 00:19:25.470
they've gotta make sure we've got
enough capacity disaster recovery site.

348
00:19:25.470 --> 00:19:27.500
What about asset and
configuration management?

349
00:19:27.500 --> 00:19:32.390
They tell us how the services are made up,
what components are in our services.

350
00:19:32.390 --> 00:19:34.360
What about information
security management?

351
00:19:34.360 --> 00:19:37.160
We've already mentioned
security on our plans.

352
00:19:37.160 --> 00:19:39.540
But think about security
in our DR sites and

353
00:19:39.540 --> 00:19:42.920
security on our recovery servers as well.

354
00:19:42.920 --> 00:19:47.840
We still got to maintain exactly
the same profiles as we did

355
00:19:47.840 --> 00:19:49.200
in our live environment.

356
00:19:49.200 --> 00:19:52.510
Bear in mind that different
people might have different roles

357
00:19:52.510 --> 00:19:54.780
in the case of a disaster.

358
00:19:54.780 --> 00:19:56.790
So all of that's gotta be contained.

359
00:19:56.790 --> 00:20:01.720
And I mentioned in our previous episode
that in service level management we should

360
00:20:01.720 --> 00:20:07.270
have different service level targets for
a continuity event.

361
00:20:07.270 --> 00:20:12.379
So any continuity event should have
different targets for availability and

362
00:20:12.379 --> 00:20:18.226
different targets for capacity, different
targets for incident management, etc.

363
00:20:18.226 --> 00:20:23.548
And of course, availability is
going to help define those targets,

364
00:20:23.548 --> 00:20:28.160
include in those targets
in the event of a disaster.

365
00:20:28.160 --> 00:20:30.350
So, let's take a look at
incident management now then.

366
00:20:30.350 --> 00:20:32.930
Incident management is a tricky one.

367
00:20:32.930 --> 00:20:36.700
Okay, because incident management, well,

368
00:20:36.700 --> 00:20:41.020
what is considered to be a disaster, and
what isn't considered to be a disaster?

369
00:20:41.020 --> 00:20:43.290
What's just a major incident?

370
00:20:43.290 --> 00:20:45.460
And is a disaster a major incident?

371
00:20:46.800 --> 00:20:47.790
That's up to you.

372
00:20:47.790 --> 00:20:49.850
That's part of your invocation criteria.

373
00:20:49.850 --> 00:20:52.190
But it's also part of your
service level agreement and

374
00:20:52.190 --> 00:20:53.820
needs to be agreed with the customer.

375
00:20:53.820 --> 00:20:59.100
And it's also part of your
incident procedures as well.

376
00:20:59.100 --> 00:21:01.570
So you should have a model.

377
00:21:01.570 --> 00:21:04.640
And if you don't understand
the concept of models, go back and

378
00:21:04.640 --> 00:21:08.310
take a look at your foundation material,
and also go and

379
00:21:08.310 --> 00:21:12.800
take a a look at the material on incident
management on the service operations show.

380
00:21:12.800 --> 00:21:19.780
But you should have a model for the event
of a disaster within incident management.

381
00:21:19.780 --> 00:21:21.790
And the problem management,
exactly the same.

382
00:21:21.790 --> 00:21:25.500
Problem management is about identifying
the root cause of an incident.

383
00:21:25.500 --> 00:21:29.160
So problem management will help us

384
00:21:29.160 --> 00:21:32.850
to find out what went wrong
in the case of a disaster.

385
00:21:34.590 --> 00:21:41.600
We do not expect you to go rooting around
for root causes when something's happened.

386
00:21:41.600 --> 00:21:45.560
We expect you to pick up the pieces and
then go and find out what went wrong.

387
00:21:45.560 --> 00:21:48.455
Our priority has to be
on restoring service.

388
00:21:48.455 --> 00:21:51.965
So our priority in the case of
service continuity is always on

389
00:21:51.965 --> 00:21:54.545
incident management,
it's on restoring service.

390
00:21:54.545 --> 00:21:56.645
And then we'll go and
find out what caused it.

391
00:21:56.645 --> 00:21:59.301
We don't need to go and
find out what caused it straightaway,

392
00:21:59.301 --> 00:22:01.329
we just need to get things back up and
running.

393
00:22:01.329 --> 00:22:03.986
>> And I guess you could maybe say
the same for change management as well,

394
00:22:03.986 --> 00:22:04.492
right, Jo?

395
00:22:04.492 --> 00:22:05.306
Looking at priorities.

396
00:22:05.306 --> 00:22:08.462
Because we're not gonna be
looking at implementing some,

397
00:22:08.462 --> 00:22:12.501
if we had a scheduled new e-mail server
that we we're gonna be setting up and

398
00:22:12.501 --> 00:22:17.040
spinning up, then that's kind of pushed
to the back burner at this point in time.

399
00:22:17.040 --> 00:22:20.450
>> Right, but then that's not the reason
why Change Management is in here.

400
00:22:20.450 --> 00:22:23.670
Change Management is actually in here
because, and I mean you're right,

401
00:22:23.670 --> 00:22:26.110
there's nothing wrong with
what you're saying at all.

402
00:22:26.110 --> 00:22:27.460
We do have to consider that.

403
00:22:27.460 --> 00:22:31.620
And if there are any changes,
then Change Management or

404
00:22:31.620 --> 00:22:35.060
the actual implementation of changes is
the last thing that we're going to be

405
00:22:35.060 --> 00:22:37.840
doing because we're implementing
changes in the live environment, and

406
00:22:37.840 --> 00:22:41.250
if the live environment's no longer there,
then we can't do that, right?

407
00:22:41.250 --> 00:22:44.530
But the reason that change management is
actually in here is because whenever we

408
00:22:44.530 --> 00:22:49.450
make any major change, we have to ensure
that we change the disaster recovery site.

409
00:22:49.450 --> 00:22:53.718
So anything that's changed in the live
environment has to be reflected in the DR

410
00:22:53.718 --> 00:22:55.450
site, in our continuity site.

411
00:22:55.450 --> 00:22:56.812
So that's why-
>> Makes sense.

412
00:22:56.812 --> 00:23:00.150
>> Yeah, that's why we have
change management in there.

413
00:23:00.150 --> 00:23:02.740
So what about roles and
responsibilities, then?

414
00:23:02.740 --> 00:23:03.960
Well, you know what?

415
00:23:03.960 --> 00:23:06.810
With service continuity management,
you've got to have an owner.

416
00:23:06.810 --> 00:23:08.780
Somebody's got to take ownership of this,
and

417
00:23:08.780 --> 00:23:12.000
you've got to have somebody that
manages it on a day to day basis.

418
00:23:12.000 --> 00:23:16.800
But everybody, and this is what
I like to point out to people,

419
00:23:16.800 --> 00:23:19.998
everybody's got a responsibility for
service continuity management.

420
00:23:19.998 --> 00:23:24.890
We all need to know what we need
to do in the case of a disaster,

421
00:23:24.890 --> 00:23:26.470
we all need to know that.

422
00:23:26.470 --> 00:23:30.530
So, yes, that's service
continuity owner and manager.

423
00:23:30.530 --> 00:23:32.000
Well, look at what they need to do.

424
00:23:32.000 --> 00:23:35.900
They need to participate in
business impact analysis along with

425
00:23:35.900 --> 00:23:40.810
the business relationship manager and
financial management.

426
00:23:40.810 --> 00:23:43.690
They need to assess
service continuity issues.

427
00:23:43.690 --> 00:23:46.151
They need to maintain
a service continuity strategy.

428
00:23:46.151 --> 00:23:49.550
And that may even mean looking at
the international standards and

429
00:23:49.550 --> 00:23:53.217
other frameworks that there are for
service continuity management.

430
00:23:53.217 --> 00:23:54.838
Yes, they need to do all of this.

431
00:23:54.838 --> 00:23:59.507
They need to do the postmortem or
rather as you call them in the states,

432
00:23:59.507 --> 00:24:03.388
the autopsy reports on what went wrong but
nevertheless,

433
00:24:03.388 --> 00:24:09.620
we all still have a responsibility for
undertaking service continuity management.

434
00:24:09.620 --> 00:24:11.080
Everybody's got to be aware.

435
00:24:11.080 --> 00:24:15.560
And as I've already mentioned, including
staff, including the organization and

436
00:24:15.560 --> 00:24:17.900
including possibly our customers as well.

437
00:24:17.900 --> 00:24:20.570
Everybody needs to be aware
that something's happened.

438
00:24:21.740 --> 00:24:24.700
And as we've already mentioned,
assessing changes for

439
00:24:24.700 --> 00:24:26.740
their impact on service continuity.

440
00:24:26.740 --> 00:24:31.550
Whenever we make a change, we've got to
think about our service continuity site.

441
00:24:31.550 --> 00:24:34.130
Which is why our service
continuity manager

442
00:24:34.130 --> 00:24:37.140
should be part of that
change advisory board.

443
00:24:37.140 --> 00:24:39.960
Whenever we talk about something
that's going to affect

444
00:24:39.960 --> 00:24:41.820
the whole of the organization.

445
00:24:41.820 --> 00:24:45.570
It's gonna affect our IT services
then they need to be present.

446
00:24:45.570 --> 00:24:50.870
Cuz they need to make sure that's
reflected in our service continuity site.

447
00:24:50.870 --> 00:24:52.908
So, what is it that we need to achieve?

448
00:24:54.763 --> 00:24:59.470
We'll, we've gotta have regular audits
of our service continuity plans.

449
00:24:59.470 --> 00:25:03.187
And this is where I always get
quite frustrated sometimes

450
00:25:03.187 --> 00:25:07.768
when I see the word regular,because
once every ten years is regular.

451
00:25:07.768 --> 00:25:10.270
[LAUGH] So what does that mean, right?

452
00:25:12.450 --> 00:25:16.410
And the other words that we like to
use in IT a lot where appropriate and

453
00:25:16.410 --> 00:25:17.370
what does that mean.

454
00:25:17.370 --> 00:25:19.850
It's where appropriate for you.

455
00:25:19.850 --> 00:25:23.840
Regular ordinance does not meet once every
ten years, it means at least once a year.

456
00:25:23.840 --> 00:25:27.660
But you can do it every three months or
six months if you want to.

457
00:25:27.660 --> 00:25:32.120
We have to make sure that all of
the targets in our SLAs obviously

458
00:25:32.120 --> 00:25:36.150
are not just agreed for our live
environment but are also agreed for

459
00:25:36.150 --> 00:25:38.250
our continuity environment as well.

460
00:25:38.250 --> 00:25:40.190
And we have to have regular tests.

461
00:25:40.190 --> 00:25:44.740
Not just of the plans but of also of
the service continuity mechanism as well.

462
00:25:46.860 --> 00:25:49.870
How regular that is is entirely up to you.

463
00:25:49.870 --> 00:25:54.550
In terms of staff awareness, and
staff preparedness, and training, and

464
00:25:54.550 --> 00:25:55.280
briefings, etc.

465
00:25:55.280 --> 00:25:59.090
If you want to go for, and
I've mentioned this in a previous episode,

466
00:25:59.090 --> 00:26:02.108
an ISO 20,000 audit, for instance.

467
00:26:02.108 --> 00:26:07.790
Then an auditor, I will come along and
I will ask anybody within your IT

468
00:26:07.790 --> 00:26:13.080
service provider whether you actually know
where your service continuity plans are.

469
00:26:13.080 --> 00:26:17.160
And if one person in the whole of
IT tells me that they don't know

470
00:26:17.160 --> 00:26:21.490
where the service continuity plans are,
then I am going to be failing that audit.

471
00:26:21.490 --> 00:26:23.440
Because quite simply, you need to know.

472
00:26:23.440 --> 00:26:24.850
Everybody needs to be aware.

473
00:26:25.930 --> 00:26:30.730
So we have to have, well business
continuity management because we have to

474
00:26:30.730 --> 00:26:32.740
understand what's
important to the business.

475
00:26:32.740 --> 00:26:34.230
It's important to the organization.

476
00:26:35.840 --> 00:26:39.510
We cannot make decisions on their behalf.

477
00:26:39.510 --> 00:26:42.470
We have to understand what their
vital business functions are and

478
00:26:42.470 --> 00:26:45.780
how they want to operate
should a disaster occur.

479
00:26:46.930 --> 00:26:52.280
In our previous episode I mentioned
about you know a supermarket and

480
00:26:52.280 --> 00:26:55.700
the fact that its vital to business
function is to sell stuff.

481
00:26:55.700 --> 00:26:57.790
Ordinarily on a day to day basis.

482
00:26:57.790 --> 00:27:00.090
But you know if something
happens to that supermarket,

483
00:27:00.090 --> 00:27:03.241
let's say it burns to the ground then
its vital business function changes.

484
00:27:03.241 --> 00:27:07.100
And its vital business function is
actually then to direct people,

485
00:27:07.100 --> 00:27:11.260
customers to the nearest
store within the same chain.

486
00:27:11.260 --> 00:27:14.540
And it's our job to support that,

487
00:27:14.540 --> 00:27:17.780
it's not our job to change that
because you can't change it.

488
00:27:17.780 --> 00:27:19.369
We've got to support the organization.

489
00:27:20.810 --> 00:27:23.330
We've gotta be completely
aligned with what they want and

490
00:27:23.330 --> 00:27:28.310
of they don't have business continuity,
then that's going to be a problem to us.

491
00:27:28.310 --> 00:27:30.660
We have to meet their objectives.

492
00:27:30.660 --> 00:27:35.690
But we have to ensure that everybody
in the organization is aware when there

493
00:27:35.690 --> 00:27:40.110
is a disaster and
when we have invoked service continuity.

494
00:27:42.290 --> 00:27:47.230
So, we've all ready mentioned the lack of
business continuity management process but

495
00:27:47.230 --> 00:27:51.090
look at the lack of support and the lack
of commitment for business continuity.

496
00:27:51.090 --> 00:27:56.360
This is quite often manifested as
lack of finances and lack of money.

497
00:27:56.360 --> 00:27:58.140
That's how we see it.

498
00:27:58.140 --> 00:28:02.610
And when we don't have the funds to
perform business continuity management,

499
00:28:02.610 --> 00:28:06.870
then this is when we
expose ourselves to risk.

500
00:28:06.870 --> 00:28:08.670
I'm not gonna tell you
that that's wrong and

501
00:28:08.670 --> 00:28:10.870
I'm not gonna tell you that
that's right obviously.

502
00:28:10.870 --> 00:28:13.360
What I'm gonna tell you is that

503
00:28:13.360 --> 00:28:16.910
whatever decision you make in
terms of business continuity and

504
00:28:16.910 --> 00:28:21.310
in terms of IT service continuity
to support the business continuity.

505
00:28:21.310 --> 00:28:27.300
Well, you have to assess the risk and
you make the decision based on the risks.

506
00:28:27.300 --> 00:28:29.890
And that decision needs
to be documented and

507
00:28:29.890 --> 00:28:32.530
you need to be able to
justify your decision.

508
00:28:32.530 --> 00:28:37.080
There is no right or wrong, but these
are all things that you have to consider.

509
00:28:37.080 --> 00:28:39.950
And you have to ensure that when
you perform the risk analysis,

510
00:28:39.950 --> 00:28:43.790
especially risk analysis on whether
to simply have service continuity or

511
00:28:43.790 --> 00:28:47.440
not, when you perform that risk analysis,
it's not done in isolation.

512
00:28:47.440 --> 00:28:51.920
It's not something that we do here in IT,
and we forget about the organization.

513
00:28:53.630 --> 00:28:56.550
So now what I'd like you to do,

514
00:28:56.550 --> 00:29:01.590
because we've wrapped up our episodes
now on service continuity management.

515
00:29:01.590 --> 00:29:06.725
You do have a couple of exercises
in your downloadable material and

516
00:29:06.725 --> 00:29:10.275
what I'd like for
you to do is to download that material and

517
00:29:10.275 --> 00:29:14.305
I'd like you to go through
those exercises that you have.

518
00:29:14.305 --> 00:29:16.675
If you have any queries
about those exercises,

519
00:29:16.675 --> 00:29:21.222
if you have any concerns at all, then
please come back to us by the forum and

520
00:29:21.222 --> 00:29:24.982
I will be happy to help in
anyway that I possibly can.

521
00:29:24.982 --> 00:29:28.142
>> Thank you Jo, we appreciate that, and
thank you for joining us as well, but for

522
00:29:28.142 --> 00:29:30.252
this show she's right, we are out of time.

523
00:29:30.252 --> 00:29:31.892
We're gonna go ahead and sign out.

524
00:29:31.892 --> 00:29:33.462
I've been your host Cherokee Boose.

525
00:29:33.462 --> 00:29:34.222
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

526
00:29:34.222 --> 00:29:36.531
>> See you next time here at ITProTV.

527
00:29:36.531 --> 00:29:42.416
[MUSIC]

528
00:29:42.416 --> 00:29:45.637
>> Thank you for watching ITPro.TV.

Jo explains how it is meant to align IT security with business security and ensure that the confidentiality, integrity and availability of the organizationâ€™s assets, information, data and IT services always matches the agreed needs of the business.

00:29:10.700 --> 00:29:12.835
>> We'll find you out there.

533
00:29:12.835 --> 00:29:14.228
>> Yep, [LAUGH] out there somewhere.

534
00:29:14.228 --> 00:29:17.019
>> Thank you so much for
being with us, but stay tuned,

535
00:29:17.019 --> 00:29:19.620
we have more information headed your way.

536
00:29:19.620 --> 00:29:22.459
For this show, we'll go ahead and sign
out, I've been your host, Cherokee Boose.

537
00:29:22.459 --> 00:29:23.365
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

538
00:29:23.365 --> 00:29:25.209
>> See you next time here on ITProTV.

539
00:29:25.209 --> 00:29:32.534
[MUSIC]

540
00:29:32.534 --> 00:29:35.173
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this show, Cherokee and Jo continue discussing design activities. First, they look at application management, application frameworks, design of specific applications and managing trade offs. Other details such as design patterns, consistent coding conventions, templates and code generation are covered as well. Tune in for more!
episodes.title: Service Design Activities Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.270 --> 00:00:01.108
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.108 --> 00:00:02.877
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

3
00:00:02.877 --> 00:00:07.235
[CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:07.235 --> 00:00:08.239
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:08.239 --> 00:00:12.274
>> You're watching ITProTV.

6
00:00:12.274 --> 00:00:14.116
>> Welcome to your
ITIL Intermediate Series.

7
00:00:14.116 --> 00:00:16.153
I'm your show host Cherokee Boose.

8
00:00:16.153 --> 00:00:19.913
This is actually a part two where we
continue taking a look at our service

9
00:00:19.913 --> 00:00:21.760
design activities.

10
00:00:21.760 --> 00:00:22.962
In the previous episode,

11
00:00:22.962 --> 00:00:26.400
Jo walked us through the process
of looking at some types of

12
00:00:26.400 --> 00:00:30.910
data management as well as different
types of functional specifications.

13
00:00:30.910 --> 00:00:34.390
She promised us application
management in the series

14
00:00:34.390 --> 00:00:36.730
along with a few other surprises,
I'm sure.

15
00:00:36.730 --> 00:00:38.660
So thank you for joining us today, Jo.

16
00:00:38.660 --> 00:00:39.330
How's it going?

17
00:00:39.330 --> 00:00:42.430
>> I promise all the surprises
will be pleasant surprises.

18
00:00:42.430 --> 00:00:42.948
How's that?

19
00:00:42.948 --> 00:00:44.950
>> [LAUGH] That's great.

20
00:00:44.950 --> 00:00:45.580
Always a plus.

21
00:00:46.600 --> 00:00:49.980
>> In this particular episode, we're going
to be looking at application management,

22
00:00:49.980 --> 00:00:52.080
the concepts of application management and

23
00:00:52.080 --> 00:00:55.950
the difference between application
management and application development.

24
00:00:55.950 --> 00:00:58.100
So where should we start off, then?

25
00:00:58.100 --> 00:01:02.150
By looking at, well,
what is application management?

26
00:01:02.150 --> 00:01:04.070
Well, it's about managing
our applications.

27
00:01:04.070 --> 00:01:06.260
How's that then for straightforward?

28
00:01:06.260 --> 00:01:12.190
An application is really our software and
software functions.

29
00:01:12.190 --> 00:01:13.810
What our software does.

30
00:01:13.810 --> 00:01:15.950
That's what we consider
to be an application.

31
00:01:15.950 --> 00:01:18.550
So an application is just
one component of a service.

32
00:01:18.550 --> 00:01:23.285
And if you remember, the components of
a service are software and hardware and

33
00:01:23.285 --> 00:01:27.820
the environment and the people that use
the service and the people that also

34
00:01:27.820 --> 00:01:31.830
develop and support the service and
our infrastructure and our documentation.

35
00:01:31.830 --> 00:01:35.190
And all of those elements are being
designed here in service design.

36
00:01:36.290 --> 00:01:44.030
But we do have a specific team that looks
specifically, again, at applications.

37
00:01:44.030 --> 00:01:46.740
And we have what we call
an application management team.

38
00:01:46.740 --> 00:01:51.550
And the application management team, well,
they work out the functional requirements

39
00:01:51.550 --> 00:01:56.700
for an application, and
they then go on to support

40
00:01:56.700 --> 00:02:01.860
an application, as well, once that
application is in the live environment.

41
00:02:01.860 --> 00:02:07.680
Now, I want you to think of this as,
how do I say this?

42
00:02:07.680 --> 00:02:10.560
We've got a subset of
application management, and

43
00:02:10.560 --> 00:02:13.520
we call them application development.

44
00:02:13.520 --> 00:02:18.850
Application development is an optional
subset of application management.

45
00:02:20.020 --> 00:02:23.941
When we first start off with a new
service, somebody has got to agree that,

46
00:02:23.941 --> 00:02:27.445
yes, this new service is gonna ahead and
we start the project off.

47
00:02:27.445 --> 00:02:30.810
And at that point in time,
application management come along and

48
00:02:30.810 --> 00:02:33.940
they gather the functional
requirements for that service.

49
00:02:35.090 --> 00:02:37.280
And then one of two things happen.

50
00:02:37.280 --> 00:02:41.480
We either develop it in-house or
we go outside and

51
00:02:41.480 --> 00:02:45.010
we buy something commercial off the shelf,
or COTS, as we call this.

52
00:02:45.010 --> 00:02:48.062
Or maybe we buy something that
we in England call bespoke, but

53
00:02:48.062 --> 00:02:50.363
I think you guys probably
call tailor-made.

54
00:02:50.363 --> 00:02:51.688
>> Yeah, custom.

55
00:02:51.688 --> 00:02:54.446
Bespoke is not too popular here,
at least that I've encountered.

56
00:02:54.446 --> 00:02:56.073
But I would know what it meant.

57
00:02:56.073 --> 00:02:57.200
>> It sounds better though, right?

58
00:02:57.200 --> 00:02:57.897
>> It does sound better.

59
00:02:57.897 --> 00:02:58.667
>> Yeah, I like it.

60
00:02:58.667 --> 00:03:01.400
>> [LAUGH]
>> We'll stick with bespoke, okay?

61
00:03:01.400 --> 00:03:03.680
So we need to do one of three things.

62
00:03:03.680 --> 00:03:05.190
We either build it in-house,

63
00:03:05.190 --> 00:03:09.570
which again is bespoke, we either
get somebody else to build it for

64
00:03:09.570 --> 00:03:14.030
us, bespoke, or we'll buy it off
the shelf, COTS, commercial off the shelf.

65
00:03:15.430 --> 00:03:18.610
All three of those are what we
call application development.

66
00:03:18.610 --> 00:03:21.908
So application management
is kind of the big banner.

67
00:03:21.908 --> 00:03:24.633
And underneath,
we've got application development.

68
00:03:24.633 --> 00:03:29.730
And then once application development have
finished the design and the development,

69
00:03:29.730 --> 00:03:34.547
it's then passed back to application
management to then manage the transition,

70
00:03:34.547 --> 00:03:36.110
they do it both together.

71
00:03:36.110 --> 00:03:38.977
And then application
management carry on and

72
00:03:38.977 --> 00:03:42.229
support the application
in the live environment.

73
00:03:42.229 --> 00:03:47.368
So think of application development as
being a subset of application management.

74
00:03:47.368 --> 00:03:52.748
However, application
development can be external.

75
00:03:52.748 --> 00:03:55.917
You know, application management can also
be external as well, just to try and

76
00:03:55.917 --> 00:03:56.970
confuse things.

77
00:03:56.970 --> 00:03:59.810
And certainly, if we're going with
commercial off-the-shelf product,

78
00:03:59.810 --> 00:04:01.650
then the support of that and

79
00:04:01.650 --> 00:04:05.080
therefore the ongoing application
management may well be offsite.

80
00:04:06.800 --> 00:04:10.340
So don't think of this as being
something that's predominantly in house,

81
00:04:10.340 --> 00:04:13.790
it doesn't have to be, but it can be.

82
00:04:14.810 --> 00:04:18.194
So we need to have a portfolio
of our applications.

83
00:04:18.194 --> 00:04:22.009
And in our application portfolio,
well, I expect that to be a database

84
00:04:22.009 --> 00:04:26.330
that feeds into our service asset and
configuration management process.

85
00:04:26.330 --> 00:04:30.920
So it feeds into both our service
portfolios and into our configuration

86
00:04:30.920 --> 00:04:36.230
management system, because an application
is a component of a service.

87
00:04:37.550 --> 00:04:41.010
And as we know, if we take a look
at service transition, and

88
00:04:41.010 --> 00:04:44.300
in fact, way back in your
foundation material as well,

89
00:04:44.300 --> 00:04:48.170
then we saw that knowledge management
ensured that all of our relationships

90
00:04:48.170 --> 00:04:52.409
between our databases went through
our configuration management system.

91
00:04:53.790 --> 00:04:59.630
We'll have a framework for
how we both design and

92
00:04:59.630 --> 00:05:03.100
how we develop and
how we manage our applications.

93
00:05:04.360 --> 00:05:06.950
And it's really important that we do this,

94
00:05:06.950 --> 00:05:10.730
because we want a standard way
of approaching applications.

95
00:05:10.730 --> 00:05:14.541
Whether it will be a standard way
of developing an application, or

96
00:05:14.541 --> 00:05:19.509
if we're going outside for development, a
standard way of sourcing new suppliers for

97
00:05:19.509 --> 00:05:20.678
our applications.

98
00:05:20.678 --> 00:05:25.764
And a standard way of then
supporting those applications.

99
00:05:25.764 --> 00:05:27.497
But we must have a standard.

100
00:05:27.497 --> 00:05:30.408
If we were to do everything
in an ad-hoc way and

101
00:05:30.408 --> 00:05:34.887
if we were to do everything in a specific
service by service by service,

102
00:05:34.887 --> 00:05:39.817
then we'd find that we'd have quite
a dysfunctional application management

103
00:05:39.817 --> 00:05:43.360
team and
application management group of people.

104
00:05:43.360 --> 00:05:46.710
Sometimes you might call them
the developers or the software team.

105
00:05:46.710 --> 00:05:50.480
And as I've always said, this is ITIL.

106
00:05:50.480 --> 00:05:51.700
We'll give you a framework and

107
00:05:51.700 --> 00:05:55.230
it's up to you then to adapt
that framework to suit you.

108
00:05:55.230 --> 00:05:57.940
So what you call these people,
that's entirely up to you.

109
00:05:57.940 --> 00:06:02.760
We're just talking about the activities
that these people will undertake.

110
00:06:02.760 --> 00:06:07.259
You need to have a consistent approach to
both the design and the build and the test

111
00:06:07.259 --> 00:06:11.779
of our software, and then a consistent
approach to the support of our software.

112
00:06:11.779 --> 00:06:18.810
Because an ad-hoc approach, or a service
by service approach, is not efficient.

113
00:06:18.810 --> 00:06:20.970
Now, I'm not saying that there
shouldn't be anomalies in there,

114
00:06:20.970 --> 00:06:22.280
because of course there should.

115
00:06:23.420 --> 00:06:26.210
Every service is different, and
every single application and

116
00:06:26.210 --> 00:06:28.490
every single piece of
hardware is different.

117
00:06:28.490 --> 00:06:30.460
So of course you're
going to have specifics.

118
00:06:30.460 --> 00:06:34.260
But nevertheless,
we should all follow a standard approach.

119
00:06:34.260 --> 00:06:36.340
So what about the design
of our applications?

120
00:06:36.340 --> 00:06:40.190
Well, it says here the design is one
of the most important phases, but

121
00:06:40.190 --> 00:06:43.680
to be perfectly honest,
the design is the most important phase,

122
00:06:43.680 --> 00:06:48.850
because this is where we design
what we're going to develop and

123
00:06:48.850 --> 00:06:52.820
therefore what we're going to deliver and
what we have to support.

124
00:06:54.110 --> 00:06:59.880
This is about where we take the customer
and the end user perception of value and

125
00:06:59.880 --> 00:07:02.860
then we design something that's
going to deliver value and

126
00:07:02.860 --> 00:07:06.110
is going to facilitate their outcomes.

127
00:07:06.110 --> 00:07:09.300
So we have to think about
here in service design.

128
00:07:09.300 --> 00:07:11.570
We're not just thinking about the project.

129
00:07:11.570 --> 00:07:14.650
We're thinking about in service design
the availability requirements and

130
00:07:14.650 --> 00:07:16.320
the capacity requirements.

131
00:07:16.320 --> 00:07:18.879
And then also maintainability and
reliability.

132
00:07:18.879 --> 00:07:21.743
How we're going to fix
something if it goes wrong.

133
00:07:21.743 --> 00:07:26.357
And then security and
continuity requirements as well.

134
00:07:26.357 --> 00:07:29.587
And then think about our tradeoffs too.

135
00:07:29.587 --> 00:07:31.433
And of course, our design tradeoffs, and

136
00:07:31.433 --> 00:07:34.140
we talk about this when we
look at project management.

137
00:07:34.140 --> 00:07:39.539
Our design tradeoffs include
the tradeoff between the resources and

138
00:07:39.539 --> 00:07:44.285
the skills we've got available,
and the functionality and

139
00:07:44.285 --> 00:07:47.820
the time,
which is the schedule itself, and

140
00:07:47.820 --> 00:07:51.933
the requirements and
the money that we have as well.

141
00:07:51.933 --> 00:07:55.040
We have to think about the tradeoff here.

142
00:07:55.040 --> 00:07:57.530
The more money we spend then you'd like to

143
00:07:57.530 --> 00:08:00.790
think that the more
functionality that we could get.

144
00:08:00.790 --> 00:08:03.250
But then the more functionality
that we're getting,

145
00:08:03.250 --> 00:08:06.520
then the longer it's going to take us
to develop that and to deploy that.

146
00:08:07.580 --> 00:08:12.470
The shorter the time scale we have,
then the chances are the less

147
00:08:12.470 --> 00:08:15.840
functionality that we can
implement in a short time scale.

148
00:08:15.840 --> 00:08:18.770
But sometimes a short time scale
means investing more money,

149
00:08:18.770 --> 00:08:21.570
because we've gotta get it out
of the door quicker, as it were.

150
00:08:23.060 --> 00:08:24.859
You've gotta get your balance right.

151
00:08:24.859 --> 00:08:27.710
And this needs to be done
within the project team.

152
00:08:27.710 --> 00:08:32.680
And it's the project team that will help
with this, even though we will support and

153
00:08:32.680 --> 00:08:35.660
we will help with
the operational aspect of that.

154
00:08:37.010 --> 00:08:40.338
You need to include the following,
like the user interface.

155
00:08:40.338 --> 00:08:45.130
And this is why we talk about utility and
warranty.

156
00:08:45.130 --> 00:08:49.010
We talk about the utility being,
does it do what it's supposed to do?

157
00:08:49.010 --> 00:08:51.543
And the warranty being, can I use it?

158
00:08:51.543 --> 00:08:55.845
And here we are in this
warranty aspect thinking about

159
00:08:55.845 --> 00:08:58.719
the usability of any given server.

160
00:08:59.720 --> 00:09:02.070
It's okay being able to send and
receive email, but

161
00:09:02.070 --> 00:09:05.080
if it's not available when you need it,
or if it's so

162
00:09:05.080 --> 00:09:09.210
cumbersome that we can't actually
really send an email, or we can't send

163
00:09:09.210 --> 00:09:13.090
the size of attachment that we need to,
then what's the point in having it?

164
00:09:13.090 --> 00:09:15.230
Will the users perceive value?

165
00:09:15.230 --> 00:09:16.620
That's what we're aiming towards.

166
00:09:16.620 --> 00:09:22.691
We're aiming to value perception and
to facilitate an outcome.

167
00:09:22.691 --> 00:09:25.654
We want to have, if we can, and I say if,

168
00:09:25.654 --> 00:09:29.670
a consistent design pattern
to all of our designs.

169
00:09:29.670 --> 00:09:34.159
What I would say to you is that we
should have a standard methodology for

170
00:09:34.159 --> 00:09:35.846
designing our services.

171
00:09:35.846 --> 00:09:41.270
Now, we talk about design patterns,
I want to see a consistent methodology.

172
00:09:41.270 --> 00:09:45.020
I want us to see maybe using an agile,
a waterfall approach,

173
00:09:45.020 --> 00:09:50.900
maybe using something like PRINCE2 or
PMP as an approach to project management.

174
00:09:50.900 --> 00:09:54.900
I'm not gonna tell you how to do this,
but I want to encourage consistency,

175
00:09:54.900 --> 00:09:58.080
because consistency is
obviously efficient.

176
00:09:58.080 --> 00:10:00.900
But in terms of the individual
applications themselves,

177
00:10:00.900 --> 00:10:02.880
of course there are going to be nuances.

178
00:10:02.880 --> 00:10:06.880
And of course each one is going
to be completely unique and,

179
00:10:06.880 --> 00:10:11.960
therefore, we have to design and
develop our services in a unique way.

180
00:10:11.960 --> 00:10:16.570
It's just that how we do that,
that needs to be consistent.

181
00:10:17.900 --> 00:10:24.330
And again we talk about consistent coding
conventions and code generation and using

182
00:10:24.330 --> 00:10:29.240
a consistent method of code generation and
maybe using consistent tools.

183
00:10:29.240 --> 00:10:32.910
Yet again, I can't tell you how to do
this, cuz it really depends on the service

184
00:10:32.910 --> 00:10:37.980
that you are developing and
the service that you will be supporting.

185
00:10:37.980 --> 00:10:41.890
But what I can tell you is that you need
to use a consistent method to do this,

186
00:10:41.890 --> 00:10:44.040
because that then promotes efficiency, and

187
00:10:44.040 --> 00:10:47.070
of course, that's exactly what
we're interesting in within ITIL.

188
00:10:48.780 --> 00:10:52.010
I'd like to think about
embedding the support

189
00:10:52.010 --> 00:10:54.920
tools within the application itself.

190
00:10:54.920 --> 00:10:58.330
It sounds kind of straightforward,
really, and

191
00:10:58.330 --> 00:11:02.010
it sounds really like common sense,
and of course it is.

192
00:11:02.010 --> 00:11:06.108
But it's not good implementing
something that you can't support.

193
00:11:06.108 --> 00:11:08.650
So design for support.

194
00:11:08.650 --> 00:11:10.846
It makes sense, of course you should.

195
00:11:10.846 --> 00:11:13.410
Design for diagnostic hooks.

196
00:11:13.410 --> 00:11:18.330
Which are those little hooks, the codes
within any application that we can

197
00:11:18.330 --> 00:11:23.220
go to and we can say, okay then,
I understand that the application does x,

198
00:11:23.220 --> 00:11:27.090
y, and zed or
z as you might refer to it as.

199
00:11:27.090 --> 00:11:32.000
It does x, y, and zed, and this is how
it does it, and now let's go through

200
00:11:32.000 --> 00:11:37.120
the workflow to try and diagnose where
something's gone wrong, where we might

201
00:11:37.120 --> 00:11:41.179
have functionality gaps or where we
might have functionality failures.

202
00:11:42.850 --> 00:11:48.290
What development has to give
us is a developed service and

203
00:11:48.290 --> 00:11:51.940
what design gives us
is a designed service.

204
00:11:51.940 --> 00:11:56.370
But application management
includes both the design and

205
00:11:56.370 --> 00:11:59.800
the development and
the ongoing support as well.

206
00:12:01.230 --> 00:12:04.630
So if I look at development and
the development side of things,

207
00:12:04.630 --> 00:12:06.670
you can see what comes out of development.

208
00:12:06.670 --> 00:12:10.180
You know, customized scripts and
specification of metrics.

209
00:12:10.180 --> 00:12:14.655
I want you to think of
your five design aspects,

210
00:12:14.655 --> 00:12:19.645
the five things that we design and
we design the complete service solution.

211
00:12:19.645 --> 00:12:23.375
But we also designed the tools
that we're going to use

212
00:12:23.375 --> 00:12:25.685
to support that service solution.

213
00:12:25.685 --> 00:12:28.293
We design our metrics as well.

214
00:12:28.293 --> 00:12:32.770
And we design our processes, and
we design our architectures.

215
00:12:32.770 --> 00:12:35.010
And I'm not just talking
about our network topology.

216
00:12:35.010 --> 00:12:37.850
I'm also talking about how we're
going to work together and

217
00:12:37.850 --> 00:12:43.055
what teams we're going to have to be able
to support a new service going forwards.

218
00:12:44.540 --> 00:12:47.840
Ultimately, with application management,
as I've already said,

219
00:12:47.840 --> 00:12:51.530
we're not just talking about
the management of our applications and

220
00:12:51.530 --> 00:12:54.100
the support,
we're also talking about development.

221
00:12:54.100 --> 00:12:57.840
And application management makes
the decision whether to build in-house or

222
00:12:57.840 --> 00:13:04.140
whether to go outside and
source from an external provider.

of the whole service design stage.

363
00:19:51.250 --> 00:19:57.151
I'd want to see that of the project over
a period of six months or 12 months etc.

364
00:19:57.151 --> 00:20:00.967
The accuracy of the service level
targets for instance again,

365
00:20:00.967 --> 00:20:03.640
I want to see these over
a set period of time.

366
00:20:04.950 --> 00:20:09.340
But only you will define the right
KPIs for your organization and for

367
00:20:09.340 --> 00:20:12.920
your individual project and
your individual implementation, too.

368
00:20:14.050 --> 00:20:16.480
So what can cause service
design to fail and

369
00:20:16.480 --> 00:20:20.730
what are the external factors that
could cause service design to fail?

370
00:20:20.730 --> 00:20:28.165
Well, we talk about maturity
levels of one process is low.

371
00:20:28.165 --> 00:20:31.110
You got to be really careful
with your processes.

372
00:20:31.110 --> 00:20:34.060
And when you're implementing processes
think about what processes you

373
00:20:34.060 --> 00:20:35.740
want to implement first.

374
00:20:35.740 --> 00:20:38.070
And the answer is never all of them,
right.

375
00:20:38.070 --> 00:20:42.510
You never ever when you're implementing
ITIL want to go all out and

376
00:20:42.510 --> 00:20:43.950
implement absolutely everything.

377
00:20:43.950 --> 00:20:45.100
That is not going to work.

378
00:20:46.180 --> 00:20:49.860
Well, it will work,
it will result in complete chaos,.

379
00:20:49.860 --> 00:20:53.650
That's what it will achieve but
that's not something that we want to do.

380
00:20:53.650 --> 00:20:58.280
So think about the CSI approach and
we'll do one at a time.

381
00:20:58.280 --> 00:21:02.790
And it's okay to get one to a specific
maturity level and then work on another

382
00:21:02.790 --> 00:21:06.550
one and then work on another one
as long as that is in your plan.

383
00:21:06.550 --> 00:21:11.380
But when you're up to say level three in
your CMMI scale on one process then you've

384
00:21:11.380 --> 00:21:15.330
got one that's down at level one, well
there's your opportunity for improvement.

385
00:21:15.330 --> 00:21:16.810
That's where you have to improve.

386
00:21:18.330 --> 00:21:19.280
What other risk are there,

387
00:21:19.280 --> 00:21:22.890
what other external factors are there
that could cause design to fail?

388
00:21:22.890 --> 00:21:25.170
Well let's go back to
the business requirements.

389
00:21:25.170 --> 00:21:28.000
And having poor business
relationship management which

390
00:21:28.000 --> 00:21:31.310
addresses things like requirements and
time scales ect and

391
00:21:31.310 --> 00:21:35.780
also addresses the testing aspect in
getting the business involved and tested.

392
00:21:35.780 --> 00:21:41.970
That could all be a risk to successful
design and that balance between risk and

393
00:21:41.970 --> 00:21:46.930
cost and innovation or between cost and
schedule and functionality,

394
00:21:46.930 --> 00:21:51.830
getting the balances wrong,
that can be a risk as well.

395
00:21:51.830 --> 00:21:53.240
That can cause us to fail.

396
00:21:54.780 --> 00:21:57.310
And over or under engineered processes.

397
00:21:57.310 --> 00:22:03.530
Over engineered processes are the biggest
bane of my existence, I have to say.

398
00:22:03.530 --> 00:22:06.050
If I see a process that's over-engineered,

399
00:22:06.050 --> 00:22:09.040
then in terms of maturity,
it's not gonna be great.

400
00:22:09.040 --> 00:22:13.190
And in fact in terms of CSI,
it's clearly not working at all.

401
00:22:13.190 --> 00:22:15.430
So it's never gonna make level five.

402
00:22:15.430 --> 00:22:17.700
But as far as efficiency is concerned?

403
00:22:17.700 --> 00:22:21.550
If it's over engineered,
it's generally not going to be efficient.

404
00:22:21.550 --> 00:22:25.540
I think of change management as a process
that's generally poorly designed,

405
00:22:25.540 --> 00:22:29.080
because we design in too much
bureaucracy into change management.

406
00:22:29.080 --> 00:22:31.900
And that actually causes inefficiencies,
not efficiencies.

407
00:22:31.900 --> 00:22:34.690
And so we wanna use models.

408
00:22:34.690 --> 00:22:40.280
We make use of process models in order
to ensure efficiencies in our processes.

409
00:22:40.280 --> 00:22:43.530
So I wanna take you back to
your foundational material and

410
00:22:43.530 --> 00:22:46.280
I wanna take you back to
the foundation recap.

411
00:22:46.280 --> 00:22:48.400
And I want to take you back
to service transition and

412
00:22:48.400 --> 00:22:54.280

413
00:22:55.440 --> 00:22:57.610

414

with functional development but

415
00:23:01.160 --> 00:23:03.060
I'm thinking about management
commitment as well.

416
00:23:03.060 --> 00:23:06.330
And I'm thinking about commitment
from the organization.

417
00:23:06.330 --> 00:23:11.380
There has to be an ongoing visible
commitment to service design in order for

418
00:23:11.380 --> 00:23:13.220
service design to succeed.

419
00:23:14.550 --> 00:23:19.760
So now at this point in time then,
we have reached the end of

420
00:23:19.760 --> 00:23:24.390
our how would I say coaching
episodes in service design.

421
00:23:24.390 --> 00:23:27.910
So what I'd like you to do
certainly at this point,

422
00:23:27.910 --> 00:23:31.130
is to go back over your material.

423
00:23:31.130 --> 00:23:35.600
You do have a couple of exercises that
look at organization for service design,

424
00:23:35.600 --> 00:23:39.020

design and I'd like you to go over them.

425
00:23:39.020 --> 00:23:44.000
And then what I'd like you to do
is I would like you then to review

426

429

then join us again and

the specific questions in that

So if you do have any questions then

00:24:17.025 --> 00:24:19.610

435
00:24:19.610 --> 00:24:22.290
>> Thank you for leading us through
that process of service design,

436
00:24:22.290 --> 00:24:26.430
Jo, as well as all those
other proceeding processes.

437
00:24:26.430 --> 00:24:28.280
So thank you for
being out there with us as well, but

438
00:24:28.280 --> 00:24:30.010
you've got some work to do like she said.

439
00:24:30.010 --> 00:24:32.670
So we're gonna go ahead and
sign out and let you get to that.

440
00:24:32.670 --> 00:24:34.740
For this show we'll go ahead and sign out.

441
00:24:34.740 --> 00:24:36.540
As your host I've been Cherokee Boose.

442
00:24:36.540 --> 00:24:37.430
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

443
00:24:37.430 --> 00:24:39.695

00:24:39.695 --> 00:24:45.750
[MUSIC]

00:24:45.750 --> 00:24:48.785
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo review some of the different techniques and details when sitting for your ITIL Intermediate exam. They recommend downloading the sample paper for review. Jo reviews the details on scoring of the exam. She also has solid exam advice for delegates preparing for an exam.

Well I've got an acronym for

First thing that I want you

episodes.description: Our Service Design show takes the ideas for new services born in Service Strategy and turns these into a defined blueprint for the development of the services. We look at the operational aspects to designing an IT service, such as Service Level Management, managing suppliers, and planning for service availability and resilience. All of our planning cumulates into a Design Package which we then handover to the Service Transition lifecycle phase. Like all ITIL shows we also look at critical success factors and key performance indicators and we do some exam prep too! For course completion certificates to be submitted for exams, please contact PassionIT Group.

episodes.description: Our Service Design show takes the ideas for new services born in Service Strategy and turns these into a defined blueprint for the development of the services. We look at the operational aspects to designing an IT service, such as Service Level Management, managing suppliers, and planning for service availability and resilience. All of our planning cumulates into a Design Package which we then handover to the Service Transition lifecycle phase. Like all ITIL shows we also look at critical success factors and key performance indicators and we do some exam prep too! For course completion certificates to be submitted for exams, please contact PassionIT Group.
